story:
Our Story

The Travel Yoga Project was born from a passion for yoga, travel, music, art, and the desire to make a difference.After living abroad teaching English at a shelter in South Africa, I traveled to Thailand to complete my thesis on gender inequality and human trafficking. Through these experiences, I was inspired to found an organization committed to creatively addressing the tragedy and violence that exists throughout the world today. 


The Travel Yoga Project is dedicated to a global effort to spread the joy of yoga to local populations. Our organization will use yoga as a tool for creating change from the inside out, from the ground up. We will use the art of yoga to empower people to heal, find their voice, discover their passion, and rise up to create change within their own communities! 

 

We will be launching the Travel Yoga Project with a trip to Indonesia this May. In Indonesia we will work in orphanages, shelters, and birthing clinics to share the transformative practice of yoga. Through yoga we will  build safe relationships, offer stimulating & soulful yoga classes, and provide teacher training to teenagers living in the orphanages. 


Beyond yoga, we full heartedly believe in the capacity of art and music to both inspire and generate awareness. With a fusion of photography, writing, film and music, we aspire to share the portraits of the human spirit illuminated along our journey, and our message of empowerment, unity, and unconditional love! T.Y.P. is not just for yoga lovers, but for all art, music travel, people, and plain life fanatics, moved by the pursuit of innovative ways to motivate social activism. 


You can follow our journey to Indonesia on www.travelyogaproject.wordpress.com


The Impact

Because yoga can be done anywhere, anytime, by anyone, it is an extremely effective, practical, and free tool for establishing personal growth and social change. Our hope is that the yoga we teach abroad will be a valuable instrument that will continue to foster healing and make waves long after we leave! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our work abroad is 100% volunteer and 100% of donations will be used to launch our project and cover a portion of the expenses of working at the orphanages, shelters, and birthing clinics. We will also provide yoga mats, as well as educational materials to ensure that our students can continue practicing after our departure. 


Currently, the project is entirely personally funded. Help us reach our goal of $3,000 dollars and make our efforts a greater success!


Out of extreme love for all of our supporters, we will be offering some fun perks as a thank you to each of you for donating. Receive framed photographs, T.Y.P. stickers, T.Y.P. t-shirts, 100 % recycled handmade Indonesian bags, handmade mala bracelets, and Indonesian music cd's!


Other Ways You Can Help


1.) Make some noise! Join our "Root Down, Rise Up” street team and help spread the word via grassroots efforts. Plan a concert, gallery opening, film showing, wine tasting, barbecue contest, brewery bus tour... Conjure up inventive ways to fundraise while creating awareness about our efforts!

 

2. Gifted in the realms of graphic design, film/photo editing, or the likes? Let your creative juices flow and help the Travel Yoga Project by working behind the scenes to construct T.Y.P. t-shirts, posters, stickers, and buttons, or revamp our website!

 

2. Share our project on your Facebook or Twitter page.

 

4. Send us ideas for your own travel yoga project! Work together with T.Y.P. to put your vision into action!

story:
Haitian Feminist Artist Seeks Educational Support

Artists are the lifeblood of the community…

WHO AM I?

My name is Marilyn Louis. I am a performing and visual artist and also a Haitian Diasporan, born in Niger and bred in Brooklyn, NY by Haitian immigrant parents. I am also a feminist, writer, yogi, and a lover of books. I have worked professionally as a dancer and teaching artist and have transitioned into expanding myself artistically and professional through musical theater.

As a multi-disciplinary artist, I recently, I exhibited my paintings for its exhibition, Reproductive Awakening: Narratives of Agency in Black America  at the Museum of Women’s Resistance (MoWRe).http://www.museumofwomensresistance.org/

Here are samples of my work: 

      


As the daughter of immigrant parents from a poor/working class background, the arts were never encouraged in me, especially as a profession. By helping me achieve my fundraising goal, you will help aspiring performing artists like myself and others be immersed fully in the arts without the burden of being held back due to lack of funds.

THIS CAMPAIGN IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE:

-  As a struggling artist, it came be very challenging to have funds to study the arts in a conservatory. This is why I am looking to you all to help me

-  Your contributions will jump-start my path towards continuing my training in the performing arts and building a career in what I love the most, performing!

-  - $2,000 will help to finance my educational goal of studying the craft of singing, dancing and acting and eventually work professionally as a triple threat.

-  The perks are that you will get the opportunity to see the growth I have gain as an artist through video clips of my performances.

THE IMPACT:

-  This project is valuable because young black female artists continue to be under-represented in the field of musical theater. Be contributing your dollars, you will help black women artists like me gain further training, thus eventually gain visibility

-  The impact of your contributions will help lessen, if not, alleviate the burden of having to scrape funds to continue my education in the arts.

-  Last year,  I was fortunate enough to raise funds to support my educational goals to attend the American Academy of Dramatic Arts (AADA) and would love to achieve that success again!


 

WHAT YOUR $10, $20, OR $30 YOU CONTRIBUTE WILL DO:

- It will help to pay the cost of tuition which covers classes, books and supplies.

- If I do not reach my entire goal by the deadline, the funds will be towards other future creative projects such as mixed-media works of art and/or writing workshops.

RISKS AND CHALLENGES:

- One risk to not achieving this goal in time is the likelihood of having to delay my dream of continuing to study the arts even later. As a late bloomer to discovering my talents, this cannot wait any longer.  

OTHERS WAYS TO HELP:

- If you are unable to contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help. I urge you all to ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

I await your contributions!

Marilyn Louis

story:
Español: a continuacion.

English: Please see below.

Français: Voir ci-dessous.

Español

Hace dos años la comunidad de Grand Boukan se organizó para hacer un regalo a sus niños y niñas: comenzó a funcionar la Escuela Comunitaria de Bassin Thomas.  Desde ese entonces, este pequeño proyecto que comenzó con menos de 30 niños ha cuadriplicado su matrícula y se ha convertido en la única posibilidad en la zona de obtener una educación básica.

Pero con los nuevos logros, nuevos retos también aparecen, entre éstos lograr la sostenibilidad a largo plazo del espacio. Nos enfrentamos a una falta de fondos y tenemos que hacer algo por los niños y las niñas de Grand Boukan. Y como dice el pueblo haitiano, “pitì pitì”, poco a poco, paso a paso nos dirigimos hacia esa meta.

Conoce la idea.

“Queremos ayudar”… pero ¿qué significa ayudar a alguien? ¿Cómo se ayuda a alguien? Podemos dar educación, comida, salud y diversión, pero ¿es eso suficiente? La nación africana Igbo tiene un dicho: “Ora na-azu nwa”, se necesita una aldea para criar un niño. Desde este proyecto, creemos en el rol de la aldea y la comunidad.

Noumenm es una palabra en Criollo Haitiano que significa a la vez “nosotros” y “vosotros”. Dentro de la expresión no hay diferencia alguna, sino que es el contexto el que otorga un significado sobre el otro. Así, cuando en Criollo Haitiano hablo de “ustedes”, perfectamente podría estar hablando de “nosotros”.

Noumenm es también el nombre de nuestro proyecto, una apuesta en donde el nosotros y el ustedes se difumina, se mezcla, y crea algo diferente. Desde hace un año estamos trabajando con la comunidad de Grand Boukan para potenciar procesos de desarrollo gestionados por líderes locales. Alguna de las cosas que hemos realizado:

  • El proyecto Noumenm participó en la I Incubadora de Ideas de la Fundación Melton, en el contexto de su “Global Citizenship Celebration” en Alemania. Esta idea fue elegida por los participantes y expertos del evento por sobre otros proyectos internacionales, recibiendo apoyo tanto en recursos para la implementación programática, como en la supervisión, diseño y reformulación del proyecto.
  • Se gestionaron los recursos para la compra del terreno de la escuela comunitaria de Grand Boukan, permitiendo así llegar a un primer paso hacia la sostenibilidad del proyecto.
  • Respondiendo a un brote de cólera, se habilitó un Punto de Rehidratación Oral y se capacitó a voluntarios comunitarios, quienes atendieron a no sólo gente de la comunidad, sino también de otras comunidades cercanas, controlando así la emergencia y reduciendo las fatalidades.

Además de la Fundación Melton, Noumenm cuenta con el apoyo de la Fundación América Solidaria, quienes han apoyado tanto en apoyar la logística de ciertas actividades, como también co-facilitado uno de nuestros trabajos, específicamente el Punto de Rehidratación Oral.

¿Qué necesitamos?

Necesitamos pagar a los docentes que día a día acompañan a los estudiantes de Grand Boukan, y que han postergado su salario para el funcionamiento de la escuela. También necesitamos contar con los insumos mínimos para continuar impartiendo las clases. En los adjuntos puedes encontrar un presupuesto detallado.

¿Para qué?

Asegurar el funcionamiento de este año escolar nos permite así centrar todos los esfuerzos de la comunidad en la búsqueda de alternativas sostenibles para el próximo año escolar, integrando esfuerzos de la comunidad, las instancias gubernamentales y/o los apoyos de otras organizaciones.

¿Por qué?

Porque el primer paso se ha dado: La comunidad cuenta con un espacio físico para la escuela, ahora todos juntos podemos contribuir para este espacio continúe alimentándose de vida e historias gracias a la vitalidad de los estudiantes; porque seguir soñando entre todos en oportunidades educativas para niños, niñas, adolescentes y jóvenes nos permitirá construir nuevas opciones para el presente y el futuro; y porque no nos falla la esperanza y tenemos la capacidad de hacer más.

¿Qué buscamos?

El apoyo de personas como tú, que desde la distancia o en la cercanía quieran jugársela y apostar por la educación, el pueblo haitiano y la comunidad de Grand Boukan.

¿Cómo puedes apoyar?

  • Nou fínanse nou: donando por medio electrónico a la campaña. Todo el dinero recolectado irá directamente a pagar los gastos de funcionamiento de la escuela.
  • Nou patajè istwa nou: Compartiendo esta iniciativa entre tus contactos para que entre todas y todos logremos que nuevas personas puedan sumarse, conocer a la comunidad y compartir nuestro sueño.
  • Nou ba nou konesans nou: Compartiendo con tu conocimiento y experiencia, apóyanos con ideas y estrategias que puedan facilitar la sostenibilidad de la Escuela Comunitaria de Bassin Thomas.
  • Nou konnèn yon moun k ap edè nou: Facilitando posibles contactos que nos puedan permitir acercarnos a la meta planteada y a que la comunidad continúe la construcción de la escuela de Gran Boukan.

Y si en dos meses no logramos la meta… ¿Qué pasaría?

Noumenm tèt ansanm (nosotros/vosotros juntando esfuerzos) alcanzaremos la meta! Pero si algo ocurriera… Todos los fondos que hayan sido recaudados serán utilizados para cubrir las necesidades básicas requeridas para el funcionamiento del Escuela, empezando por los insumos requeridos para poder seguir impartiendo las clases en Grand Boukan.

Durante y después de la campaña ¿Qué pasará?

Desde ahora la comunidad de Gran Boukan y Noumenm estamos diseñando alternativas de mediano y largo plazo que permitan que la escuela por sí misma sea sostenible para la implementación del próximo año escolar.

Te invitamos a ser parte de esta historia que construimos al andar. Recuerda revisar a la derecha los ti kadò (pequeños obsequios) que hemos preparado para quienes nos ayuden.

English

Two years ago the Grand Boukan community organized itself to make a gift for its children: the Bassin Thomas Community School began operating. And from this day on, this small community project which started with less than 30 children has quadrupled its enrollment and has become one of the few opportunities to get elementary education in the area.

But with these new achievements new challenges emerged as well, like achieving long-term sustainability. The school faces a lack of funding and,the community all of us, Noumenm and yourselves, have to do something for the boys and girls in Grand Boukan. And as the Haitian people say, “pitì pitì”, little by little we will move forward to rise over the challenges.

Meet the idea.

“We want to help”… But, what it is to help someone? How do you really help someone? We can provide education, food, health and entertainment, but is that enough? The Igbo people have a saying: “Ora na-azu nwa”, it takes a village to raise a child. With this project, we make a commitment to believe in this ‘village’ and its community.

Noumenm is a Haitian Creole word that means “ourselves” and “yourselves” at the same time. The expression doesn’t make any difference in itself, but it is the context that provides with the particular meaning. So, when we talk about “you” in Haitian Creole, we might as well be talking about “us”.

Noumenm is also the name of our project, a gamble in which the “us” and “you” gets blurry, they mix and create something different. For over a year we’ve been working with the Grand Boukan community to strengthen development processes managed by local leaders. Some of the things we did during 2011:

  • The project participated in the 1st Melton Foundation Global Citizenship Celebration / Idea Incubator, in Jena, Germany. Noumenm was chosen by the participants and field experts over all other presented international projects, winning early funding for project implementation and support in the design and idea re-developing.
  • We secured the funding needed to purchase the land where the Bassin Thomas community school is located, this being the first real step to achieve sustainability.
  • In response to a cholera outbreak in the community, we established an Oral Rehydration Point, providing emergency supplies and, more importantly, training community volunteers who provided care not only to people of Grand Boukan, but also of nearby communities, reducing fatalities and helping to control the emergency.

Other than The Melton Foundation, Noumenm also has the support of America Solidaria Foundation in the implementation of some activities and which even co-managed the project of the Oral Rehydration Point.

What do we need?

We need to pay the teachers who day by day accompany the kids of the community, and have postponed their salary in order for the school to keep running. We also need to buy the basic school supplies for the year. You can find a detailed budget in the attached documents.

What for?

Securing the funding for this school year allows us to focus the community efforts in looking for sustainable solutions for the next one, utilizing grassroots initiatives and involving the government and other organizations.

Why?

Because the first step has been already made: the community has the physical space for the school and now we all can contribute for this place to continue be nourished with the joy and stories of its students; because we can make come true the dream of having an education for boys and girls of the Grand Boukan community; and because we are not short in hope nor in our capacity of achieving more.

What are we looking for?

We are searching for the support of people like you who, from the distance or closeness, want to bet in supporting the education, the people of Haiti and the Grand Boukan community.

How can you help us?

  • Nou fínanse nou: You can support us by donating to this fundraising. All the collected money will go straight to pay for the school operation.
  • Nou patajè istwa nou: You could share this initiative with your family, friends and contacts, so more people get to know about the Grand Boukan community and share our dream.
  • Nou ba nou konesans nou: You can support us by sharing with us your experience and knowledge, providing us with new ideas and strategies to achieve the sustainability of the Bassin Thomas community school.
  • Nou konnèn yon moun ki kapab edè nou: By putting us in contact with someone who can help us get close to our goal and help the community continue to build and improve it school.

What if we don’t achieve our goal?

We are going to make it, noumenm, tèt ansanm! (ourselves/yourselves, putting our heads together). If by any chance we don’t achieve the 100% of our goal, all the collected money will go to the school nonetheless, we will prioritize what’s more urgent while we look for new funding opportunities.

What’s going to happen during and after the fundraising?

Noumenm and the Grand Boukan community have already started to look for opportunities that in the long run will allow the school to be sustainable and finance the next school year.

We invite you to be part of this story that we are building by walking. Remember to check the ti kadò (“Little gifts”) we will share with those who support us. 

Français

Il ya deux ans, la communauté de Grand Boukan s’est organisée pour faire un cadeau à ses enfants: l’école communautaire de Bassin Thomas a ouvert ses portes. Depuis, ce petit projet, qui a commencé avec moins de 30 enfants, a quadruplé ses effectifs et est devenu la seule option dans la zone pour obtenir une éducation de base.

Mais avec ces évolutions, de nouveaux défis sont apparus, notamment rendre le fonctionnement de l’école durable. L’école est confrontée à un manque de fonds et nous, la communauté, l’association Noumen et VOUS, pouvons agir pour les filles et garçons de Grand Boukan. Comme dit le peuple d'Haïti, «piti piti», petit à petit, nous avançons pour surmonter ces défis.

L’idée

«Nous voulons aider» ... mais qu'est-ce que venir en aide à quelqu'un ? Comment réellement aider quelqu'un ? Nous pouvons fournir l’éducation, l'alimentation, la santé et le divertissement mais est-ce suffisant ? La nation africaine Igbo a un dicton: «Ora na-azu nwa», il faut tout un village pour élever un enfant. Avec ce projet, nous nous engageons à croire dans le rôle de ce village et de cette communauté.

Noumenm est un mot créole haïtien qui signifie à la fois «nous» et «vous». Seul le contexte permet de donner un sens à ce mot, qui sans cela vaut de manière indifférenciée pour « nous » et « vous ». Donc, quand on dit «vous» en créole haïtien, on pourrait tout aussi bien parler de «nous».

Noumenm est aussi le nom de notre projet, un pari où la distinction entre « nous »  et « vous » devient flou, où « vous » et « nous » se confondent pour créer quelques chose de différent. Depuis un an, Noumenm travaille avec la communauté de Grand Boukan pour renforcer les processus de développement gérés par les leaders communautaires. Voici quelques unes des choses qui ont été faites jusqu’à présent:

  • Le projet Noumenm a participé au programme d’incubateur d’idées de la première «Global Citizenship Celebration» de la Fondation Melton, en Août 2012 en Allemagne. Il a été sélectionné, parmi tous les autres projets internationaux présentés, par les participants et les experts de l'événement, remportant ainsi un financement de départ pour la mise en œuvre du projet mais aussi de l’aide pour la conception du projet.
  • Noumenm a obtenu le financement nécessaire à l’achat du terrain sur lequel l’école est construite, faisant ainsi un premier pas vers la durabilité.
  • Pour faire face à une épidémie de choléra dans la communauté, nous avons mis sur pied un point de réhydratation orale, fournissant un service d’urgence et, plus important, formant des bénévoles de la communauté qui ont pu apporter des soins aux personnes de Grand Boukan mais aussi dans les communautés voisines, réduisant ainsi les décès et les cas d’urgence.

Outre la Fondation Melton, Noumenm est également soutenu par la fondation America Solidaria, notamment sur le plan logistique de certaines activités et a co-géré la mise en place du point de réhydratation orale.

De quoi avons-nous besoin?

Nous devons payer les enseignants qui accompagnent chaque jour les élèves de Grand Boukan et qui ont renoncé à leurs salaires pour que l’école puisse continuer de fonctionner. Nous avons également besoin d’acheter les fournitures de base pour l’année. Pour cela, il nous faut collecter 5000$ (vous trouverez un budget détaillé dans les documents attachés). Mais au delà de l’argent, ce que nous désirons vraiment c’est VOUS intéresser à notre démarche, c’est également que vous vous sentiez concerner et que vous vous impliquiez en la partageant autour de vous et en diffusant notre rêve à travers la planète.

Dans quel but ?

Assurer le financement de cette année scolaire nous permettrait de concentrer les efforts de la communauté dans la recherche de solutions durables pour la prochaine année scolaire, de mettre en pratique des initiatives populaires et d’essayer d’impliquer  le gouvernement ainsi que d’autres organisations.

Pourquoi?

Parce que la première pierre a été posée : la communauté dispose d'un espace physique pour l'école, nous pouvons maintenant tous contribuer à nourrir cet espace de joie et  d’histoires de ses élèves ; parce que nous pouvons réaliser ce rêve d’offrir une éducation aux filles et garçons de la communauté de Grand Boukan ; et parce que nous sommes plein d’espoir et croyons en notre capacité d’aller toujours plus loin.

Que recherchons-nous ?

Le soutien de gens comme vous, qui de près ou de loin veulent croire en l'éducation, dans le peuple haïtien et dans la communauté de Grand Boukan.

Comment pouvez-vous nous soutenir?

  • Nou finansye nou: Vous pouvez nous soutenir en faisant un don financier. Tous les fonds amassés au cours de cette campagne serviront à payer directement les frais de fonctionnement de l'école.
  • Nou pataje istwa nou: Vous pouvez partager cette initiative avec vos familles, amis et autres contacts afin que toujours plus de personnes connaissent la communauté de Grand Boukan et en viennent à partager notre rêve.
  • Nou ba nou konesans nou: Vous pouvez nous soutenir en partageant vos connaissances et expérience, nous donner de nouvelles idées et stratégies permettant de rendre l’école communautaire durable.
  • Nou konnen yon moun ki kapab ede nou: Vous pouvez également nous mettre en contact avec quelqu’un qui peut nous aider à nous rapprocher de notre objectif et aider la communauté à améliorer son école.

Et si nous n’atteignons pas notre objectif ? 

Nous allons nous mettre Noumenm tet ansanm (nous / vous allons unir nos efforts) pour atteindre l'objectif. Si malheureusement nous n’y arrivons pas à 100%, tout l’argent récolté ira à l’école malgré tout et nous prioriserons les dépenses nécessaires, pendant que nous chercherons de nouvelles opportunités de financement.

Que se passe t-il pendant et après la campagne ?

Noumenm et la communauté de Grand Boukan avons déjà commencé à cherches des solutions à moyen et à long terme pour permettre à l'école d’être viable pour la mise en œuvre et financer la prochaine année scolaire.

Nous vous invitons à faire partie de cette histoire que nous construisons comme vous allez. N'oubliez pas regarder les ti kadò (petits cadeaux), que nous partagerons avec les personnes qui pourront nous aider.
story_txt:
Español: a continuacion.
English: Please see below.
Français: Voir ci-dessous.
Español
Hace dos años la comunidad de Grand Boukan se organizó para hacer un regalo a sus niños y niñas: comenzó a funcionar la Escuela Comunitaria de Bassin Thomas.  Desde ese entonces, este pequeño proyecto que comenzó con menos de 30 niños ha cuadriplicado su matrícula y se ha convertido en la única posibilidad en la zona de obtener una educación básica.
Pero con los nuevos logros, nuevos retos también aparecen, entre éstos lograr la sostenibilidad a largo plazo del espacio. Nos enfrentamos a una falta de fondos y tenemos que hacer algo por los niños y las niñas de Grand Boukan. Y como dice el pueblo haitiano, “pitì pitì”, poco a poco, paso a paso nos dirigimos hacia esa meta.
Conoce la idea.
“Queremos ayudar”… pero ¿qué significa ayudar a alguien? ¿Cómo se ayuda a alguien? Podemos dar educación, comida, salud y diversión, pero ¿es eso suficiente? La nación africana Igbo tiene un dicho: “Ora na-azu nwa”, se necesita una aldea para criar un niño. Desde este proyecto, creemos en el rol de la aldea y la comunidad.
Noumenm es una palabra en Criollo Haitiano que significa a la vez “nosotros” y “vosotros”. Dentro de la expresión no hay diferencia alguna, sino que es el contexto el que otorga un significado sobre el otro. Así, cuando en Criollo Haitiano hablo de “ustedes”, perfectamente podría estar hablando de “nosotros”.
Noumenm es también el nombre de nuestro proyecto, una apuesta en donde el nosotros y el ustedes se difumina, se mezcla, y crea algo diferente. Desde hace un año estamos trabajando con la comunidad de Grand Boukan para potenciar procesos de desarrollo gestionados por líderes locales. Alguna de las cosas que hemos realizado:

El proyecto Noumenm participó en la I Incubadora de Ideas de la Fundación Melton, en el contexto de su “Global Citizenship Celebration” en Alemania. Esta idea fue elegida por los participantes y expertos del evento por sobre otros proyectos internacionales, recibiendo apoyo tanto en recursos para la implementación programática, como en la supervisión, diseño y reformulación del proyecto.
Se gestionaron los recursos para la compra del terreno de la escuela comunitaria de Grand Boukan, permitiendo así llegar a un primer paso hacia la sostenibilidad del proyecto.
Respondiendo a un brote de cólera, se habilitó un Punto de Rehidratación Oral y se capacitó a voluntarios comunitarios, quienes atendieron a no sólo gente de la comunidad, sino también de otras comunidades cercanas, controlando así la emergencia y reduciendo las fatalidades.
Además de la Fundación Melton, Noumenm cuenta con el apoyo de la Fundación América Solidaria, quienes han apoyado tanto en apoyar la logística de ciertas actividades, como también co-facilitado uno de nuestros trabajos, específicamente el Punto de Rehidratación Oral.
¿Qué necesitamos?
Necesitamos pagar a los docentes que día a día acompañan a los estudiantes de Grand Boukan, y que han postergado su salario para el funcionamiento de la escuela. También necesitamos contar con los insumos mínimos para continuar impartiendo las clases. En los adjuntos puedes encontrar un presupuesto detallado.
¿Para qué?
Asegurar el funcionamiento de este año escolar nos permite así centrar todos los esfuerzos de la comunidad en la búsqueda de alternativas sostenibles para el próximo año escolar, integrando esfuerzos de la comunidad, las instancias gubernamentales y/o los apoyos de otras organizaciones.
¿Por qué?
Porque el primer paso se ha dado: La comunidad cuenta con un espacio físico para la escuela, ahora todos juntos podemos contribuir para este espacio continúe alimentándose de vida e historias gracias a la vitalidad de los estudiantes; porque seguir soñando entre todos en oportunidades educativas para niños, niñas, adolescentes y jóvenes nos permitirá construir nuevas opciones para el presente y el futuro; y porque no nos falla la esperanza y tenemos la capacidad de hacer más.
¿Qué buscamos?
El apoyo de personas como tú, que desde la distancia o en la cercanía quieran jugársela y apostar por la educación, el pueblo haitiano y la comunidad de Grand Boukan.
¿Cómo puedes apoyar?


Nou fínanse nou: donando por medio electrónico a la campaña. Todo el dinero recolectado irá directamente a pagar los gastos de funcionamiento de la escuela.

Nou patajè istwa nou: Compartiendo esta iniciativa entre tus contactos para que entre todas y todos logremos que nuevas personas puedan sumarse, conocer a la comunidad y compartir nuestro sueño.

Nou ba nou konesans nou: Compartiendo con tu conocimiento y experiencia, apóyanos con ideas y estrategias que puedan facilitar la sostenibilidad de la Escuela Comunitaria de Bassin Thomas.

Nou konnèn yon moun k ap edè nou: Facilitando posibles contactos que nos puedan permitir acercarnos a la meta planteada y a que la comunidad continúe la construcción de la escuela de Gran Boukan.
Y si en dos meses no logramos la meta… ¿Qué pasaría?
Noumenm tèt ansanm (nosotros/vosotros juntando esfuerzos) alcanzaremos la meta! Pero si algo ocurriera… Todos los fondos que hayan sido recaudados serán utilizados para cubrir las necesidades básicas requeridas para el funcionamiento del Escuela, empezando por los insumos requeridos para poder seguir impartiendo las clases en Grand Boukan.
Durante y después de la campaña ¿Qué pasará?
Desde ahora la comunidad de Gran Boukan y Noumenm estamos diseñando alternativas de mediano y largo plazo que permitan que la escuela por sí misma sea sostenible para la implementación del próximo año escolar.
Te invitamos a ser parte de esta historia que construimos al andar. Recuerda revisar a la derecha los ti kadò (pequeños obsequios) que hemos preparado para quienes nos ayuden.
English
Two years ago the Grand Boukan community organized itself to make a gift for its children: the Bassin Thomas Community School began operating. And from this day on, this small community project which started with less than 30 children has quadrupled its enrollment and has become one of the few opportunities to get elementary education in the area.
But with these new achievements new challenges emerged as well, like achieving long-term sustainability. The school faces a lack of funding and,the community all of us, Noumenm and yourselves, have to do something for the boys and girls in Grand Boukan. And as the Haitian people say, “pitì pitì”, little by little we will move forward to rise over the challenges.
Meet the idea.
“We want to help”… But, what it is to help someone? How do you really help someone? We can provide education, food, health and entertainment, but is that enough? The Igbo people have a saying: “Ora na-azu nwa”, it takes a village to raise a child. With this project, we make a commitment to believe in this ‘village’ and its community.
Noumenm is a Haitian Creole word that means “ourselves” and “yourselves” at the same time. The expression doesn’t make any difference in itself, but it is the context that provides with the particular meaning. So, when we talk about “you” in Haitian Creole, we might as well be talking about “us”.
Noumenm is also the name of our project, a gamble in which the “us” and “you” gets blurry, they mix and create something different. For over a year we’ve been working with the Grand Boukan community to strengthen development processes managed by local leaders. Some of the things we did during 2011:

The project participated in the 1st Melton Foundation Global Citizenship Celebration / Idea Incubator, in Jena, Germany. Noumenm was chosen by the participants and field experts over all other presented international projects, winning early funding for project implementation and support in the design and idea re-developing.
We secured the funding needed to purchase the land where the Bassin Thomas community school is located, this being the first real step to achieve sustainability.
In response to a cholera outbreak in the community, we established an Oral Rehydration Point, providing emergency supplies and, more importantly, training community volunteers who provided care not only to people of Grand Boukan, but also of nearby communities, reducing fatalities and helping to control the emergency.
Other than The Melton Foundation, Noumenm also has the support of America Solidaria Foundation in the implementation of some activities and which even co-managed the project of the Oral Rehydration Point.
What do we need?
We need to pay the teachers who day by day accompany the kids of the community, and have postponed their salary in order for the school to keep running. We also need to buy the basic school supplies for the year. You can find a detailed budget in the attached documents.
What for?
Securing the funding for this school year allows us to focus the community efforts in looking for sustainable solutions for the next one, utilizing grassroots initiatives and involving the government and other organizations.
Why?
Because the first step has been already made: the community has the physical space for the school and now we all can contribute for this place to continue be nourished with the joy and stories of its students; because we can make come true the dream of having an education for boys and girls of the Grand Boukan community; and because we are not short in hope nor in our capacity of achieving more.
What are we looking for?
We are searching for the support of people like you who, from the distance or closeness, want to bet in supporting the education, the people of Haiti and the Grand Boukan community.
How can you help us?


Nou fínanse nou: You can support us by donating to this fundraising. All the collected money will go straight to pay for the school operation.

Nou patajè istwa nou: You could share this initiative with your family, friends and contacts, so more people get to know about the Grand Boukan community and share our dream.

Nou ba nou konesans nou: You can support us by sharing with us your experience and knowledge, providing us with new ideas and strategies to achieve the sustainability of the Bassin Thomas community school.

Nou konnèn yon moun ki kapab edè nou: By putting us in contact with someone who can help us get close to our goal and help the community continue to build and improve it school.
What if we don’t achieve our goal?
We are going to make it, noumenm, tèt ansanm! (ourselves/yourselves, putting our heads together). If by any chance we don’t achieve the 100% of our goal, all the collected money will go to the school nonetheless, we will prioritize what’s more urgent while we look for new funding opportunities.
What’s going to happen during and after the fundraising?
Noumenm and the Grand Boukan community have already started to look for opportunities that in the long run will allow the school to be sustainable and finance the next school year.
We invite you to be part of this story that we are building by walking. Remember to check the ti kadò (“Little gifts”) we will share with those who support us. 
Français
Il ya deux ans, la communauté de Grand Boukan s’est organisée pour faire un cadeau à ses enfants: l’école communautaire de Bassin Thomas a ouvert ses portes. Depuis, ce petit projet, qui a commencé avec moins de 30 enfants, a quadruplé ses effectifs et est devenu la seule option dans la zone pour obtenir une éducation de base.
Mais avec ces évolutions, de nouveaux défis sont apparus, notamment rendre le fonctionnement de l’école durable. L’école est confrontée à un manque de fonds et nous, la communauté, l’association Noumen et VOUS, pouvons agir pour les filles et garçons de Grand Boukan. Comme dit le peuple d'Haïti, «piti piti», petit à petit, nous avançons pour surmonter ces défis.
L’idée
«Nous voulons aider» ... mais qu'est-ce que venir en aide à quelqu'un ? Comment réellement aider quelqu'un ? Nous pouvons fournir l’éducation, l'alimentation, la santé et le divertissement mais est-ce suffisant ? La nation africaine Igbo a un dicton: «Ora na-azu nwa», il faut tout un village pour élever un enfant. Avec ce projet, nous nous engageons à croire dans le rôle de ce village et de cette communauté.
Noumenm est un mot créole haïtien qui signifie à la fois «nous» et «vous». Seul le contexte permet de donner un sens à ce mot, qui sans cela vaut de manière indifférenciée pour « nous » et « vous ». Donc, quand on dit «vous» en créole haïtien, on pourrait tout aussi bien parler de «nous».
Noumenm est aussi le nom de notre projet, un pari où la distinction entre « nous »  et « vous » devient flou, où « vous » et « nous » se confondent pour créer quelques chose de différent. Depuis un an, Noumenm travaille avec la communauté de Grand Boukan pour renforcer les processus de développement gérés par les leaders communautaires. Voici quelques unes des choses qui ont été faites jusqu’à présent:

Le projet Noumenm a participé au programme d’incubateur d’idées de la première «Global Citizenship Celebration» de la Fondation Melton, en Août 2012 en Allemagne. Il a été sélectionné, parmi tous les autres projets internationaux présentés, par les participants et les experts de l'événement, remportant ainsi un financement de départ pour la mise en œuvre du projet mais aussi de l’aide pour la conception du projet.
Noumenm a obtenu le financement nécessaire à l’achat du terrain sur lequel l’école est construite, faisant ainsi un premier pas vers la durabilité.
Pour faire face à une épidémie de choléra dans la communauté, nous avons mis sur pied un point de réhydratation orale, fournissant un service d’urgence et, plus important, formant des bénévoles de la communauté qui ont pu apporter des soins aux personnes de Grand Boukan mais aussi dans les communautés voisines, réduisant ainsi les décès et les cas d’urgence.
Outre la Fondation Melton, Noumenm est également soutenu par la fondation America Solidaria, notamment sur le plan logistique de certaines activités et a co-géré la mise en place du point de réhydratation orale.
De quoi avons-nous besoin?
Nous devons payer les enseignants qui accompagnent chaque jour les élèves de Grand Boukan et qui ont renoncé à leurs salaires pour que l’école puisse continuer de fonctionner. Nous avons également besoin d’acheter les fournitures de base pour l’année. Pour cela, il nous faut collecter 5000$ (vous trouverez un budget détaillé dans les documents attachés). Mais au delà de l’argent, ce que nous désirons vraiment c’est VOUS intéresser à notre démarche, c’est également que vous vous sentiez concerner et que vous vous impliquiez en la partageant autour de vous et en diffusant notre rêve à travers la planète.
Dans quel but ?
Assurer le financement de cette année scolaire nous permettrait de concentrer les efforts de la communauté dans la recherche de solutions durables pour la prochaine année scolaire, de mettre en pratique des initiatives populaires et d’essayer d’impliquer  le gouvernement ainsi que d’autres organisations.
Pourquoi?
Parce que la première pierre a été posée : la communauté dispose d'un espace physique pour l'école, nous pouvons maintenant tous contribuer à nourrir cet espace de joie et  d’histoires de ses élèves ; parce que nous pouvons réaliser ce rêve d’offrir une éducation aux filles et garçons de la communauté de Grand Boukan ; et parce que nous sommes plein d’espoir et croyons en notre capacité d’aller toujours plus loin.
Que recherchons-nous ?
Le soutien de gens comme vous, qui de près ou de loin veulent croire en l'éducation, dans le peuple haïtien et dans la communauté de Grand Boukan.
Comment pouvez-vous nous soutenir?


Nou finansye nou: Vous pouvez nous soutenir en faisant un don financier. Tous les fonds amassés au cours de cette campagne serviront à payer directement les frais de fonctionnement de l'école.

Nou pataje istwa nou: Vous pouvez partager cette initiative avec vos familles, amis et autres contacts afin que toujours plus de personnes connaissent la communauté de Grand Boukan et en viennent à partager notre rêve.

Nou ba nou konesans nou: Vous pouvez nous soutenir en partageant vos connaissances et expérience, nous donner de nouvelles idées et stratégies permettant de rendre l’école communautaire durable.

Nou konnen yon moun ki kapab ede nou: Vous pouvez également nous mettre en contact avec quelqu’un qui peut nous aider à nous rapprocher de notre objectif et aider la communauté à améliorer son école.
Et si nous n’atteignons pas notre objectif ? 
Nous allons nous mettre Noumenm tet ansanm (nous / vous allons unir nos efforts) pour atteindre l'objectif. Si malheureusement nous n’y arrivons pas à 100%, tout l’argent récolté ira à l’école malgré tout et nous prioriserons les dépenses nécessaires, pendant que nous chercherons de nouvelles opportunités de financement.
Que se passe t-il pendant et après la campagne ?
Noumenm et la communauté de Grand Boukan avons déjà commencé à cherches des solutions à moyen et à long terme pour permettre à l'école d’être viable pour la mise en œuvre et financer la prochaine année scolaire.
Nous vous invitons à faire partie de cette histoire que nous construisons comme vous allez. N'oubliez pas regarder les ti kadò (petits cadeaux), que nous partagerons avec les personnes qui pourront nous aider.

story:
An Empowering Summary

Hello, everyone! My name is Mattie Wyndham, and I'm a senior in high school in coastal South Carolina. As a little girl, I would swing on the hammock with my dad, and I'd ask him, “Daddy, where do you want to go? We can go anywhere.” And we would. I would pluck the magic strings, and we would fly off to enchanting places as far as our imaginations could reach. Now, I have the opportunity to really pluck the strings. I have been invited to participate in the global gap year program Thinking Beyond Borders next year. Along with 18 other students and three program leaders, I will journey to six different countries to study global development issues. My year will consist of living with host families, fieldwork with local experts, academic study, language learning, and independent travel opportunities. 

As a junior in high school, I launched my blog You Me We Empower which focuses on human rights and the pursuit of happiness; it also doubles as my non-profit organization of the same name's website. Over the past two years, I have dedicated my time to critical global issues, particularly women's rights and education equality; I've even coined myself an "empowerment junkie." My passion for global change is permanent, and I plan on majoring in International Relations and English in college so I can become an International Journalist. This global gap year with TBB is exactly the kind of foundation I need to further my education and break outside the classroom walls. Thank you for your support! It means the world to me.

Financial Empowerment

Total Program Cost: $30,000

I know it's a lot, and it is a tad overwhelming. BUT, Thinking Beyond Borders has generously agreed that for every $1 I raise, they'll raise $2!! 

This means that I just need to raise $10,000 by July 1st! (Airfare and travel expenses is around $5,000, so I need a rough total of $15,000). But with your help, I know it's possible! 

My fundraising plan is extensive. I intend to host multiple fundraisers, launch a letter writing campaign, apply for scholarships and grants, and reach out to those who have inspired me along the way. 

HOWEVER, if for some reason I cannot raise the money, while I will be dreadfully disappointed, the money will NOT go to waste! TBB will use it for furthering their scholarship program to help students like me realize their full potential and obtain a true purpose in life!

Break It Down Now: The Empowering Details

  • Orientation--Ecuador: 2 Weeks
     We start the trip with a two week orientation in Ecuador where we get to know each other, learn about travel etiquette, complete health and safety training, and set goals for the adventurous year to come!

  • Unit 1--Ecuador: Natural Resources & the Environment--5 Weeks
     The environment and its resources are threatened, and in this unit we will learn about  how production and consumption systems affect the environment, as well as industry, agriculture, and cultural conflicts. We will even plant trees to help local farmers.

  • Enrichment--Peru: Trek to Machu Pichu--1 Week
     It's adventure time! During this "enrichment week" we will immerse ourselves even further into the culture in order to gain a new perspective. Plus, I will be breaking out of my comfort zone (a personal favorite of mine) by hiking the legendary Machu Pichu! During this four-day trek, we will learn about the Incan Empire and all its grand mysteries.

  • Unit 2--Thailand: Sustainable Agriculture--6 Weeks
     In this second unit we will center our discussions around sustainable agriculture--an issue which often gets overlooked, in my opinion. The world's populations has tripled in the past 60 years, which has brought on great complications in the agriculture world. We will investigate how farmers, government, and businesses cooperate to balance demand for food with the ecosystem in Northern Thailand. By living in rural Thailand, we will immerse ourselves in the very culture we're learning about.

  • Enrichment--Cambodia: Angkor Wat--1 Week
     Hello, Cambodia! During this enrichment week we will travel to Angkor Wat to explore the legendary Khmer temples and tour powerful museums in Phnom Penh. 

  • Unit 3--India: Education & Economic Growth--5 Weeks 
     I am particularly excited for this unit because of my love for education equality. We will explore how education can empower individuals and communities to treat disease, produce goods, and support effective government. We'll even work in education centers for women and children in some of the poorest parts of Jaipur. 

  • Enrichment--India: Udaipur & the Pushkar Camel Trek--1 Week
     Talk about adventure! We will venture to Udaipur and Pushkar on India’s famous railroads and explore Udaipur’s waterways and architecture. We’ll get to visit the Hindu pilgrimage city of Pushkar and camp on a camel trek! 

  • Unit 4--South Africa: Public Health & the AIDS Epidemic--5 Weeks
     I can't even imagine the kind of impact this unit will have on me--on all of my group. HIV/AIDS is the most critical global health crisis, and while we in America may have a medical handle on it, most of the world does not. In fact, death tolls are in the millions in sub-Saharan Africa and some communities face the threat of collapse. During this five week experience we will work with home-based caregivers, a nursing center, and clinics.

  • Enrichment--South Africa: ADDO Safari--1 Week
     Man, oh man. I don't think it's possible to express my excitement for this one! Elephants, lions, giraffes! I can't wait to cross this one off my bucket list. 

  • Culmination--Washington, DC: 3 Weeks
     We will conclude our whirlwind experience back in the nation's capital. We’ll explore the relationship between the US and the rest of the world; we'll also meet representatives from the World Bank, Congress, and NGOs to discuss international development. We'll reflect and bring together our learning and experiences into powerful conclusions by creating a "Presentation of Learning" to raise awareness about critical global issues. Finally, we will attend the TBB gap year programs graduation and celebrate our accomplishments from the past nine months.

Next comes college and a lifetime of world changing and empowerment!
     

A Motley Crew of Empowering Ways to Help

Every dollar helps! Whether it's $10 or $1,000, it is dearly appreciated.

I have been fundraising for various causes since middle school, and I know that sometimes donations simply aren't an option--and that's perfectly fine! If you can't financially donate, I would be incredibly grateful if you could just share this campaign in any way you can. Whether it be via social media, e-mail, word-of-mouth, etc., anything helps! 

If you have any tips, questions, comments, or ideas, please please reach out. 

Thank you so much for watching the video and learning about this incredible experience. Your support matters more than you know.

We'll even work in education centers for women and children in some of the poorest parts of Jaipur. 

Enrichment--India: Udaipur & the Pushkar Camel Trek--1 Week     Talk about adventure! We will venture to Udaipur and Pushkar on India’s famous railroads and explore Udaipur’s waterways and architecture. We’ll get to visit the Hindu pilgrimage city of Pushkar and camp on a camel trek! 


Unit 4--South Africa: Public Health & the AIDS Epidemic--5 Weeks     I can't even imagine the kind of impact this unit will have on me--on all of my group. HIV/AIDS is the most critical global health crisis, and while we in America may have a medical handle on it, most of the world does not. In fact, death tolls are in the millions in sub-Saharan Africa and some communities face the threat of collapse. During this five week experience we will work with home-based caregivers, a nursing center, and clinics.

Enrichment--South Africa: ADDO Safari--1 Week     Man, oh man. I don't think it's possible to express my excitement for this one! Elephants, lions, giraffes! I can't wait to cross this one off my bucket list. 

Culmination--Washington, DC: 3 Weeks     We will conclude our whirlwind experience back in the nation's capital. We’ll explore the relationship between the US and the rest of the world; we'll also meet representatives from the World Bank, Congress, and NGOs to discuss international development. We'll reflect and bring together our learning and experiences into powerful conclusions by creating a "Presentation of Learning" to raise awareness about critical global issues. Finally, we will attend the TBB gap year programs graduation and celebrate our accomplishments from the past nine months.

Next comes college and a lifetime of world changing and empowerment!     
A Motley Crew of Empowering Ways to Help
Every dollar helps! Whether it's $10 or $1,000, it is dearly appreciated.
I have been fundraising for various causes since middle school, and I know that sometimes donations simply aren't an option--and that's perfectly fine! If you can't financially donate, I would be incredibly grateful if you could just share this campaign in any way you can. Whether it be via social media, e-mail, word-of-mouth, etc., anything helps! 
If you have any tips, questions, comments, or ideas, please please reach out. 
Thank you so much for watching the video and learning about this incredible experience. Your support matters more than you know.

story:
Hi Guys, I am helping an old friend put up this campaign. Here's what she has to say. Please help. Thanks.

Short Summary

My name is Fome. I am a 24 year old female. I have big dreams and trying to get a good education but can't afford it. I am from one of the developing countries in Africa and I am taking an online course in computing and information system at the University of London External programs. I have exams in May and unfortunately it doesnt look like I can make the examination fee which is about 1120GDP or about $2062USD. It seems like a small amount but I dont have it, and If I dont do it this year, I will have to wait one more year and re-register the courses which will cost me money again.

I have put myself out there, because I have no other choice. If you are kind hearted and would like to help but are not sure if I am telling the truth, see the image in this campaign, you would find my student number. Feel free to call the school and ask if I am a student.I just need help.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

The entire program costs £ 5,025, please view the following page for fee structure. http://www.londoninternational.ac.uk/courses/undergraduate/goldsmiths/bsc-computing-information-systems-bsc-diploma-work-entry-route#fees

I am not asking for the full amount, I just need to finish my first year exams and figure out what to do later. All I need right now is that 1120GDP

I am hoping I will be able to get to my goals but the end of the month, If I don't I will pay whatever I possible can raise and take only those exams hoping that the university will let me do that. If they let me, I will take some of the first year courses next year worse case. But I really hope I am able to get all done this year.

The Impact

By helping me, you should be satisfied within yourself that you have just helped on person in the world who cannot afford good education get closer to her dream. If I am able to raise the money for my exam fees, this will mean a great deal to me. It might mean not losing one year of studies for me.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that some of you may be willing to help but not have money to help, that's find, but please if you know someone who can, kindly send this message to them using the indiegogo tools and other tools. Thanks.

story:
Hej!

Namaste!!

Destination Kathmandu!

I am Lena, born 21 years ago into a normal European family. Having grown up in northern Germany with best circumstances, I finished high school in Summer 2012. I could have gone directly to university, ensuring that I would get further educated and after that getting a job, working and earning money; Simply the normal case.

This idea did not quite satisfy me as I had the feeling that there could be a more meaningful way how to live my adult life. Looking at the world nowadays isn’t always just a pleasure; I think all of you could come up with something that is not as we wish it would be.

I could live on my life in Germany and have a good time and don’t worry about all that. Out of an inner impulse though, I feel obliged to look at the world as a whole and make my contribution to make it at least a tiny little better place.

  • WHAT I do now:

I became very enthusiastic when I first heard of the International Youth Initiative Program, YIP (http://yip.se):

The perfect combination between developing myself and also learning about how I as an individual can contribute towards a more positive future - And all this in my most favorite country Sweden.

I have already been living this dream for 3 months now.

Being a YIP-participant, a Yippie, I’ve been learning and living in a community with 20 wonderful people from all around the globe.

Already now I can say that this is an incredibly enriching and inspiring experiment and I can feel how positive this one-year program will influence my further life.

Besides weekly changing courses to get a deeper understanding of the global situation, a main part of YIP’s curriculum is also an international 5-week-internship in an already existing initiative. It gives us the chance to apply what we have learnt by contributing to a real project and also explore and learn from others who made their ideas reality.

Feeling a strong calling that I would like to go where I would be surrounded by a totally different culture, the actual activity during my internship doesn't have priority. In any case, I would learn something very valuable.

It felt never tempted to travel far away to spend my holidays there and observe foreign cultures from the outer. I rather want to dive into it and experience what it means to live in that place by really living there. I’ve never been outside of Europe, which might be also caused by my fear of flying.

  • WHERE am I going to spend my internship?

I’m going to spend my internship at Kevin Rohan Memorial Eco Foundation (KRMEF) in Nepal. The foundation is located in a small village close to Kathmandu. 


Together with two other Yippies, who you can see on the picture, I got really excited about KRMEF, as they have built up an amazing community that aims to become a fully self-sufficient village.

Several YIP participants who went to KRMEF made me feel more and more excited, when they reported from their adventurous time which was full of great personal learning.

KRMEF works with sustainable methods and applies a number of innovative and environmentally aligned practices such as natural building, biodynamic farming and local fuel production. Besides this, there’s also an education program for handicapped and leprosy villagers, a free clinic and a waldorf inspired school.

Meeting the needs of the village, I am convinced that KRMEF will also have a positive impact in other parts of Nepal, as they share their work and projects with similar villages.

Particularly the foundation’s values made me feel confident that this is definitely the right place to spend my internship!

respect - integrity - dignity - productivity - trust - inclusiveness

''We believe everyone has something to offer. Creativity and participation make the community thrive.''

I am looking forward to be working with my hands as I normally tend to be driven by my head than by my hands. I am ready to face any challenges that might come along through cultural differences and to enjoy the learning.


  • WHY do I need fundraise?

Being a participant of YIP, I don't have the opportunity to earn money besides the program. The main part of my budget is provided by YIP and is now already spent on the long travel between Stockholm and Kathmandu. 

The amount of money I still need will be spent on accommodation and food during the stay at KRMEF, which will benefit a lot from that. Additionally, I still need to finance local transport and my visa.

As I’m already leaving to Nepal on 7th January, I had no alternative choice but to finance this internship in advance by borrowing money and trusting in the success of this campaign!

I’ll be updating this campaign with pictures and reports during my time in Nepal.


If you feel inspired, please support me to reach my goal and share my campaign with other people.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and I hereby wish you a very fresh start into 2014!

All the way from my heart,

Lena

story:
UPDATE!


WE HAVE REACHED OUR GOAL! Although it may not look that way on the front page, we have reached our $10,000 goal for this campaign thanks to a very generous donor. however, this gift will after the closing date of July 28.

THANK YOU to all of our supporters and friends for passing the word along about this campaign! You have shown us that our community is strong and believes in what we’re doing. We’re changing lives every day, and it’s all thanks to you.

Let's Do This For The Kids

Summertime’s supposed to be a great time for kids--a time for learning, discovery, and the joy of being a kid. At Boys & Girls Clubs of Brea - Placentia - Yorba Linda, we believe that every child should have the opportunity to learn and have fun in a safe, nurturing environment. Education, character development and healthy activity for every kid are at the heart of everything we do.

With trips to the beach, park, baseball games, and other educational and entertaining activities, our summer day camp program gives working parents peace of mind and gives our campers a summer’s worth of great memories. Unfortunately, some of the kids who need our program the most are those whose families can’t afford it.

Win-Win Situations Rule

Our Club never turns away a kid who wants to be here--but we can only do that because our amazing community of supporters and partners make it possible. In 2013, 50% of our summer day campers needed some financial help to be able to attend.

We are proud to have qualified and well-trained staff, trips that offer both fun and learning, and activities that help kids develop their character and leadership skills. But we need your help to bring these life-changing programs to more kids who need us. Will you step up and help us serve more kids in need?

  • We've got some great perks including once-in-a-lifetime experience, tickets to our events, Club swag, and much more.

  • Our goal is to raise $10,000 for summer camp scholarships. Every dollar donated will go towards helping our Club kids to enjoy a great summer experience!


The Impact

It’s proven, kids who spend time at their Club are better off than those who don’t. According to a Harris Survey conducted by the national Boys & Girls Club:

  • 90% of kids who attended Club programs graduate from high school, compared to the national high school graduation rate of 85%.

  • 80% of Club alumni say that the Club gave them a positive attitude towards health and fitness.

  • 60% of Club alumni say the Club was the only place they could go after school.


Can't Give? No Problem. You Can Still Help.

If you are unable to donate right now, we certainly understand, but there are still ways you can help:

  • Please share our campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and other social networks--we want to be anywhere and everywhere you connect!

  • We invite you to volunteer with us and find out firsthand how our programs change kids’ lives. Please visit http://www.everykid.org/contribute.html for more information.

story:
Please help my student chefs open up a mock restaurant to serve 30 community members, teachers, and family members. Rachel Greenberger, a food blogger, came to the students' final presentation in 2011 and 2013 to serve as a celebrity judge.  Here are the two articles she wrote to describe the pop-up restaurants:

1.  http://www.examiner.com/sustainable-agriculture-in-boston/wowed-by-top-chefs-charlestown

2.  http://www.examiner.com/article/sixth-graders-launch-a-pop-up-restaurant-dorchester

This spring, across ten, 90-minute class sessions, my student chefs will learn how to prepare several dishes as a team and the nature of running a restaurant.  For their final presentation, students take on “front of the house” and “in the kitchen” roles to open up a pop-up restaurant.  To offset the total out-of-pocket cost, it would be helpful if you can make a donation.  I am a full-time student again so personal funds are limited but I would love to continue teaching this course.  Your help would be most appreciated!

Thank you in advance for taking the time to read and consider my request.  I hope that you are able to support my young chefs!

NOTE: If I meet my goal, I will end up with $744 dollars after all the processing fees.  If I fall short of the $800 goal, I will get $0 and the money you pledged would be returned to you.  Fingers crossed that I meet the goal!

story:
Helping Abaarso School Students Achieve Success in Western Schools

Who are we?

We are a group of students at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor who've been given the task to make a difference. We have set out to help raise funds to the only secondary school in Somaliland whose students are not only given the opportunity, but also expected to go to university abroad.

Why did we start this campaign?

Very few people from Somalia have been able to pursue any kind of higher education. This past year, Abaarso Tech successfully sent dozens of students to top tier universities and boarding schools across the United States and other countries. Although nothing binds them to return to Somalia, it is highly expected and encourage that these students return to Somalia once they have graduated to help bring new knowledge and ideas to make Somalia thrive once more.

It has been over two decades since the Republic of Somalia collapsed, and it has been the world’s only failed state for five consecutive years. As a result of the incessant turmoil, generations have grown up only knowing a conflict-ridden society. Not only has this had devastating impacts on Somalia’s people and its infrastructure, but its effects have also been felt internationally through the piracy, terrorism and refugees created by the conflict. We believe that the only way that this cycle will end is by helping to support those that are dedicated to make Somalia a safer and more educated nation, and providing them with the necessary financial support to achieve their goals.

What is Abaarso Tech?

The Abaarso Tech School strives to make this change a reality. By establishing an elite Somali educational institution to lead the development of future Somali leaders for decades to come, while setting a standard for others to follow. The acceptance criteria to attend the school is wholly based on merit and potential of the student, ensuring that those who go through the program have a real shot of succeeding abroad. The model the school has been extremely successful at sending students to  preparatory boarding schools, as well as elite colleges like Michigan State University, Oberlin College, and MIT.

Why do we need YOUR help?

Abaarso’s students often find themselves in a position where they have earned a full-scholarship to a wonderful foreign university or boarding school, however, the extra costs of flights, health insurance, and clothing, are not provided. In a state where the GDP per capita is estimated at under $1,000, these cost quickly become entirely preventative to studying abroad. As the school grows and becomes more successful, more hopeful students will face this issue.  Without access to funds for these essentials, it is impossible for students to reap the benefits of their hard work and dedication to change.

This campaign will offset the costs of the following expenses for students from Abaarso Tech who will be attending Western universities and boarding schools next year:

Transportation from Somaliland, Computers, Calculators, Books, Clothing, University Meal Plans, Phone, Book bag...

story:
My name is Rashell Aunchman and I am the founder and director of Taproots school of lively living.  I've been in gardening/farming for about 10 years now and teaching for about 6 of those years.  

Taproots strongly believes that people are empowered when they know how to be more self sufficient.  Our goal is to provide quality farm based educational opportunities to adults and children.  We run all of our programs on a  financial sliding scale to accommodate people in all economic walks of life.  Our hope is that people leave Taproots with inspiration to jump into their local food system, and respect for the cycle of life.  

Right now we are raising money to be able to keep our classes at a price that all can afford.  We need to money to be able to maintain the farm space. That means money will go towards things like fixing fencing for the animals, maintaining our greenhouse and adding shelving for more greenhouse space.  We need money for different farm and garden equipment like childrens tools, and materials to help build solar dehydrators. Money will also be going towards materials for our classes so that we can keep the class cost on a sliding scale!  

We need your help!  Your money equals other peoples opportunities...perhaps even your own :)  

Thank you!
story_txt: My name is Rashell Aunchman and I am the founder and director of Taproots school of lively living.  I've been in gardening/farming for about 10 years now and teaching for about 6 of those years.  Taproots strongly believes that people are empowered when they know how to be more self sufficient.  Our goal is to provide quality farm based educational opportunities to adults and children.  We run all of our programs on a  financial sliding scale to accommodate people in all economic walks of life.  Our hope is that people leave Taproots with inspiration to jump into their local food system, and respect for the cycle of life.  Right now we are raising money to be able to keep our classes at a price that all can afford.  We need to money to be able to maintain the farm space. That means money will go towards things like fixing fencing for the animals, maintaining our greenhouse and adding shelving for more greenhouse space.  We need money for different farm and garden equipment like childrens tools, and materials to help build solar dehydrators. Money will also be going towards materials for our classes so that we can keep the class cost on a sliding scale!  We need your help!  Your money equals other peoples opportunities...perhaps even your own :)  Thank you!

story:
The Enlightenment Arcade Project

is a non-profit collaborative organization trying to bring newly emerging technology to students who wouldn't normally have such an advantage — and we need your help!


       We are currently a collective of Game Developers, Artists, Writers and Teachers. Our goal is to bring new and emerging technology to inner-city and impoverished schools across America. We believe every child deserves the right to learn the already endangered subjects such as Music, Art and Technology. Most students might already be using these high tech instruments at home, but we want to work together with School Boards to bring that technology into the classroom.

       A large portion of the youth of America are missing out on amazing education due to lack of funding for the media and art subjects. By adding these newer technologies ( iPads, Kindles, Kano Kits, Micro PC's) to these schools we can ease back in to those wonderful courses that encourage creativity just by using these products alone. We aren't just looking to start Fundraising to donate a few products into a sparse amount of schools. We will be contacting every School Board to get them to join our Program.

     We are creating Applications that will be now, and forever, FREE. We'll work with each school district to individualize their applications and send free Tutorials to all personal. Anytime the software becomes outdated, or just needs to be tweaked, we will have upkeep servicing at no charge to the schools.

       Right now we have Teachers, Software Developers, Game Designers, and a great team of volunteers from around the globe working on Open-Source learning applications that can be stored directly to our network and accessed in any school with an Internet Connection.

     We also have a few volunteers working on Localizing the project into several other languages so that every child has the same opportunity. We really want to start inside several communities and for that to happen we need to work on our 501(c)3 Non Profit Status, building our network to house the open-source tools to allow anyone who wants to volunteer their time to help in the application building process, and pay for our basic organization bills.


What We Need & What You Get

Our Indiegogo fundraiser will allow us to file for our official 501(c)3 status and help us purchase the space we need to house our online network for our organizations website, volunteering pages and applications housing.

Our Perks have been donated donated to our cause by Writers like Martin Skate, Game Developers like Studio Oleomingus, IBOL, Flippfly and HardHead Games, Artists like Jessica Thornton, Kenton Sheely and Kelly Miller, Comic Publisher Hall of Comics, and Musicians like Karl R Olson, Kevin Balke and Martin Kvale.


Other Ways You Can Help

 There are many ways to help us out!

On our site we have a contact form you can use to get in touch with us if you'd like to inquire about out other ways you can help our organization by volunteering your time or other options. Thank you.

Please, share this with all your loved ones and friends all the amazing people out there through all aspects and Social Media outlets you can! Again, Thank you.

Thank you. Much love. And that’s all there is to it. 

Now to the betterment of Education in America!

story:
Short Summary

SGM Lifewords’ vision is to present the life-giving words of the Bible – to see hearts changed and lives transformed. We achieve this by freely resourcing people all over the world to share their faith through literature ministry and programmes. Our work started in 1888 and since then we have published well over a billion Bible resources in more than 1,000 languages worldwide.

However, demand is always greater than supply and the need for quality Bible resources in some languages is especially evident. One such language is Telugu, spoken by about 74 million people in southern and central India – it is the 3rd most used language in the country and 13th in the world.

There are many churches and Christian ministries looking for resources to help them share the Gospel with Telugu speakers. Unfortunately, at the moment we have nothing to give them – and here’s where you can help! We are ready to publish a Telugu version of An Invitation (a popular evangelistic booklet, available in many languages). To prepare and print 5,000 copies, we need 700 USD.

What we need

Here’s a breakdown of the cost needed to publish the booklet in Telugu:

  • Translation and proof-reading: 75 USD
    This is the amount that we need to hire a competent translator and a professional proof-reader.
  • Typesetting and administrative work: 75 USD
    This is the cost of administering the project, preparing the typeset, having it checked and delivered to the printing press.
  • Printing: 550 USD
    This is the cost of printing 5,000 copies of An Invitation booklet.

What if we do not get there

If we are unable to raise the whole amount, we will continue raising funds for this project in other places until funding is secured. Then the printing will commence. Please rest assured that your contribution will not be wasted!

The Impact

It very often happens that people who are most actively involved in bringing the Gospel to others are opportunity-rich but cash-poor. They are usually on their own when it comes to obtaining literature for the people they reach. SGM Lifewords has always been at the forefront of resourcing believers. By providing a Christian population living in the states of Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and in the union territory of Yanam with an evangelistic booklet, we will help them share the Gospel with their fellow neighbours and other Telugu speakers.

Risks & challenges

There are several risks involved in publishing a quality resource in a completely unfamiliar language, such as:

  1. finding a competent translator and a professional proof-reader;
  2. getting the typeset right (bad things tend to happen to fonts and texts laid out in non-Latin character sets);
  3. quality of the final print output.

Fortunately, we have considerable experience in publishing resources in various world languages. Risk no 1 is circumvented by SGM Lifewords’ office in India which has numerous local contacts. This office has been able to provide us with translators and proof-readers in Hindi, Tamil and other languages.

As for risk no 2, we have already typeset many resources in challenging languages such as Arabic (which is a right-to-left language) or Chinese Simplified (with its own distinct set of characters). We have the necessary tools and experience to handle this with ease. Additionally, we have already published An Invitation in 12 languages so we know how to get it right.

Last but not least, quality control is something that we exercise on a regular basis. We always carefully check each print run and if necessary we request print shops to improve their work before accepting the final output.

Other ways you can help

If you care about getting the Gospel out to people who have not heard it yet, you can use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word about this campaign within your circle of influence. Thank you in advance for your help!

story:
Short and simple - 

CHANGE MAKES A CHANGE -

So we"re becoming The 'Spare Change' Warriors .. 

These  children would beg in their country, so I'm taking it off the streets and on to a global level. The  Internet. 

Where the first change starts!

Orphanages in Indonesia need what to us is basic, but to them would be luxury - so I'm running a campaign. 


To give a little.. to the little people with out parents!


Simply... 


Just giving a little, to kids that don't have a lot.. At all.


*110% cent raised will be donated 


We need to replace :

- sheets and pillows

- socks and shoes

- pencils and paper

- shampoo and conditioner

- Lice treatment.

- medical basics - (band aids/bandages/antiseptic )

No $1  goes unused 

Thanks for making the world a better place.
