story:
"Have Bear Will Run!"

Raising funds for the education of children fighting cancer. 

WHO AM I?

My name is David King and I am an Education Coordinator at The Children’s Hospital, Westmead. My two great passions in life are children and sport and this year I am hoping to combine the two for what I believe to be a worthy and challenging cause. 

In recent years I have attempted a variety of challenges to not only challenge myself but to also raise awareness for less fortunate children.

  • I have trekked the Kokodo Trail,
  • I have run across the Sahara Desert in the 250km Marathon Des Sables Race,
  • I have set up an annual Indian Immersion exchange program and 
  • I have attempted to solo swim the English Channel.

I attempt these adventures to not only raise funds and awareness but to give people a sense of hope that anything is possible. I am committed now to helping families fight cancer by raising much needed funds for their children’s educational needs.

 

WHAT IS 'HAVE BEAR WILL RUN?'

Over the next 5 months I will be attempting to complete a marathon in every state of Australia to raise money and awareness for the ‘Back on Track’ Program at The Children’s Hospital, Westmead.

  • 6 months
  • 8 Marathons (42.2km)
  • 8 States of Australia
  • Carrying the Children's Hospital Bandaged Bear on my back!

This is a challenging process and one that I am not taking lightly but an event like this one pales in comparison to the hardship and courage shown by children and families who battle Cancer every day.

 

WHAT IS THE 'BACK ON TRACK' PROGRAM?

When children are diagnosed with cancer their entire world is thrown into chaos. Education is one of the only areas in their life that they can still have a sense of control over.

The ‘Back On Track’ Program at The Children’s Hospital, Westmead works with children, families and schools to develop support plans that meet the educational and social needs of the students while they are having treatment. They also assist with their transition back to full time schooling when the time arises, as well as educating their school and friends on how to support a child fighting cancer. This completely unique program bridges the gap between families fighting cancer in hospital and their child’s school.

 

WHAT I NEED? 

In order to compete in this event and raise much needed funds for The Back on Track Program. I have undertaken a strenuous training schedule as well as a significant financial burden. And for this reason I am reaching out to the wider community to request sponsorship, support, help… anything that will ensure this journey is a success.

By using 'indiegogo' I am unashamedly putting my humility and pride aside. I need financial support to fund the extensive travel costs, which will ultimately help raise the funds, needed for the 'Back on Track' Program. I am also in need of exposure to support the fantastic work done by the doctors, nurses, teachers, social workers and volunteers at the hospital. Any support would be greatly appreciated!

 

WHAT I CAN OFFER YOU?

All sponsors will be recognized on my website and various social media outlets. Significant donations will receive one or more of the following -

  • Certificates of Appreciation
  • Free drink at the fundraising after party
  • Advertising opportunities at each of the remaining marathons
  • A warm fuzzy feeling in your heart knowing you have helped numerous families in their bid to keep their children connected to their education and friends.

 

MARATHON CALENDAR

ACT   14th of April           Canberra Marathon   (42.2km)

VIC   19th of May            Great Ocean Road Marathon   (45km)

WA   16th of June            Perth Marathon   (42.2km)

QLD  7th of July              Gold Coast Airport Marathon   (42.2km)

NT     27th of July            Outback Marathon   (42.2km)

SA     25th of August        Adelaide Marathon   (42.2km)

TAS   1st of September        Ross Marathon   (42.2km)

NSW  22nd of September   Sydney Blackmore's Marathon   (42.2km)

story:
This year, I'm not giving up my birthday... 

Instead I'm traveling to Hong Kong in January and need all the help I can get!

For the past two years, I've fundraised for clean water during my birthday (November 29) and the Holiday season. I would do it again in a heartbeat, but reality kicked in. As a senior at NYU and unpaid intern I'm a bit short on the travel & education funds.

In Hong Kong I'll be taking NYU Steinhardt's Global Food Cultures course and pursuing my thesis research. 

I'm backing this experience on my own and need all the financial help I can get to make my dream of returning to Hong Kong come true!

The Class

Steinhardt's Global Food Cultures takes place in Hong Kong from January 2 - 14, 2014. It will not only teach me tons of culturally enriching information on Hong Kong and Asia, but it will also allow me to pursue further research on the cultural adaptations of Disney Parks around the world (my senior thesis project!). Check out more information about the course here.

Cost Breakdown

Here is a the cost breakdown for the trip, which is what your generous donations be going towards!

  • Food: $500 +
  • Housing Fees & Activities fees: $1,000 +
  • Flight: $1,500 +

The Goal

As you can see from the cost breakdown, the trip is going to to cost over $2,200. This is my fundraising goal because I turn 22 on November 29th, and in the spirit of feeling 22 I wanted to make my goal $22 Hundred. Plus let's be real: HONG KONG IS EXPENSIVE. Any contribution will be greatly appreciated small or large, whatever you can!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help out more, or you can't contribute some cash money, here's what else you can do:

  • Suggest a spot! Have a place on your travel list that seems cool? Let me know!
  • Spread the word!! (You can share on Facebook, Twitter, by email, etc.)
  • Follow my travels on Instagram/Twitter/Pinterest, whatever you want!
  • Follow my travel buddy's (+ my 1 of my closest friend) blog, WWW.YOUCANKISSMYSASS.COM where she will be updating our adventures!

Thank You!!

story:
About EARLA

EARLA works to improve government transparency and accountability, as well as protect media and citizen access to information through the reform of substantive law and administration of justice. EARLA works closely with its Egyptian partners on the ground to develop structural reforms of relevant laws and procedures that are accessible, fair, and efficient. 

EARLA’s work is nonpartisan and does not serve the interests of a particular party, organization, or individual. Rather, EARLA’s work focuses on supporting post-revolution reforms of Egypt’s laws and procedures.

 EARLA حول

تعمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون على تحسين شفلفية و مسئؤلية الحكومة، فضلا عن حماية وسائل الاعلام و ضمان وصول المواطن للمعلومات، من خلال اصلاح القانون الموضوع و اقامة العدل
تعمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون مع شركائها المصريين عن كثب على ارض الواقع لتطوير هيكلة القوانين و الاجرءات حتى تكون عادلة و فعالة و متاحة
عمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون هو عمل غير حزبي و لا يخدم مصلحة بعينه و لا منظمة و لا شخص بل يركز عمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون على دعم اصلاحات مرحلة ما بعد الثورة في هيكلة القوانين و الاجراءات في مصر
 

What We Have Done So Far

This past summer, during a training workshop, EARLA trained over forty attendees in Cairo on the elements of FOIL (Freedom of Information Legislation). Attendees learned about the key components of an affective freedom of information law, how it helps the average Egyptian, and ways in which the media, lawyers, and civil society can use the law to decrease corruption.

Egyptians have asked us for more workshops about transparency to help them become a democratic society.  And we need your help!

ما قمنا به حتى الان

في الصيف الماضي، خلال ورش عمل تدريبية، قامت اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون  بتدريب اكثر من اربعين في القاهرة على عناصر قانون حرية المعلومات، كيف تساعد المواطن المصري، و الطرق التي يمكن لوسائل الاعلام، المحامين و المجتمع المدني ان تستخدم بها القانون لتقليل الفساد
لقد طلبنا المصريون بالمزيد من ورش العمل حول الشفافية لمساعدتهم على ان يصبحوا مجتمع ديموقراطي

!و نحن بحاجة لمساعدتك 

We Need Your Help to Expand Our Workshops to More Leaders in Egypt

We need $6500 to provide the following services to the Egyptian legal reform community:

  • Provide Training Workshops to Lawyers, Journalists, and Civil Society on Transparency and Accountability ($1000)
  • Develop High Quality Training Materials on Freedom of Information and Transparency Laws and Policies ($1500)
  • Provide Arabic/English Translations of Legal Analysis and Training Materials ($1500)
  • Venue and Travel Expenses Associated With the Training Workshops ($2500)

Each workshop will address the following topics:

      1. An Overview of Freedom of Information Laws and Policies

      2. A Comparative Analysis of Best Practices in Promoting Transparency Within
          Developing and Developing Nations

      3. An Analysis and Breakdown of Circulating Drafts for an Egyptian Freedom of
          Information Act

      4. Analysis of How Transparency Laws Can Positively Impact Egyptian Citizens'
          Daily Lives

      5. Discussion of Key Impediments to Transparency and Accountability in Egypt's  
          Governance Structures

نريد مساعدتكم لتوسيع ورش العمل لتشمل المزيد من القادة المصريين

نحتاج 6500 دولار لتقديم الخدمات التلية لاصلاح المجتمع القانوني المصري

  تقديم ورش عمل تدريبية للمحامين و الصحفيين و المدافعين عن المجتمع المدني على الشفلفية و المساءلة - 1000 دولار

  تطوير مواد ذات جودة عالية للتدرب على حرية القوانين و السياسات - 1500 دولار

  توفير ترجمة عربي/ انجليزي من التحليل القانوني و مواد التدريب - 1500 دولار

  مكان السفر و النفقات المرتبطة بعمل التدريبات و ورش العمل - 2500 دولار

:كل ورشة عمل سوف تتناول المواضيع الاتية

   لمحة عامة عن قوانين حرية المعلومات و السياسات    -  

 تحليل مقارن لافضل الممارسات لتعزيز الشفافية داخل الدول المتطورة و الدول النامية    -  

  تحليل و توزيع مسودات قانون حرية تداول المعلومات    -  

  تحليل كيف يمكن لقوانين الشفافية ان تؤثر ايجابيا على حياة المصريين اليومية    -  

مناقشة العوائق الاساسية التي تعيق الشفافية و المساءلة في هيكلة الحكومة المصرية    -  

Your Donations Make a Significant Impact on Promoting Democracy

Egypt is a regional leader with a vibrant civil society eager to transform authoritarian regimes to functional democracies rooted in each country's norms and values.  EARLA is committed to providing them with the expertise and objective legal analysis to make informed decisions about the future of their nation.

EARLA is the only Egyptian American organization that focuses exclusively on rule of law in Egypt - a fundamental prerequisite for transitioning to democracy.  Through their language skills, cultural familiarity, and personal contacts, EARLA members have already made significant headway in supporting Egyptian lawyers, civil society advocates, and journalists in their indigenous reform efforts.  But we can do more with your donations.  Please help us promote democractic reforms led by Egyptians!

تبرعاتكم تحدث تأثيرا كبيرا على التويج للديموقراطية

مصر دولة رائدة في المنطقة مع وجود مجتمع مدني نابض بالحياة يحرص على تحويل النظم الاستبدادية الى نظم ديموقراطية فعالة لها جذور في قيم و معايير البلد. و تلتزم الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون  بتزويدهم بالخبرة و التحليل القانوني الموضوعي لمساعدتهم على اتخاذ قرارات مستنيرة حول مستقبل امتهم

الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون هي المنظمة المصرية الامريكية الوحيدة التي تركز بشكل حصري على سيادة القانون في مصر كشرط اساسي للتحول الديموقراطي. من خلال مهاراتهم اللغوية، مرونتهم الثقافية و اتصالاتهم الشخصية، قدم اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون بالفعل تقدما كبيرا في دعم المحامين المصريين، و المدافعين عن المجتمع المدني و الصحفيين و جهودهم الاصلية في الاصلاح، و لكن يمكننا ان نقدم المزيد بتبراعتكم

برجاء مساعدتنا لتعزيز الاصلاحات الديموقراطية بقيادة المصريين

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, help spread the word:

  • Like us on Facebook, https://www.facebook.com/EARLAEgypt
  • Follow us on Twitter, https://twitter.com/EARLAEgypt
  • Use hashtag #TransparencyEgypt and share our video, http://youtu.be/81ec4SC4gNM 
  • Visit our Website, http://www.earla.org/

story_txt:
About EARLA
EARLA
works to improve government transparency and accountability, as well as protect
media and citizen access to information through the reform of substantive law
and administration of justice. EARLA works closely with its Egyptian
partners on the ground to develop structural reforms of relevant laws and
procedures that are accessible, fair, and efficient. 

EARLA’s work is nonpartisan and
does not serve the interests of a particular party, organization, or individual.
Rather, EARLA’s work focuses on supporting post-revolution reforms of Egypt’s
laws and procedures. 

 EARLA حول

تعمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون على تحسين شفلفية و
مسئؤلية الحكومة، فضلا عن حماية وسائل الاعلام و ضمان وصول المواطن للمعلومات، من
خلال اصلاح القانون الموضوع و اقامة العدل
تعمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون مع شركائها المصريين عن كثب على ارض الواقع لتطوير هيكلة القوانين و
الاجرءات حتى تكون عادلة و فعالة و متاحة
عمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة دور القانون هو عمل غير حزبي و لا يخدم مصلحة
بعينه و لا منظمة و لا شخص بل يركز عمل اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية لسيادة
دور القانون على دعم اصلاحات مرحلة ما بعد
الثورة في هيكلة القوانين و الاجراءات في مصر 
What We Have Done So Far
This past summer, during a training workshop, EARLA trained over forty attendees in Cairo on the elements of FOIL (Freedom of Information Legislation). Attendees learned about the key components of an affective freedom of information law, how it helps the average Egyptian, and ways in which the media, lawyers, and civil society can use the law to decrease corruption. 
Egyptians have asked us for more workshops about transparency to help them become a democratic society.  And we need your help!

ما
قمنا به حتى الان

في الصيف الماضي، خلال ورش عمل تدريبية، قامت اعضاء الجمعية المصرية الامريكية
لسيادة دور القانون  بتدريب اكثر من اربعين
في القاهرة على عناصر قانون حرية المعلومات، كيف تساعد المواطن المصري، و الطرق
التي يمكن لوسائل الاعلام، المحامين و المجتمع المدني ان تستخدم بها القانون
لتقليل الفساد
لقد طلبنا المصريون بالمزيد من ورش العمل حول الشفافية لمساعدتهم على ان يصبحوا
مجتمع ديموقراطي
!و نحن بحاجة لمساعدتك 
We Need Your Help to Expand Our Workshops to More Leaders in Egypt
We need $6500 to provide the following
services to the Egyptian legal reform community:

Provide
     Training Workshops to Lawyers, Journalists, and Civil Society on
     Transparency and Accountability ($1000)
Develop
     High Quality Training Materials on Freedom of Information and Transparency
     Laws and Policies ($1500)
Provide
     Arabic/English Translations of Legal Analysis and Training Materials
     ($1500)
Venue
     and Travel Expenses Associated With the Training Workshops ($2500)

Each workshop will address the
following topics:
      1. An Overview of Freedom of
Information Laws and Policies
      2. A Comparative Analysis of
Best Practices in Promoting Transparency Within           Developing and Developing
Nations
      3. An Analysis and Breakdown of
Circulating Drafts for an Egyptian Freedom of           Information Act
      4. Analysis of How Transparency
Laws Can Positively Impact Egyptian Citizens'           Daily Lives
      5. Discussion of Key
Impediments to Transparency and Accountability in Egypt's            Governance Structures

story:
Hi Everyone

My heart bleeds to know more than 3000 people have been killed by a massive 7.9 magnitude earthquake that hit Nepal on April 25, 2015. The Death toll has been rapidly increasing and the number of injuries continue to rise.

I am appealing  to you friends, family and everyone reading this to make a little contribution to the affected people as they mourn their loss of love ones. Every little gesture helps so that they rebuild their lives again.

''One Small Donation - A Little Goes A Long Way'' 

What We Need 

I am aiming to raise USD 10500 
  • The  money we will use to  Provide Food and Water to those in need; Provide Blankets as many people are sleeping in streets after their houses has been destroyed by the earthquake. Provide Medicine and donate money to the local hospital and relief camps.

About Me :

For those who dont know me, I want to assure you that your contributions will be used to help victims of the earthquake . I think that sometimes people hesitate  to give because they don't know if their contributions will reach the right people, especially given the mismanagement of funds that occur after large scale natural disaster. That is why I think you should know a little about me so you can contribute knowing that your money will be put to the best use.  

Manish Bohara(21). I was born and raised in Pokhara one of the city of Nepal. I have complete my high school degree and now i am as a web designer and developer. And sometime working in the volunteering work in Pokhara. And this is my first time crowd funding to raise the money for those who are in need. I hope people will trust me and help me reach the goal of the this campaign and help people who are in need and who have been the victim of this earthquake. And i assure all the donors that  the money you give goes to the right organizations. That is my promise. 

Additional Resources

  1. Google has launched a Person Finder Tool to locate missing individuals in Nepal’s Earthquake.

  2. Facebook activated Safety Check for people affected by the earthquake in Nepal. It's a simple way to let family and friends know you're okay. If you're in one of the areas affected by the earthquake, you'll get a notification asking if you're safe, and whether you want to check on any of your friends. When disasters happen, people need to know their loved ones are safe. It's moments like this that being able to connect really matters.

  3. Earthquake Report.com has live updates with images and technical information on seismic activities.

  4. A Google spreadsheet Nepal Earthquake Fundraising Campaigns with tabs that list organizations and individual funding campaigns. I’m not sure of the author .

  5. Another Google spreadsheet, Blood Bank Earthquake Nepal 2015, with listing of blood group types needed for earthquake victims in Nepal. Again, I am not sure of the author.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word:  Please share this page with your friends and family. 

Other ways you can help is by donating to 

Red Cross Nepal: http://www.nrcs.org/donate-nrcs

Global Giving: https://www.globalgiving.org/projects/nepal-earthquake-relief-fund/

Assist those in need in anyway you can. If you have questions, please email Me back! 

#PRAYFORNEPAL

story:
The Shannen Koostachin Monument

After two years, we are in the final stages of the monument project!

Descriptor:  The piece will be a figurative depiction of Shannen Koostachin in her traditional regalia, incorporating impressionistic touches. The iconic figure will blend through drapery into a granite base. The sculpture will be finished in a traditional bronze patina, with highlights and color gradations on points of interest.


Here's a CBC story on the inspiration for the monument


WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL GO TOWARDS:


  • The bronze sculpture of Shannen 
  • Design, transportation and installation of the base
  • If we surpass the financial goal, the funds raised will be donated to SHANNEN'S DREAM charity
  • COMMUNITY MEMBERS who donate will carry the advocacy work of Shannen Koostachin in their hearts

Shannen Koostachin Profile

Shannen Koostachin Cree from  Attawapiskat First Nation lead a movement for “safe and comfy” schools and quality culturally based education for First Nations children called the Attawapiskat School Campaign. She knew how hard it was to learn in an on reserve school that was under funded. The only elementary school for the 400 children in Attawapiskat was closed as thousands of gallons of diesel fuel contaminated the ground under the school. The federal government put portable trailers on the play ground of the contaminated school as a “temporary school” until a new one could be built.

Shannen never went to class in a proper school and the portables became more unbarable over time. The heat would often go off, the children would have to walk outside in the cold to go from one portable to another and the doors were warped. Therefore the children of Attawapiskat launched the Attawapiskat School Campaign to reach out to non-Aboriginal children all across Canada to write to the federal government and demand a new school for Attwapiskat. Thousands of children answered the call and three Ministers of Indian Affairs promised a new school and then broke their promise. The children kept writing. When the Minister of Indian Affairs, Chuck Strahl, wrote in 2008 to say the federal government could not fund a new school, the grade 8 class cancelled their graduation trip to Niagara Falls and used the money to send three youth, including Shannen, down to meet with Minister Strahl to demand a new school.

Minister Strahl said the government could not afford a new school. Shannen did not believe him and that she told the Minister she would never give up because the younger children in her community deserve a proper school. She kept her promise. Shannen spoke to thousands of people asking for their help to ensure every child got a good education and a “comfy” school. She was an inspiring speaker because she talked from the heart. She made a compelling speech at an education rights conference hosted by the children of Attawapiskat and attended by 500 other children at the University of Toronto in 2009.  Shannen’s incredible leadership was remarkable and she was nominated, as an ambassador for all the children of Attawapiskat, for the International Children’s Peace Prize given out by the Nobel Laureates. In 2009, Minister Strahl promised the children of Attawapiskat a new school.

In May of 2010, Shannnen Koostachin passed away in an automobile accident. With the support of her loving family, friends and community, Shannen’s Dream is a campaign named in her memory to make sure all First Nations children across Canada have “safe and comfy schools” and receive a good quality education that makes them proud of who they are.

Quoting Jenny Nakogee (the late Shannen's mother): "My message is to never give up. You get up, pick up your books and keep walking in your moccasins."


Mee'Kwetch for the donations thus far, the funds raised will help make this MONUMENT happen


***We know sending/filling out online forms to donate can be a bit unsettling.  If this is the case please feel free to mail checks/money orders to:

VisJuelles Productions Inc.
152 Edmund Street
Sudbury, ON P3E 1L7

Receipt of donation will be mailed promptly for your records and ours

Summary

Whatchia!   My name is Jules Koostachin, I'm Cree from Attawapiskat First Nation and currently living in Sudbury with my family.  I currently work at Laurentian University as the Equity and Diversity Advisor in the Human Rights Office,  Northern Recruitment for the Indigenous Visual Culture Program at OCADU in Toronto, and as an educator at the University of Sudbury, Indigenous Studies program.  I am also a multimedia artist, and an activist for Indigenous rights and equal access to education. I will be heading out west this coming fall to start my PhD at UBC in the Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice Program where I will be focusing on Indigenous women and digital narratives.

In 2011, I had the opportunity to visit the sacred site where Shannen Koostachin passed away, just south of Temagami in northern Ontario. To my surprise I found it extremely difficult to locate because the shrine was up on a small hill on the side of highway 11.   To this day, the image of the community shrine for Shannen lives in the back of my mind and has for many many years.

In the summer of 2013,  I was sitting at my desk in Toronto, and suddenly I was gifted with a  powerful vision; I quickly ran outside and called my cousin Andrew Koostachin, the late Shannen’s father.  I asked for the family's permission to take the lead in the creation of a monument/public installation for Shannen, and he agreed, giving me his full blessing.  I assured him that he and his family would be consulted throughout the development and installation process.

For the last few years, my friend Rick Miller (fellow documentary filmmaker) and I have been trying to find ways to fund raise and gather community support in hopes that  Shannen's life's work is honoured and remembered. 

To date I have been able to locate funding through the Ontario Arts Council, but I am still IN NEED of your community spirit and support to raise the remainder of the funds to go towards the balance owing for the completion of the bronze monument and lastly the installation of the monument.

So I am asking all of you for your support to raise the last $25,000 which will go towards the monument base (granite, installation of the solar lights and transportation to site from Sudbury) and the remainder of the sculptor fees.   

NOTE:   I have been successful in securing a site for the monument/public installation; it will be installed this coming fall in New Liskeard, Ontario. 

I feel that it is necessary to ensure that we have the Shannen Monument in northern Ontario, as this is where Shannen's roots are and it will be a sacred place where northern community members will be able to access and pay their respects.

JULES' BIO:  Born in Moose Factory, Ontario, Jules Arita Koostachin was raised by her Cree speaking grandparents in Moosonee, and her mother in Ottawa. She is from Attawapiskat First Nation, and currently resides in Sudbury. While living in Toronto, she completed graduate school at Ryerson University where she was awarded the Award of Distinction for her thesis work, as well as the Masters level Ryerson Gold Medal for academic achievement. While pursuing her Masters, Jules finished her first feature length documentary Remembering Inninimowin, about her journey of remembering the Cree language, now distributed by V Tape. After graduation, Jules was one of six women selected across Canada for the Women in the Directors Chair program at the Banff Centre, where she directed a scene from her script Broken Angel. She just finished production of her television youth series AskiBOYZ for APTN, about two urban Cree youth going back to the basics. Jules’ company VisJuelles Productions Inc. has a number of television and film projects in development, her most recent development is Red Barz about the incarceration of Indigenous women in Canada with Shaw Media. She has been working in the Indigenous community for many years servicing Indigenous women and children who are facing barriers. She hopes to continue creating pieces of work in theatre, literary arts, television, and film that will bring to light social issues that urban and rural Indigenous peoples face.

http://www.visjuellesproductions.ca/


Impact

  • The impact of this monument will be TREMENDOUS because it will be one of remembrance and honour
  • The Shannen Monument will be a reminder to all of Shannen's Dream and the importance of fighting for equitable access to education in Canada

Dedication and Commitment:

Shannen's advocacy has lead to change in legislation, and to a NEW SCHOOL in Attawapiskat First Nation.  I believe a monument honoring her young life is an important tribute to Canadian and Indigenous herstory.

THE MONUMENT:

The proposed bronze life-like monument of Shannen Koostachin will stand approximately 48 inches in height and it will rest upon a granite base approximately 1-2 feet in height.

We are also looking to have two butterfly benches made for Shannen Koostachin's and Rose Thornton's families, they will be placed beside the monument. 

Sadly, there were two lives taken on June 1, 2010, therefore, we will also be paying our respects to Rose Thornton by providing a plaque at the base of the monument with a quote from Rose.

The ARTISTS Involved in the CREATION of the Shannen Monument:

  • Design/Cultural Consultant Kenneth (Jake) Chakasim (Funded by the Ontario Arts Council)
  • Sculptor Tyler Fauvelle (Funded by this campaign)
  • As the project lead, please be assured that I will continue with this campaign until the monument is installed
  • My overall goal is to have this monument/public installation erected in New Liskeard by late SEPTEMBER/OCTOBER 2015!

Introducing Design/Cultural Consultant Kenneth (Jake) Chakasim:  Jake is a lecturer with Laurentian University’s School of Architecture where he teaches design studio. His interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to the creation of indigenous art + architecture addresses the need to re-contextualize Aboriginal traditions through refined typologies.

Quoting Jake:  "When I hear the name Shannen Koostachin I instantaneously think of dire ‘living-learning’ conditions of Attawapiskat’s First Nation children and youth.  More extensively, I’m also aware of the fact there are many more communities across Northern Ontario that are challenged with similar or worse off socio-economic conditions.  So, it’s fair to say, this project is just as much the plight of all First Nation children today as it was yesterday.  As with all monument projects, this one serves many purposes.  For some, it's a placeholder away from home, for others, a beacon of light indicating a way forward and that, to me, is the message I bring as a collaborative designer to this project.  The need to sustain Shannen’s transformational message of hope!"   

Introducing Sculptor Tyler Fauvelle:  Tyler is a professional sculptor, based in Northern Ontario, Canada.  Inspired by Canada’s natural and cultural heritage, he works in a figurative style, sculpting in clay and casting his work in classic bronze.   He will be unveiling several public art sculptures this summer, including a life-sized bronze commemorating Canadian music icon Stompin’ Tom Connors.  Tyler will have the honour of creating a life-sized monument commemorating Francis Pegahmagabow, one of Canada’s greatest First Nation war heroes. (June 2016)

Quoting Tyler: “My hope for this sculpture is that it will help aboriginal youth see their own reflection in Shannen’s heroic face, and realize that they can, and that they must, carry on with her vision.”

To see more of Tyler's work, please see link below:

http://tylerfauvelle.ca/

Short Documentary Film: "The Butterfly Monument"

Both myself and filmmaker Rick Miller will be filming the process of installing the monument/public installation, which will, after a year of festival submissions be accessible and free to watch online. 

We both feel that it is extremely important to document this endeavour and create an Indigenous archive.

***Note: The short documentary film was fully funded by the Ontario Arts Council

Introducing Documentary Filmmaker Rick Miller:

RICK'S BIO:  Rick has been in the documentary industry since graduating from York University’s film school. He has edited in excess of 100 television programs, spending over 20,000 hours in Toronto’s edit suites. His credits include productions for TVO, Discovery, History, CTV, and CBC.  After earning a Master of Fine Arts in Documentary Media Rick has been awarded two artist residencies and has been working as a photographer and videographer on a wide variety of projects.  Rick is currently developing Labyrinth, an interactive documentary on his own search for a cure for mental illness.

To see more of Rick's work:

https://vimeo.com/rickmiller
https://www.flickr.com/photos/millrick/

Quoting Rick:  "I first heard about Shannen when Jules shared the news of her death with me. I was saddened by the loss of such a young life, of course, but as Jules told me more about Shannen's extraordinary efforts to help the children of
Attawapiskat First Nation I came to realize that the world had lost a leader and a teacher. Meeting Shannen's family has convinced me that her spirit lives on. Working on this project has been a humbling and enriching experience for me." 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can do to get the word out there is appreciated:

  • Please help us get the word out there by sharing the link
  • Please help us make some noise about this important campaign
  • Please use the Indigogo share tools!

Chi Mee'Kwetch!
story_txt:
The Shannen Koostachin Monument
After two years, we are in the final stages of the monument project!
Descriptor:  The piece will be a figurative depiction of Shannen Koostachin 
in her traditional regalia, incorporating impressionistic touches. The 
iconic figure will blend through drapery into a granite base. The 
sculpture will be finished in a traditional bronze patina, with 
highlights and color gradations on points of interest.
Here's a CBC story on the inspiration for the monument

WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL GO TOWARDS:


The bronze sculpture of Shannen 
Design, transportation and installation of the base
If we surpass the financial goal, the funds raised will be donated to SHANNEN'S DREAM charity
COMMUNITY MEMBERS who donate will carry the advocacy work of Shannen Koostachin in their hearts


Shannen Koostachin Profile


Shannen Koostachin Cree from  Attawapiskat First Nation lead a movement for 
“safe and comfy” schools and quality culturally based education for 
First Nations children called the Attawapiskat School Campaign. She knew how hard it was to learn in an on reserve school 
that was under funded. The only elementary school for the 400 
children in Attawapiskat was closed as thousands of gallons of diesel 
fuel contaminated the ground under the school. The federal government 
put portable trailers on the play ground of the contaminated school as a
 “temporary school” until a new one could be built. 
Shannen never went to class in a proper school and the portables 
became more unbarable over time. The heat would often go off, the 
children would have to walk outside in the cold to go from one portable 
to another and the doors were warped. Therefore the children of Attawapiskat 
launched the Attawapiskat School Campaign to reach out to non-Aboriginal
 children all across Canada to write to the federal government and 
demand a new school for Attwapiskat. Thousands of children answered the call and three Ministers of Indian
 Affairs promised a new school and then broke their promise. The 
children kept writing. When the Minister of Indian Affairs, Chuck 
Strahl, wrote in 2008 to say the federal government could not fund a new
 school, the grade 8 class cancelled their graduation trip to Niagara 
Falls and used the money to send three youth, including Shannen, down to
 meet with Minister Strahl to demand a new school.

Minister Strahl said the government could not afford a new school. 
Shannen did not believe him and that she told the Minister she would 
never give up because the younger children in her community deserve a 
proper school. She kept her promise. Shannen spoke to thousands of 
people asking for their help to ensure every child got a good education 
and a “comfy” school. She was an inspiring speaker because she talked 
from the heart. She made a compelling speech at an education rights 
conference hosted by the children of Attawapiskat and attended by 500 
other children at the University of Toronto in 2009.  Shannen’s incredible leadership was remarkable and she was nominated, as an 
ambassador for all the children of Attawapiskat, for the International 
Children’s Peace Prize given out by the Nobel Laureates. In 2009, 
Minister Strahl promised the children of Attawapiskat a new school.

In May of 2010, Shannnen Koostachin passed away in an automobile 
accident. With the support of her loving family, friends and community, 
Shannen’s Dream is a campaign named in her memory to make sure all First
 Nations children across Canada have “safe and comfy schools” and 
receive a good quality education that makes them proud of who they are.
Quoting Jenny Nakogee (the late Shannen's mother): "My message is to never give up. You get up, pick up your books and keep walking in your moccasins."

Mee'Kwetch for the donations thus far, the funds raised will help make this MONUMENT happen

***We know sending/filling out online forms to donate can be a bit unsettling.  If this is the case please feel free
 to mail checks/money orders to:

 VisJuelles Productions Inc. 152 Edmund Street Sudbury, ON P3E 1L7

 Receipt of donation will be mailed promptly for your records and ours
Summary
Whatchia!   My name is Jules Koostachin, I'm Cree from Attawapiskat First Nation and currently living in Sudbury with my family.  I currently work at Laurentian University as the Equity and Diversity Advisor in the Human Rights Office,  Northern Recruitment for the Indigenous Visual Culture Program at OCADU in Toronto, and as an educator at the University of Sudbury, Indigenous Studies program.  I am also a multimedia artist, and an activist for Indigenous rights and equal access to education. I will be heading out west this coming fall to start my PhD at UBC in the Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice Program where I will be focusing on Indigenous women and digital narratives.

In 2011, I had
the opportunity to visit the sacred site where Shannen Koostachin passed away, just south of Temagami
in northern Ontario. To my surprise I found it extremely difficult to
locate because the shrine was up on a small hill on the side of highway 11.   To this day, the image of the community shrine for Shannen lives in the back of my mind and has for many many years. 
In the summer of 2013,  I was
sitting at my desk in Toronto, and suddenly I was gifted with a  powerful vision; I quickly ran outside and
called my cousin Andrew Koostachin, the late Shannen’s father.  I asked for the family's permission to take the lead in
the creation of a monument/public installation for Shannen, and he agreed, giving me his full blessing.  I assured him that he and his family would be consulted throughout the development and installation process.

For the last few years, my friend Rick Miller (fellow documentary filmmaker) and I have been trying to find ways to fund raise and gather community support in hopes that  Shannen's life's work is honoured and remembered.  
To date I have been able to locate funding through the Ontario Arts Council, but I am still IN NEED of your community spirit and support to raise the remainder of the funds to go towards the balance owing for the completion of the bronze monument and lastly the installation of the monument.
So I am asking all of you for your support to raise the last $25,000 which will go towards the monument base (granite, installation of the solar lights and transportation to site from Sudbury) and the remainder of the sculptor fees.    
NOTE:   I have been successful in securing a site for the monument/public installation; it will be installed this coming fall in New Liskeard, Ontario.  
I feel that it is necessary to ensure that we have the Shannen Monument in northern Ontario, as this is where Shannen's roots are and it will be a sacred place where northern community members will be able to access and pay their respects. 
JULES' BIO:  Born in Moose Factory, Ontario, Jules Arita Koostachin was raised by her Cree speaking grandparents in Moosonee, and her mother in Ottawa. She is from Attawapiskat First Nation, and currently resides in Sudbury. While living in Toronto, she completed graduate school at Ryerson University where she was awarded the Award of Distinction for her thesis work, as well as the Masters level Ryerson Gold Medal for academic achievement. While pursuing her Masters, Jules finished her first feature length documentary Remembering Inninimowin, about her journey of remembering the Cree language, now distributed by V Tape. After graduation, Jules was one of six women selected across Canada for the Women in the Directors Chair program at the Banff Centre, where she directed a scene from her script Broken Angel. She just finished production of her television youth series AskiBOYZ for APTN, about two urban Cree youth going back to the basics. Jules’ company VisJuelles Productions Inc. has a number of television and film projects in development, her most recent development is Red Barz about the incarceration of Indigenous women in Canada with Shaw Media. She has been working in the Indigenous community for many years servicing Indigenous women and children who are facing barriers. She hopes to continue creating pieces of work in theatre, literary arts, television, and film that will bring to light social issues that urban and rural Indigenous peoples face.http://www.visjuellesproductions.ca/

Sculptor Tyler Fauvelle (Funded by this campaign)

story:
About The Love & Light Institute

The Love & Light Institute is a non-profit learning environment where science connects mind, body, emotion, and soul.

When one's mind, body, emotion, and soul are in alignment one can more fully manifest life’s richness and meaning. And that is why we are thrilled to have the ability to offer classes – both in-person and online – that bring all four of these pillars together within one learning environment.

Our Vision

We have a vision to expand our ability to teach, touch, and heal more people in Atlanta… in the south… in the U.S…. and even all around the world.

And we want to do it with YOU.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $90,000 to cover our initial start-up costs. We will use these funds for class development, product development, faculty training, branding and marketing.

Any amount helps — $10, $25, $100, $500 or more! Your donation is tax-deductible.

We have all sorts of great rewards for every donation level. Check out our perks in the right-hand column right over there →

Will YOU be the change you want to see in the world? We hope you’ll join us. Please invest today!

THANK YOU! And be well — mind, body, emotion, and soul.

XOXO,
Jamie & Corey

The Love & Light Institute is a registered not-for-profit Georgia Corporation and a Verified Nonprofit with Indiegogo. Donations are tax-deductible.

story:
Hello name is Asia Fajardo-Wright, my indigenous name is Xotchiquatzali which is nahautl for Beautiful Flower.

I am a saxophonist, composer and cultural educator. For the past 10 plus years I have been involved in the non-profit world providing arts outreach education to k-12 schools in Colorado by teaching students about art, music, and the Mexica (Aztec) culture through art projects, workshops and presentations.

My activities as a saxophonist/composer have included leading the ensemble Asia Jazz Project and composing an experimental musical called Omecihuatl Rising that was debuted at the Aurora Fox Theater in 2010. I have performed with hip-hop artist Molina Speaks, some featured performances where TedEx in Denver and opening up for Lupe Fisaco. I was also a saxophonist for Mono Verde and the Pink Hawks.

I am currently earning my Masters in Music performance at the University of Wyoming and am the saxophone graduate assistant for which I teach applied saxophone lessons. I am also activity composing and researching Native American saxophonist Jim Pepper. I am interested in how cross-cultural composition is important in engaging students of color in their culture.

I'm very passionate about music and I strive to complete my schooling. I have been struggling with my instrument for which I have had to repair several times. My current instrument has cost time, money, and strain on my being. This cost is no longer tolerable. I really need assistance in getting a reliable instrument that will get me through my Master's in Music, and allow me to continue my work with community and the arts.
Title: Asia's Nahui Nahui Composition


My instrument has been reliable for 15 years. However, now even after a very expensive over haul it still has issues with holding its key alignment. When its out of alignment I have to take it to a saxophone repair specialist immediately, because it is impossible to play.

 
  I have already spent my savings on my instrument's repairs, leaving me to use my last resort, using this campaign, in hopes for some help. Currently I have taken out all of my offered school loans for my schooling and can no long afford to take out any more otherwise I will go over the amount I can responsibly pay back.

What I need? I need assistance in purchasing a new alto saxophone. I want to purchase a Yamaha 82 Z for which I need 5,000 (horn, tax, and new instrument set up). A new instrument will enable me to complete my Master's in Music and should last another 20 years.

A new saxophone will help me to teach future generations. How can I get me students to listen to me, if my instrument won't? My goals are to teach a creative/experimental ensemble for instrumentalist and composers, applied saxophone lessons, and work as the cultural diversity specialist for a high school or college that values cultural diversity, creativity, and community.

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone!

As you may or may not have heard, Mrs. Rajabally was recently diagnosed with breast cancer. We don't know what stage she is at, but her current students have been doing various things, like wearing pink and tying pink ribbons around the school, to show their support for her. But some of us former students are thinking that it would be amazing to do something to show that her FORMER students also support her in this difficult time. Whether you took one of her French classes or not, Rajabally was always an optimistic and present figure within Yale and we think it goes without saying that she has been a very influential person in many of her students' lives. 

We know that many of us are struggling students who don't have a whole lot of money to spare, but if you can even donate $5, that's good enough. To bring back a little of that competitive Yale spirit, we want to encourage people to donate by making this a competition of sorts! Included in this fundraiser are 7 grad classes (2008 to 2014). Whichever class can raise the most money wins...ultimate bragging rights? We can work this out later! Please circulate this link to everyone you know who has been a student of Yale or of Raj's, and please ensure Raj doesn't catch wind of this (ie. don't share on your Facebook pages, only send by direct messages!) - we want to keep this a surprise!

When you donate, feel free to leave a comment of encouragement to Raj AS WELL AS YOUR GRAD YEAR so that we can keep track of how much each class has raised. We will show her this campaign page after we present her with the money. 

The Impact

Every year, Raj has done the CIBC Run for the Cure. It seems fitting that 100% of the funds raised will be donated to the Canadian Breast Cancer Foundation on her behalf. Ms. Burdeyny has confirmed that she believes Raj will prefer the money to be donated, so this shall be the plan!

The $500 goal is the smallest amount we could use - we're hoping to go ABOVE and BEYOND this! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Write letters and send cards of support to Raj! Let her know that you support her, how she's made a difference to you, and what you've been up to in your life. She would love to hear all about her former students! If you're interested in doing this, please contact myself or Tamara to get Raj's address, as we don't want this information floating around the internet all willy-nilly like.

story:
NEWS FLASH:  My story was on the Seattle KOMO4 news.  Please watch:

http://www.komonews.com/news/problemsolvers/169251946.html

 

Short Summary

Hello:  My name is Irene and my husband and I are here to ask for donations to purchase a second hand wheelchair van.  I am a Polio survivor and have spent over 55 years in a wheelchair.  Now I am experiencing the effects of Post Polio Syndrome.

Our current van has over 250,000 miles on it now.  It is falling apart and this is our only means of transportation.  A new van would be out of our reach as they cost $45,000 and up.  We think we could find a used van that still has life in it and would fit our needs.

You probably know someone that was touched by the Polio epidemic.  Maybe a parent or grandparent, aunt or uncle, brother or sister, or even you yourself. 

Hundreds of thousands of these survivors are experiencing a second round of symptoms.  This comes from the overuse of their good muscles to compensate for what was lost. After establishing a life, being hit a second time with the Post Polio symptoms is very hard.  Most doctors that know about how to treat Polio patients are also dying which leaves us in quite a situation.  Most younger doctors have no idea how we were effected.

What We Need

My husband is also disabled and works part time.  His job with our disability benefits makes for limited income.  We have one credit card that we hope to pay off if we get enough funds.  Then my husband could quit his job and stay home and take care of me.  My condition has steadily grown worse and I don't have the strength to be at home by myself.

I set our goal as $10,000 because any amount would be a blessing.  But we are hoping to get $20000.  This would give us about $15000 for a used van and $5000 to pay off our Sears Card.

Then by being really frugal, Joe could quit his job and be home with me.

 A Few Of Our Problems

I have severe scoliosis and have had 3 surgeries but that was years ago and the scoliosis continues to worsen.

I have great fatigue and sleep problems.  My weakness prevents me from doing many of the things I used to do.  My poor husband has to do most of the housework and cooking.

My hands have been going numb, which makes even using the computer very difficult. (and I love to use my computer and photoshop).

My aches and pains get so bad that many times I have to stay in bed and just rest to recoup.  (I don't even like going shopping anymore!)

My husband, Joe has back problems from his accident.  His leg is constantly numb.  His varicose veins are very bad.  He also suffers from Fibromyagia which causes him constant aches and pains.

What we hope to do with old van

If we are able to get a new van we would like to donate our old van to our local, small town senior center.  Then seniors with disabilities could get a ride to the center for food, fun and association.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are certanly aware of the economic conditions and not everyone can contribute.  But please, pass this along to anyone in your group of friends because even a dollar would help.  

You can use the Indiegogo share tools.

Although we have challenges, we look for ways to help others.  You will never really know how much your help means to us and how grateful we are.  Thank you from the bottom of our hearts...

story:
Cambodia and Vietnam!

The past few weeks have been chaotic and rather busy so unfortunately, I have had little time to host my usual fundraising events.  Since my post on facebook, many of you have expressed interest in contributing to the nonprofit work that I will be doing while over in Siem Reap and Saigon.  As I work out my schedule with the Somaly Mam Foundation and Thay Thich Chon Tinh (a Buddhist monk that I traveled with while I was in VN), I figure that no matter what, I will be doing some form of non-profit work!

I'm setting my goal at $500 for those who want to contribute and hopefully I can achieve it with your help!  

For those of you who have followed my adventures in the past 4 years, you have seen my work in Nepal, Vietnam and Costa Rica.  Although each of these countries were for  a Habitat for Humanity build, I do normally try to purchase basic necessities such as slippers, notebooks, pens, shampoo, conditioner, combs, soap, school uniforms, and my favorite candy - packs of Skittles (toothbrushes and toothpaste to be included) for the kids in the community:)  

I am coordinating with the human trafficking shelters in Cambodia while also going back and revisiting my little friends in Vietnam (as noted in the pictures above).

Any contribution large or small will be incredibly helpfull and all funds will go directly to the children and their community.  

Thank you for your enthusiastic energy and support!!  Additional information provided below!

Annie

SOMALY MAM FOUNDATION

Cambodia has 3 residential rehabilitation and training centers, housing a total of 180-200 women and children at any one time. The breakdown is approximately:

  • Babies and toddlers under 5: Approximately 15-20. This includes young residents, and children/babies of adult women
  • Children 5-18 years old: Approximately 70
  • Women over 18 years old (usually under 30): Approximately 100-120

** Heading to Cambodia January 1-4 to meet with staff.  A list of the shelter's needs were emailed to me. if you'd like a copy (since it is rather extensive), please let me know and I can forward the details.

About the SIEM REAP CENTER -  44 women, 3 infants

The center houses adult women who pursue a full time vocational training program in either sewing, weaving or hairdressing. Again, they also receive supplementary programs in Khmer literacy and numeracy, English, computing, agriculture, small business management and life skills. Women who have babies are able to live with their children and we employ a child care worker to take care of them during the day while the women are in training. The average age range is about 19-24, however we do sometimes have women up to about 30 years of age.

The team of social workers visit brothels and sex establishments on a daily basis to deliver their outreach program in HIV prevention and support for sex workers. The items listed are things frequently needed by sex workers, who are often living in very basic conditions with little access to or spare income for hygiene products or contraceptives. (Please contact me for the list)

story:
Bricks for change is the name of this mission, but the true mission kicked off  two years ago during my first trip to Madagascar that began with the desire to share the endangered and endemic wildlife of Madagacar with schools here in the United states through SKYPE ( live internet feed).. 


The initial mission took an unexpected turn when my former professor  Dr. Pat Wright of Stony Brook University, and founder of Centre Val bio Research station invited me to do wildlife program for UNICEF's connecting classrooms program, and for children in the town of Ranomafana Madagascar.

 We had a fantastic time, and although there was a language barrier it seemed to have no effect on the excitement of the children. My guide Jose translated and the they were very responsive and appeared to light up with JOY!.

After meeting  the children and families It was apparent that many lived in poverty... and unfortunately  many of the children could not go to school because  they had to work at a young age to help their families to make a living...

Following the program I asked  my guide Jose  who is now now great friend,if it would be possible to create a nature center in Ranomafana Madagascar.

 He explained that the children and families  would really benefit from having something like in the village. But more importantly  provide knowledge of nature through hands on education and experiences, which many children will not because they cannot afford to go to school,  and those that do attend class have a limited education due to lack of books and supplies.  

How will we do it?

How will we do it  I asked ? Both Dr. Wright and  Jose informed  me that it would be necessary to meet with the Mayor and  write a letter to the people of the town.  

Thanks to  the assistance of Eileen,  Dede, and Jean Claude and other staff members at Center val bio a meeting with the Mayor was arranged. The Mayor was very open and grateful for our plans to provide something positive for the village.   

At the close of our meeting he shook my hand and said "I am looking forward  to your mission to bring Nature education to the Village. This will be of great benefit to our children." 

 A few months later we received a letter from the people of Ranomafana giving us permission to have the nature center in the their town!

Since December 2011 we have shared over 20 lessons through Skype sessions, Nature videos, activity sheets , and provided snack for the children.  This program has continued and has been funded through Erik's Reptile Edventures and  with donations from friends, and costs about 300 dollars a month to run the program. 

We also set up a not for Profit called WKCI to allow us to Raise funds and WKCI was set up in May 2012 with the approval of the Education Department of NY. After providing educational programs for hundreds of schools and institutions throughout the New York Tri-state area it was time to expand the give back to the local and global community by connecting our kids to nature and life beyond our own back yard.

We Want You To Join! 

 The most important thing is for you all to be part of an effort that will change your life!  It has definitely changed mine and  the lives of others. The feeling of joy that is shared when your heart is open to the whole of humanity is indescribable!  

On January 31st we received an estimate pictured below and it will cost 65,000 to build the Nature education center, We will need the support of many to generate the funds. 

We really want you to be part of this and to share in the global community!

 On January  31st the contractor sent an estimate  including the cost  of 65,000 to build the center.  The additional 35,000 will run the center for the next 3 years and Provide education for thousands of Kids we're hoping for millions over the next 10 years. 

Who Benefits?

Our kids and everyone who will listen! 

The funds we seek will help the children have a nature center that will provide weekly activities, and a chance to go to school we will also get the unite with the local communities to support conservation and preservation initiatives in Madagascar and any of the countries we visit.

Please give what you can afford. All donations will be greatly appreciated.*


When Will The Journey Begin?

The Journey will begin from February 22nd until March 10th  Live from Erik's Reptile Edventures Website www. edventureshow .com and click on the video tab  then click streaming Live.. Hope to see you all in Madagascar and thank you for taking time to read this! 

Peace Joy and Happiness always  Love Erik 

Please join our campaign and buy a brick for change ! 

visit  www.edventureshow.com for more details

story:
Kentucky Partnership for Families and Children, Inc. (KPFC)

KPFC is a statewide, not-for-profit family organization.  KPFC's vision is that all families raising youth and children affected by behavioral health challenges will achieve their fullest potential.  KPFC's mission is to empower families affected by behavioral health challengs to initiate person and system change. 

A family organization is an organization that is family-governed and family-run. KPFC's board must be over 51% parents/primary caregivers raising children with behavioral health challenges. KPFC's staff are 80% parents/primary caregivers that have raised, or are raising, children with behavioral health challenges.  One staff member is an adult that has lived experience of growing up with a behavioral health challenge.

What We Need & What You Get.

KPFC needs approximately $25,000 to host a weekend-long conference for teens and young adults with behavioral health challenges and their parents (45-50 families).  Because many of the families we serve live in poverty, KPFC provides both nights of lodging, all meals, training materials, and workshops for $25 per family to show they have "buy in."  If families cannot afford the $25, it is waived.  

The Impact 

This conference along with the other activities implemented by KPFC transforms lives.  Because of the stigma related to children's behavioral health needs, these teens, young adults and their families are often isolated, shamed, and blamed.  This conference is often the first time teens, young adults and their families meet other teens, young adults and families.  To watch their fear, embarrassment and shyness become excitement, pride and enthusiasm over one weekend is amazing.  Once these teens, young adults and families become empowered, KPFC offers many other opportunities to help them achieve their fullest potential 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate, but want to help?  

  • Please share this page with others that might be interested in donating.  
  • If you are a parent raising a child with behavioral health challenges and live in, or near, Kentucky, please join us at our conference.
  • Educate your family and friends about children's mental health challenges and how they might support families without judgment.

story:
Summary

 Glencoe DECA is a marketing at Glencoe High School, located in Hillsboro Oregon. This year, as years in the past,  DECA students create and participate in a five day field trip to another city. While there the students have an opportunity to learn about various aspects of the city. These include:

  • The history of the locale.
  • Local landmarks that enhance the historical perspective - many times this helps the students understand the history of not only the city, but history of the United States.
  • Businesses in the visited city - including a tour of some of them that city is known for.
  • A visit to a college or university in the area.

Many of the students that participate in these field trips have never left the state and know little of other cities. When they participate in these field trips they have the opportunity to see other parts of the U.S. and how the people there live and work. They get an opportunity to experience other cultures that live in the locale and widen their vision of what it is to be an American. They also have the opportunity to broaden their view of what a higher education could mean to them.

This fundraising effort will also help low income students pay their DECA dues and costs for other fieldtrips.

Also, for every $10.00 made from this campaign $2.00 will go toward the Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA), a non-profit that helps children with nuero-muscular disease through funding research and services.

What We Need

This year DECA is planning a trip to Hawaii. The trip is planned by the students with the guidance of an instructor. The cost for each student for this trip is $950.00. It is the group's hope that they will be able to raise enough funds to pay for 1/2 of 10  students costs so they can participate in this field trip.

The students are very excited about some of the planned activities, such as a visit to Pearl Harbor and the Arizona Memorial, the Dole Plantation (along with a visit to a historically correct early plantation village),  a tour of the University of Hawaii, the Waikiki Aquarium, and the Polynesian Village that represents the cultures of Hawaii and neighboring islands.

If we don't reach our ultimate goal, what funds we raise will still help some of the students participate in the field trip. Eacsudent is going to share this campaign with their friends and family so they can help them make this "once in life time" trip.


The Impact

For some students, participating in this campaign and field trip it will be their first time traveling out of state or visiting another state of the union. While on this trip they will learn about the diversity of this country and how it makes it unique and the best country to be from. To be knowledgeable citizens of this country (and the world) it is important for young people know understand all of it's citizens. This trip is a perfect opportunity for them to see part of the grandeur of this country and how other's live. 

This trip also gives the students an opportunity to realize that they can and should pursue a higher education, perhaps at the university that they will visit. Another opportunity for the students is to understand some of the needed skills needed for various occupations, such as in the hospitality industry or international business.

Of course there will be some time for fun, if enough money is raised the students could swim with dolphins or go snorkeling in one of the most perfect places to do so. 

 Students that have participated in past field trips created bonds that have lasted through their lifetime. Some of them have gone on to attend colleges and universities that were visited and decided what their career path will be, and are pursuing their dreams.  

Giving to the MDA helps children that impacted by nueromuscular disease through funding research and providing needed services.

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes the timing is off and you can't contribute to something you want to, like assisting students expanding their world view. We have been there and understand, But you might know someone else that can give $5.00  or $10.00 toward the trip. If the students can get 1000 people to contribute $10.00 each their trip(s) will be paid for.

Please share this campaign with others so the students can go on this field trip and can give to the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

If the students can get 1000 people to contribute $10.00 each their trip(s) will be paid for.Please share this campaign with others so the students can go on this field trip and can give to the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

story:
What We're Doing

We're on a mission to make arts education accessible to primary and secondary students around the globe, and we've come up with a viable solution that makes arts education both accessible to students and cost-effective for administrators. 


We're creating a powerful online platform that will allow members to access a complete arts curriculum for primary and secondary students delivered through interactive and engaging 20-minute video classes, which come with guides and lesson-based activities for a full 50-minute learning session. Video classes will be ideal for group instruction and can be led by instructional coaches. No prior arts education or experience are be necessary, and every lesson will meet nationally accepted standards for the arts. Our institutional and individual membership fees will be extremely affordable for public, private, charter, and virtual schools as well as for homeschoolers or after-school facilities. Schools will be able to use our video classes as their primary arts curriculum or as a supplemental resource for their existing program.


What We've Done

Find out what school administrators are saying about World Upside Down's video classes after sixty-one students in the Dominican Republic participated in our first beta test in 2011...

Testimonials
First Beta Test
Beta Test Stats

What We Need & What You Get

Our first fundraising campaign of $15,000 will help us create the first four video class templates as well as a basic website for membership access. Just so you can have an idea of what we're working towards, here are some Class Snippets. Remember: these are not professional produced videos, but they give you an idea of where we're headed.



Here's what you can do:

  • Give a lot or give a little--donations start at $25 and go up to $2,500+.
  • Sponsor a school - larger donations can be used to sponsor schools.
  • Sponsor a student - smaller donations can be used to sponsor students.

Here's what you get if you help us out:

  • For donations of $50 and more, you will receive a gorgeous, custom-designed World Upside Down t-shirt!

The Impact

These are just some of the ways your contribution to World Upside Down will make an impact:

  • You will help make arts education accessible to primary and secondary students around the globe.
  • You will provide arts educators with a platform to share their knowledge in a way that promotes their expertise on a global level and helps promote their services in their own local community. 
  • You will provide schools who cannot afford to hire arts educators with a complete curriculum that instructional coaches can facilitate. No prior experience is necessary.
  • Scholarships will be available for individuals or institutions who cannot afford our membership fees.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out about us on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube (Indiegogo's share tools make this easy).
  • Share our promotional videos and website with your friends and family.
  • If you're a teacher, a PTA member, or a parent who values arts education, talk to your school administrator about getting World Upside Down in your school.

story:
Who Are We:

We are the North Hollywood High School Cross Country team, located in Los Angeles.  We have a great group of hard working athletes, who range from experienced to complete novices.  It is our goal to put together the best team we possibly can.

Unfortunately, Los Angeles Unified School District does not provide any funding for our team.  Our volunteer coach pays all of the team’s expenses out of his own pocket.  This includes race registration fees, limited uniforms, a canopy and post-race water.

The team is composed of a spirited group of individuals.  All of our running is done on city streets.  Occasionally when our school’s football team looks the other way, we are able to run on our ancient sand track.  What we don’t have in terms of the perks of other teams in our league, we make up for in determination.


What We Need:

We need $1,300 to reimburse our coach for the expenses he has so far paid for this season’s team, as well as pay for various future expenses through the completion of our Fall 2013 season.  This will include purchasing more uniforms (currently our entrants in early morning races have to give their uniforms to teammates to re-wear in later races).  We’d like to buy a second sun canopy so we don’t all have to stand underneath our current single 10'x10', as well as a school banner to hang from it.  Finally, we’d like to give out trophies at the end of the season to a few of our senior runners.

We also need to pay registration fees for this season’s remaining invitational races:

  •  Oct 25 – Mt. Sac Inv. in Walnut, CA
  •  Nov 7 – League Finals at Pierce College in Reseda, CA
  •  Nov 23 – City Finals at Pierce College
  •  Nov 30 – CA State Finals in Fresno, CA


How You Can Help:

Even small donations make an enormous difference!  We are truly grateful for any donation!  As extra thanks, every donator of over $50 will receive a signed photo of our team.  In addition, that donator will be “adopted” by a member of our team and will receive updates on personal and team progress and results.

Any funds received above our necessary amount will be used to begin the funding of next year’s team. 

Cross country running is a sport that can dramatically affect the lives of its participants, as alumni of the sport will attest.  It strengthens will and determination, and teaches goal-setting.  Thank you to everyone who supports us!

story:
Short Summary

Wally and Zavy's Autistic Kids Can Do {W&Z} is a provider of compelling specialized educational and recreational services to Autistic and Special Needs Children between 5-21 years of age.:

  • Taleana Williams Hurst is the Founder of W&Z and the proud mother of a child with Autism.
  • This Campaign is important because it highlights the "Unlimited Potential of Special Needs Children.
  • This Campaign has "Transformational Value". We will change negative mindsests and opinions about Special Needs Children  one child at a time.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

The Unlimited Possibilities Campaign is Raising One Hundred Thousand Dollars:

  • The Funds we are raising will fund recreational after school and weekend programs for Special Needs Kids in the Central New Jersey Area.
  • We will provide each contributor with Branded W&Z Merchandise including Bracelets, T-Shirts and Tote Bags!

The Impact

  • Wally and Zavy's will offer Next Level Services in Central New Jersey.
  • Wally and Zavy's will partner with institutions like Rutgers University to increase its reach and Impact.
  • Wally and Zavy's will partner with Borad's of Education in Elementary and High Schools in the Central Jersey area to provide access to more children .

Risks & Challenges

  • Wally and Zavy's is a real life story which demonstrates the power and possibility of what one convicted and passionate parent can achieve.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our story with your friends and family. Our Victory is Your Victory!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Josh Hancock, I am currently studying Architecture at Cardiff University and have recently been offered the chance to support the build of a charitable school in a town called Kenema, in eastern Sierra Leone. In order to fund this trip I am going to cycle from London (Kensington) to Cardiff (City Centre), a distance of 182 miles, hopefully within two days. 

By contributing to my cause I will be able to engage with and support a very underprivileged community in a less fortunate part of the world. I will primarily be involved with designing and building the school's furniture and will also help the finishing elements of the school's design.

I will be part of a group of Architecture students from my University, led by Architectural professionals from varying universities in the UK. I will be working for an organisation called Orkidstudio, who are a non-profit humanitarian architecture design studio whose focus is to benefit young people and communities worldwide through innovative, responsive and sustainable design and construction.

http://www.orkidstudio.co.uk/projects/5/

"We believe that creativity has the power to inspire and instill pride within people regardless of race, nationality or circumstance and our aim is to explore the potential of architecture as a tool for relieving poverty and those affected by conflict or natural disaster" - Orkidstudio.


By cycling almost 200 miles I hope to raise the best part of £1000, which will go towards flights and additional transport to Kenema and back. The money will also fund my accommodation in Africa, and required vaccinations and visas that are necessary for the trip. 

My attributes and hard-work in Kenema will help produce innovative and very responsive design solutions that will be cheap and efficient to build, yet extremely helpful for the community in question. I will be personally working with a local carpenter, aged 76, to decide on suitable characteristics and materials for the school's furniture. I will provide drawing skills and varying drawing media to facilitate the communities needs in the best way possible, and reflect these across the school.

Furthermore, I will be involved with the task of organising and delivering a dinner and film event directed at the local community, which displays and further explores the potential of Architecture bringing people together.

I am very grateful to you for reading my pitch and thank you kindly if you choose to donate. However if you choose not to, for whatever reason, please post my campaign to your family, friends and colleagues by using the Indiegogo share tools.

Kind Regards

Josh Hancock

story:
Becoming Yogini

Hey there! My name is Amanda Pagniello - I am a community activist, writer, and artist living in the Pittsburgh city. Over this past year I have recovered and come out of many trials and have successfully put myself on a healthy path through friendship, becoming and being an active individual in my community, active in my own development, and active in my body through Yoga. Yoga changed my life, gave me more balance, and made me happier and healthier. I want to share this with people by teaching others the way of yoga.

What I Need & What You Get

How can you help share the beautiful gift of Yoga? By helping me get through 200 hours of teacher training where I can learn the different techniques, the healthy lifestyle, training sequencing, anatomy, and more. By this education and getting a certificate I am able to gain empowerment through regular employment doing something I love that benefits others. To teach others what it can do for them, and better the well being of individuals, and my community, as a whole. You would be helping that! How great would that feel?!

The Impact

I am just an individual, and yes, this is for my own education so I can live a dream career- however, as I have expressed, it's not just about me...

  • I pledge to share the generosity and commit to free community classes and out reach work on the regular when my training is done. And not just Yoga, but whole health and spiritual wellness, as well. It's not just exercise, it's way more.

Giving is Receiving

Can't donate financially but want to contribute? Then share this campaign with others! Sure enough maybe someone you know can. Want to contribute in another way? Do yourself a solid and start taking yoga, even if it's just a couple of classes. Yes, I am serious. It changed my life, it can change yours!

Reaching Goals - Complete Funding

What will I do if I don't get complete funding? I have opted to flexible funding- if you don't know the Indiegogo system, it means I will get to keep any funding I get. If I don't reach my goal through this platform of crowd funding, I will finish funding it through my own means of saving a little at a time.

All the funds will go into a savings account where they will sit until I can reach my goal to pay for the training. Why $2999? - That is the cost of the Himalayan Institute, my ideal school. If needed, I will choose a more affordable program that leads to a certification. The programs I have researched all come out to or slightly over $2000. A certification is a certification after all, and I will be grateful for my education no matter where it comes from.


Open Perks!

Want to donate an different amount than any listed through the perks? Contact me directly. Want to donate and gift the perk? Yoga is a great present! Want to work out a set number of private classes, health sessions, training, or have me for a specific event or party? We can work out the details! Send me your idea, and your contribution amount, and let's work it out!
