story:
Get Ready to Rock the Block!

We're the Corner Health Center's Youth Leadership Council. In case you haven't heard, the Corner is a super amazing nonprofit teen health center located in downtown Ypsilanti, MI. We help the Corner make sure their services and programs best meet the needs of young people. This is why we are planning Rock the Block, the Corner's annual community block party which is taking place on September 13th!

Above: Rock the Block draws 400 youth and families to downtown Ypsi!

We often hear from our peers that there is nothing to do in Ypsilanti. Sometimes we feel that way too and that is why we love Rock the Block! Not only does Rock the Block give us something fun to do on a Saturday afternoon, it also connects us to incredible programs and services for teens in Ypsilanti. Programs like fitness classes at the Corner Health Center, career training at Ozone House, and after school tutoring at Mentor2Youth are just some great examples!

Above: Guests picked up free swag at Rock the Block 2013 and learned about services available to youth and families.

Your support will help to ensure that young people (and their families) know that Ypsilanti is a place where they will be supported, encouraged, celebrated, and inspired.

Your Support = 1 Cool Block Party + Gifts + Shout Outs!

The more fun we offer, the more teens we reach! Help us make sure lots of teens and families get connected to the awesome services and programs available to them in our community. Every cent we raise will directly support Rock the Block activities, like food, prizes, contests, and more! Your support helps us keep the Rock the Block free for the 400+ teens and families who attend. 

Above: A youth participant at Rock the Block 2013 shows her excitement after winning an iPod touch!

Take a look at what you will get for your support:

  • $25 = Supporter: Get a Corner Health Center "Here 4 YOUth" sticker.
  • $50 = Super Fan: Get a Corner Health Center "Here 4 YOUth" t-shirt.
  • $75 = Prize Sponsor: Sponsor our giveaways (movie passes and gift cards) and we'll display your name or your organization's name/logo on the prize table! We'll also send virtual hugs your way via social media and our annual donor honor roll.
  • $150 = Photographer Sponsor: Sponsor our event photographer and get your own portrait taken at Rock the Block! We'll email you copies of your digital pics. We'll also send virtual hugs your way via social media and our annual donor honor roll.
  • $200 = Grand Prize Sponsor: Sponsor our grand prize giveaway of a Beats by Dr. Dre 2.0 Portable Stereo Speaker and our MC will give you or your organization a shout out when announcing the prize winners! We'll also display your name or your organization's name/logo on the prize table. Plus, we'll send virtual hugs your way via social media and our annual donor honor roll.
  • $500 = Activity Sponsor: Sponsor one of the main activities (airbrush tattoos, bungee run, etc!) at Rock the Block and we'll post you or your organization's name/logo on signage next to the activity. We'll also send virtual hugs your way via social media and our annual donor honor roll.
  • $750 = Rock Climbing Wall Sponsor: Sponsor the most exciting activity at Rock the Block and we'll post you or your organization's name/logo on signage next to the activity! You'll receive a shout-out by our MC during the event, and we'll send you a personalized thank-you video which you can share with your networks. We'll also send virtual hugs your way via social media and our annual donor honor roll.
  • $1,000 = Food Truck Sponsor: Sponsor the food truck and we'll post you or your organization's name/logo on signage next to the activity. You'll receive shout-outs every hour by our MC during the event, and we'll send you a personalized thank-you video which you can share with your networks. We'll also send virtual hugs your way via social media, our annual donor honor roll, and our e-newsletter!

Above: Teens race each other on the bungee run challenge!

Get Involved!

Can't give $$ this year? No prob. There are lots of ways you can still support Rock the Block!

  • Click here to sign-up as a Rock the Block volunteer.
  • Get the word out and make some noise about Rock the Block! Email Monique (mselimos@cornerhealth.org) for Rock the Block promotional materials.
  • Share this campaign with your networks on facebook or twitter!
  • Attend Rock the Block! Come to the Corner Health Center (47 N. Huron Street in downtown Ypsilanti) on Saturday, September 13th between 2 - 5 p.m. to get your free event pass!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Ryan.
And I'm in need of some rent money.
I moved to Out of home yearly this year to study at uni, and have been looking for a job for a good 9 months now, without success. And if someone can get funding to make potato salad, then why can't I get some funding for something that actually matters.

What We Need & What You Get

  • This months rent will cost $1,607. 
  • I'm studying screen and VFX media, and have a chance to work on some brilliant films in the future, but without your help - I might not be able to stay at at uni, in order to work on your next favorite blockbuster film
  • I'm really committed to rent, so even if I don't reach the goal, all money will still go towards towards next months rent

Risks & Challenges

  • If I don't make next months rent I'll no longer be able to stay at uni, as I'll have nowhere to live
  • The only way to overcome this challenge, is for people to send me money. Or harass the manager at EB games so he gives me a job, as my persistence over he last 7 months hasn't been effective

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You don't have to send money to help out, be sure to spread the word - I really appreciate it!

story:
Help us to stay connected and learn more!

After just one year the principal of our school decided to change following:

  • Our teacher (usually class has same teacher for 4 years).
  • Our class, we would not have our own.
  • Our educational habits - joined classes with our peers from 2.B. class.
  • Our routine - moving between floors and classes on different subjects.

We thinks it is too much changes for kids age of (7-8 years) and we decided to fight at least for our own class and own teacher for one of the key subjects (prvouka - Fundaments of civics and natural science).

What We Need & What You Get

  • If we raise $2,000 the kids will have their own teacher for subject "Prvouka".
  • If we raise $8,000 the kids will have own teacher for all their subjects.
Together with kids we offered unique perks for your support and your contributions. You can visit us and enjoy our hospitality. If you are a fan of Battle of Austerlitz you can visit us at the time of the Battle re-enactment at 29 Nov 2014. 

    The Impact

    Our goal is to gain your support for our idea of tailored education for youngest kids.  

    Risks & Challenges

    After few rounds of negotiations, the principal promised to accept at least few of our requirements.  Public school in Czech Republic are funded partially from state funds and municipal funds. Probably for village school (such as ours) it is more difficult to have desired number of pupils (i.e. optimize budgets). Thus we need to collect funds to support our ideas.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute and you still like our ideas you can help by:

    • Make some noise about our campaign.
    • Share our campaign with your friends.
    • Message us your ideas or experience.

    Thank you very much! Kids from 2.A.

story:
My name is Deborah DeLisle and I have lived in the small rural mountain town of Hot Springs, NC since 1997.  As a mother of three I became intimately aware of the lack of services available for young families and set forth to prepare a survey of the needs of families in the town.  I then organized a community town meeting to review the results and brainstorm solutions.  From that meeting we gathered that preschool, after school, out of school care, nutrition, and home school support were areas of greatest concern and need.  It was decided that I would pursue the directorship of opening a non-profit, licensed child care facility with the help of a key group of persons with personal interest in the well-being our of children.  We opened (non-profit) Hot Springs Community Learning Center in September of 2008.

The families came and our staff was ready!  We took the liberties of designing our curriculum with a community focus.  In addition to our developmentally appropriate practices for acedemic support, once per week a community visitor comes and shares a talent with us.  We go on field trips that bring our themes together and residents often volunteer on a regular basis for 1:1 tutoring.  We are always learning and laughing and doing and learning some more!  Quickly, we achieved a 5 star rating from the state.

However, one year into the project we experienced the massive cuts to education and child care programs and immediately began our own Community Scholarship Program.  We help families raise the funds needed to stay enrolled through community events like the annual Trailfest, Appalachian Heritage Festival, French Broad River Festival Kids Village, 5K Runs, and of course Bingo and Bake Sales!  We have teamed up with our local businesses and churches, but there are always more children to serve than costs to do so. 

The best part about our program though is that it is a 'give and take' style agenda.  We raise funds and the parents perform the maintenance tasks that help our Center run smoothly.  They earn 'credits' towards their tuition and HSCLC in turn does not have to pay out the maintenance costs for hauling trash, mowing the lawn, doing the sheets, and cleaning the facility.  Everyone wins, especially the children. 

Each year we run an annual Pledge Drive from August 1st - the 15th to help secure the amount of money we can promise out for the school year.  It is estimated that we will need $4000 to help our families in need to fund the out of school care expenses this coming school year.  

Good for YOU

Since Hot Springs is such a sweet little destination vacation place (and because our town is so supportive of its local Learning Center) we are prepared to offer 'perks' for supporting us this year:  Soak in the natural mineral spring water hot tubs along the French Broad River, get a free pass to the annual French Broad River Fall Festival, or stay 2 nights in a cozy cabin on an organic farm with natural mineral spring water hot tubs on the porch!  These kinds of perks will help you get a good sense of the kind of environment our darlings get to grow up in!

The Impact

Having been open now for four years we have actual data to support the concept that learning through doing is extremely effective.  Our students get the 1:1 help that they need from knowledgeable, professional people and they are SUCEEDING in their educational endeavors.  We have graduated 32 children from our Transitional Kindergarten program and are now watching them soar.  We host 48 amazing children in the 5 - 12 year old age range with after school and summer camps and witness them use problem solving skills to navigate issues while earning one award after another in their classrooms.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute money, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

We have started our own thrift store called Community Thrift, so shopping and/or providing gently used items are a great way to help us generate funds while providing a great community service of having affordable goods for sale.  We take used books, clothes, housewares, toys, etc. every day of the week except Sunday.

 

Also, most everyone has something that they are good at, so we are always inviting people over to share their skill or talent with the children.  This expands their thinking and makes them smarter!  We'd love to learn something from you.

 

Another great way to contribute is to help us with our 1:1 tutoring sessions.  Retired teachers and clergy are great candidates for this. 

 

Please feel free to visit our web site and learn more about Hot Springs Community Learning Center and supporting this community is good for the environment > even yours!

story:
Short Summary

Dr Abiodun Jonathan was a Pediatrician and pastor before his life was suddenly and violently cut short in the ill-fated Dana Airline on June 3, 2012. His widow, Funmi is now saddled with the task of raising their three kids as a single mother. Before his death Dr Jonathan worked as a neonatologist taking care neonates in a fertility center in Abuja, Nigeria and as a the Central Pediatric Advisor at International Centre For Aids Care And Treatment Program, ICAP.

Those who know him know how passionate he was about the wellbeing of other people’s children and how much he invested in this. Now his kids are without their breadwinner and at a risk of falling short of their maximum potential.

Biodun was a very close friend of mine and I felt moved to do something for him to smile over in his grave. At least he would'nt have to worry that the family he left behind would go through difficult times because of his untimely death.

Please join me to raise an endowment fund that will be used to fund Abiodun Jonathan’s children’s education. The funds raised will be invested in a mutual fund in the name of the children.

I also plan to make a book of rememberance for him ...the least i could do to keep his loving memory alive!

Thank you for your support

 

http://abiodun-jonathan.last-memories.com/gallery

http://news2.onlinenigeria.com/photos-of-dana-airlines-crash-victims-in-nigeria/168667-dr-abiodun-jonathan.html

http://ca.news.yahoo.com/video/world-22186928/nigeria-mourns-air-crash-dead-29547103.html#crsl=%252Fvideo%252Fworld-22186928%252Fnigeria-mourns-air-crash-dead-29547103.html
story_txt:
Short Summary
Dr Abiodun Jonathan was a Pediatrician and pastor before his life was suddenly and violently cut short in the ill-fated Dana Airline on June 3, 2012. His widow, Funmi is now saddled with the task of raising their three kids as a single mother. Before his death Dr Jonathan worked as a neonatologist taking care neonates in a fertility center in Abuja, Nigeria and as a the Central Pediatric Advisor at International Centre For Aids Care And Treatment Program, ICAP.
Those who know him know how passionate he was about the wellbeing of other people’s children and how much he invested in this. Now his kids are without their breadwinner and at a risk of falling short of their maximum potential.
Biodun was a very close friend of mine and I felt moved to do something for him to smile over in his grave. At least he would'nt have to worry that the family he left behind would go through difficult times because of his untimely death.
Please join me to raise an endowment fund that will be used to fund Abiodun Jonathan’s children’s education. The funds raised will be invested in a mutual fund in the name of the children.
I also plan to make a book of rememberance for him ...the least i could do to keep his loving memory alive!
Thank you for your support
 
http://abiodun-jonathan.last-memories.com/gallery
http://news2.onlinenigeria.com/photos-of-dana-airlines-crash-victims-in-nigeria/168667-dr-abiodun-jonathan.html
http://ca.news.yahoo.com/video/world-22186928/nigeria-mourns-air-crash-dead-29547103.html#crsl=%252Fvideo%252Fworld-22186928%252Fnigeria-mourns-air-crash-dead-29547103.html

story:
Our Story

We are Kids for Kenya, a group of students from Rosedale Heights School of the Arts. We are working with Free the Children to build a school in Kenya because we want to give children there a brighter future. Education can empower children and entire communities to break the cycle of poverty for future generations. Our group is fundraising money to buy school supplies, uniforms, building materials and other necessities for the community. 

The Impact

A group of approximately 15 of us are going to Kenya this March to build a school in the Maasai Mara region. Maasailand has the highest primary school dropout rate in Kenya due to poor educational facilities, health issues, lack of education and because their family needs them at home. Kenya is considered to be the "promise land" of Africa, as it has the most potential to be the first independent country in the continent. We can aid Kenya in becoming a model country for the rest of Africa to follow. 


As students from an arts school in addition to getting our hands dirty by actually helping to build the school, we would also like to learn about the culture of the Maasai people. We want to bring back handmade beads to work with, some art pieces to share and a new dance style and technique to show our peers. We want to learn all we can, so that when we return we can share what we learned with those who weren't able to join us on this trip.


This will be a life changing experience and we are ecstatic to have the opportunity to travel to Kenya to build a school. After the trip we will return and continue working with Free the Children to rid the world of poverty and stop the exploitation of children. We will share our experiences and spread the word, encouraging everyone to join us and the Me to We community to make a difference in the world.


What We Need & What You Get

Our group has been raising funds in various ways, but it is an expensive trip and we are going to need as much help as possible from everyone. So if you can help us in any way to reach our goal of $ 6,000 it would be greatly appreciated. We would like to thank you in advance for all your support in our efforts to make the world a better place.


Note: to all our Canadian friends - donation amounts are listed in USD.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to support us, but are unable to assist us by contributing money, please send this link around and you can help us get the word out by following us on Twitter and liking us on Facebook. 
Thank you so much!

story:
What’s the goal?

Raise $3,800 to send my Ghanaian friend Jey to the University of Ghana for 3 years so that he can earn his bachelor’s degree in Afforestation (the conservation and reintroduction of plant life in barren areas).

 

Who is Jey?

Jey is a 28-year-old Ghanaian man who lives in Accra.  His father passed away when he was 9 and he grew up in a single mother household, polishing shoes on the street until he was 16 to help support his family.  He made it all the way through high school (earning good grades), but was unable to continue into college because of a lack of funds.  He’s smart, caring, good-natured, and passionate about education.  Right now, Jey lives hand-to-mouth selling handmade bracelets and necklaces to tourists who stay at or near The Rising Phoenix Hotel. 

 

Where does your Money Go?

  1. Jey’s Tuition & Housing Costs for 3 Years
  2. 3 annual allowances for Jey to purchase books, school supplies, new clothes, and cover basic needs
  3. Printing & Shipping costs for ‘Wisdom’ Tees

 

About the Traveler...

Hi!  My name is Justin Dart and I’m a soon-to-be senior business student at the University of Colorado.  A little over a month ago, I set foot off the MV Explorer in San Diego having completed a Semester at Sea and traveled through 11 different countries.  It was the most challenging and intense (not to mention fast-paced) environment I’ve ever been in.  I’ve never felt so many high highs and so many humbling lows in just over 100 days.  I’ve come out of SAS more sure of who I am and the kind of person that I wish to become than I’ve ever been in my life.  For these reasons and the fact that I got an opportunity to take a voyage like that, I am incredibly blessed.  Thank you for taking a look at ‘Teach a Man,’ I hope you like what you see.

 

About the Program

SAS is a nonprofit program run by The Institute of Shipboard Education that recruits college students from all over the world and sends them on a circumnavigation of the globe aboard the MV Explorer (our traveling campus) twice a year.  We took classes full-time on the ship and traveled in country at each new port.  Simply put, “the world is our classroom.”  The spring 2012 voyage journeyed to:

  • Nassau, Bahamas
  • Rosseau, Dominica
  • Manaus, Brazil
  • Tema, Ghana
  • Cape Town, South Africa
  • Port Louis, Mauritius
  • Cochin, India
  • Singapore
  • Saigon, Vietnam
  • Hong Kong
  • Shanghai, China
  • Kobe, Japan
  • Yokohama, Japan
  • Hilo, Hawaii

 

‘Teach a Man: Wisdom’ T-Shirts

When I designed this shirt, I wanted a purpose-oriented Tee that people would actually want to wear.  I started with a high quality Anvil Sustainable product that’s comfortably soft, cut in a flattering shape, and will stand up to years of wear.  Details include:

  • 50% Organic Cotton & 50% Post-Consumer Recycled Polyester
  • Ultra smooth, lightweight Fabric
  • Pre-shrunk
  • Tear-away Neck Tag for Comfort
  • Available in Sizes S through 3XL
  • Note: Typically runs small (for sizing info visit: http://www.customink.com/items/sizing/166200_lineup/standard.htm)

 

What happens if we exceed $3800?

Until the time meter runs out, we can continue to raise funds above and beyond the current goal.  Meaning, if you still want a ‘Wisdom Tee’ (or any other perk) or just care to support the cause, please go ahead and do so.  Here’s what I have in mind in case this happens:

  1. Jey gets several new sets of nice clothing for school.  There’s a reason you only see him in that lime green Tee (those pictures came from multiple days).  Attending the sociology lecture, I was blown away with how well students dress for class (polo’s, button-down shirts, skirts, dresses, and so on).  Compared to us casual Boulder students, our Ghanaian counterparts dress REALLY nicely.
  2. Depending on housing costs, I’ll help Jey look into renting an apartment in Accra for when he’s on summer and winter break.  What I didn’t mention in the video is that Jey currently sleeps on a covered bench outside the Rising Phoenix Hotel.  He uses a tarp for a blanket and wears long-sleeve clothing to avoid mosquitoes and getting malaria during the night.  He very much lives hand-to-mouth...at least for now.
  3. If the funds allow, I’d like to purchase a laptop for Jey.  Not necessarily a high-end or brand new model, just something that he can complete schoolwork on and send email to all of his supporters in the US.  He needs something that’ll last for at least three years.  And I know for a fact, this would be the first major possession he could call his own.
  4. Other than that, you decide!  I’m certainly flexible in where additional support goes.  I’d love to hear any ideas you might have.


FAQ’s

  1. You said you keep in touch with Jey through email.  Does he have a computer?
    • The first time I was asked this question, I had to ask Jey myself because I really didn’t know the answer.  No, he doesn’t have a computer.  Like many in Accra, Jey just doesn’t have the money to afford one.  Instead, he goes to public computer terminals and pays 80 peswes (about 41 cents) for each hour of use.
  2. Can you donate in other currencies besides USD?
    • Yes, absolutely!  Indiegogo will take payment in most currency forms, but your donation will need to be equivalent to the dollar amount of the perk you choose.  For instance, if you wish to recieve one of Jey's bracelets ($100), you'll need to donate something like 80 euros or 5,729 Indian Rupees.  Thanks to all our international sponsors.
  3. What percentage of T-shirt funds go to supporting Jey?
    • Each ‘Wisdom’ shirt sold generates right around $10 US for Jey’s education.  Unfortunately because of printing and shipping costs, I wasn’t able to negotiate a better margin without sacrificing product quality.  If you’re interested in helping Jey more (and still getting a Tee), I suggest looking at the other levels of contribution as they yield more to the ‘Teach a Man’ fund.
  4. How are you getting Jey enrolled?
    • I’m currently in touch with Professor Kofi Adjei at the University of Ghana and despite his busy schedule, he’s offered to help in whatever ways he can to get Jey started.  So far, he’s given advice on how to pay the University and process that Jey must undergo to become enrolled.
  5. Do you have any other contacts in Ghana helping with this?
    • Yes, actually.  Not too long ago, I received an email from a Dutch volunteer, Jurriaan de Jong, who’s currently serving a 10-week stay in Ghana.  Jey put me in touch with Jurriaan in hopes that he could help me with this project.  We’ve emailed back and forth a few times and I’m thrilled to have someone actually in Ghana that can lend a hand if necessary.
  6. Where did you get all those photos in the video?
    • All but the T-Shirt pic came from my camera.  No Google Images on this one.  What you saw in the video is what my friends and I experienced.

 

Cheers & Thank You

On behalf of Jey, Jurriaan, Prof Adjei, and myself, I’d like to say thank you for your support.  It means the world to me that I have friends, family, and friends-of-friends to call on for something like this.  I know for a fact that it certainly means the world to Jey.  I believe we have the power to change the world every single day; we just need to start small.  For today, let’s teach a man...

story:
Welcome to my campaign! This is a campaign not just about dollars, but of building a fan base that will take this journey of basketball with me. For many players the goal of the NBA is the ultimate goal. For me, the goal is to continue to play, travel the world and incorporate my education into the ultimate goal of putting forth a positive image of the game to fans all over the world.

Since I graduated from college in 2010, I’ve continued to train and grow as a player. I got the chance to play in Europe last fall with an exhibition team and was selected for my first pro team as a rookie in the PBL. Immediately after the season, I continued my training and this summer I am attending camps so that I can try and secure a new team because my first team folded before the official season ended. I am utilizing my earnings for training, camps and travel already, but the more camps I attend and the more training I receive, the more chances I have to secure a team. Camps range from $175.00 to $500.00. I am attending several camps that have already been paid for. Also, while I pay for my gym membership myself, personal training is an additional expense. Finally, you need video of your games. As you know, putting your work on sites like YouTube and Vimeo is helping people from all walks of life to secure jobs and showcase their talents. You can spend up to $500.00 for a great highlight tape. I’m looking to offset those costs.

I am also looking for people to join “Team Mike Troll” and help me develop my fan base. There are perks for financial support but I hope that people who can’t support my campaign financially will still be a part of “Team Mike Troll” and help me spread the word about my journey!  I want fans of all ages to join me. I need you! If there are companies who are looking for a model for your sports branding, I’m your man! I have a background as a professional model. I am a member of SAG/AFTRA in good standing. I look forward to lending my talents to your vision! I’m looking forward to your support for this campaign and in the future. Thanks!  

Here are some links to show you where I’ve been in the process and where I plan to go! I hope you will join me! Check the box for email updates on the donation page!

http://www.proplayervideo.com/playerinfo.php?action=profile&id=349121

http://vimeo.com/10293913

http://vimeo.com/6778884

http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/19063400 (Mike Troll #20 in this film)

story:
Summers without reading hurt kids  

  • Kids who don't read over the summer lose what they've already learned. Not fair! 
  • Kids who do read over the summer stay on grade level or improve.
  • 60% of the kids we will reach this summer have no books at home.
  • You + $2 + 8,900 libraries = 2 Million Summers Saved

We know how to get this done. For the past three years, we've been helping all the kids in Kentucky public elementary schools learn to love reading with a cool little magazine called The Fit4Fun Reader.  Now we're ready to take our proven science nationwide!

We've already signed up authors, publishers, printers, distributors and libraries, to get this done for just $2 per child.

Image Courtesy of the National Center of Educational Statistics

We've partnered with all 8,900 public libraries nationwide, and some amazing children's book authors, to create a special publication that contains whole books, poems, creative pages, jokes and a lot of other fun stuff. The special Fit4Fun Summer Reader promises to make summer fun while preventing the dreaded "summer slide" back off grade level.

As publishers, we've been able to make this program a reality at an incredibly low cost: just $2 per child. The nationwide Collaborative Summer Library Program has agreed to serve as the distributors and program directors at public libraries nationwide.

NOW, all we really need is YOU. For every TWO dollars we raise here, another child will be served. Could your family take this on as a service project? Could your team make it happen for kids who don't have books? Could your company make a library's worth of kids' summer reading dream come true?

There's more information here: www.twomillionsummers.com

Live Events will include soccer pro, cancer warrior and “Survivor:Africa” winner Ethan Zohn reading his children’s book (included in the Summer Reader) and hosting Digital Read-Alongs, and Dr. “Patch” Adams will talk to families about how important happiness is to health. 

The content themes of the five books include playing/creating games, healthy learning, teamwork, sportsmanship, entrepreneurship. The books seek to foster reading, critical thinking, future thinking, creativity and curiosity. Once you join our cause, you'll get updates about the books we will include in the Summer Reader, live events where you are invited and other exciting details!

WHO IS HELPING?

It's amazing who is already helping!

Good guys like Dr. “Patch” Adams, Survivor: Africa winner-turned-social-entrepreneur Ethan Zohn and University of Louisville Men's Soccer Head Coach Ken Lolla; the Gannett Corp.; Aviva Publishing and Nomad Press; the Collaborative Summer Library Program and public libraries nationwide, some Boys & Girls Clubs of America, some YMCAs, retail locations, and school libraries from Alaska to Florida and everywhere in between. 

And now, YOU! :)

For every two dollars you give, we can serve another child. Seriously. For the price of a cheap burger, a year's worth of learning can be saved for a child. Aren't our partners amazing? They are supporting this effort up to a run of TWO MILLION Summer Readers. Don't you want to join us? $2 = one summer saved. Let's get kids off that summer slide, now. TWO MILLION SUMMERS, saved. 

For every $2 we raise over the $10,000 goal, we can serve another child. 

Meet Some of Our Team

Publisher Janny Winter

Janny is a born mom-preneur. She saw a problem and took her 25 years of publishing experience, crossed it with her 25 years being a mom and created a magazine for kids that lights up their imagination, their sense of a positive future and a strong drive for self-responsibility. She founded Wordsworth Publishing to address the fact that schools really don't teach health any more. And they never really have taught creativity, curiosity or critical thinking. The Fit4Fun Reader leaps over broken systems to get directly to kids and plant the seeds of a successful life. Over the past four years Janny has grown an international network of friends and colleagues who believe in Fit4Fun and in kids. 

Co-founder Mae Marks

Mae is on our Dream Team for a reason - she is a tireless, hilarious, dedicated young idealist with a strong passion for quality. Mae represents the Fit4Fun brand in every sense and at every opportunity. She is a designer, a developer, a dreamer and a do-er. She suggested and is running this Indiegogo campaign to tell the world about all the cool stuff we are doing for families. 

Sales Director Nick Maxim

We spend every day seeking new partners, collaborators and friends, with Nick at the top of managing that list. A young dad who reads to his kids daily, Nick knows that these early experiences are the most meaningful. He is super fun to work with and enjoys knowing our work makes a difference.

Artist Eddie Sun

Every image in every Fit4Fun Reader comes from the mind and heart of our artist, Eddie Sun. He brings to life our characters in hilarious, compelling new ways in every edition. A father of three young children, Eddie is dedicated to giving all kids the kind of fun with the Reader his own kids enjoy. 

Writer Robbin Goodin

Robbin is the teacher on our team, the one who helps us understand how to help teachers and parents connect with their child's learning via the Fit4Fun Reader. She's also the kind of mom every kid needs.

Besides these key players, our advisory team includes brilliant educators, researchers, parents, teachers, and kids. We'd love to hear from you, too!


HOW CAN I HELP? Because this is awesome.

This party is officially moving and grooving people! Now that the money is rolling in, don't you want to be a part of this AWESOME project? Here are ways you can HELP:

1) Donate if you can. Remember every $2 is another summer saved!

2) Share us with your friends! Be our friend on Facebook.com/MyFit4Fun, Tweet us on Twitter @MyFit4Fun, Show us your pics on Instagram @MyFit4Fun, or Pin us with your summer reading ideas on Pintrest @MyFit4Fun!

3) Read to the important kids in your life. At the end of the day, Two Million Summers is about getting kids and families connected to reading. Showing them how reading can be FUN!
story_txt:
Summers without reading hurt kids  
Kids who don't read over the summer lose what they've already learned. Not fair! 
Kids who do read over the summer stay on grade level or improve.

60% of the kids we will reach this summer have no books at home.
You + $2 + 8,900 libraries = 2 Million Summers Saved

We know how to get this done. For the past three years, we've been helping all the kids in Kentucky public elementary schools learn to love reading with a cool little magazine called The Fit4Fun Reader.  Now we're ready to take our proven science nationwide!We've already signed up authors, publishers, printers, distributors and libraries, to get this done for just $2 per child.Image Courtesy of the National Center of Educational Statistics
We've partnered with all 8,900 public libraries nationwide, and some amazing children's book authors, to create a special publication that contains whole books, poems, creative pages, jokes and a lot of other fun stuff. The special Fit4Fun Summer Reader promises to make summer fun while preventing the dreaded "summer slide" back off grade level.
As publishers, we've been able to make this program a reality at an incredibly low cost: just $2 per child. The nationwide Collaborative Summer Library Program has agreed to serve as the distributors and program directors at public libraries nationwide.NOW, all we really need is YOU. For every TWO dollars we raise here, another child will be served. Could your family take this on as a service project? Could your team make it happen for kids who don't have books? Could your company make a library's worth of kids' summer reading dream come true?There's more information here: www.twomillionsummers.comLive Events will include soccer pro, cancer warrior and “Survivor:Africa” winner Ethan Zohn reading his children’s book (included in the Summer Reader) and hosting Digital Read-Alongs, and Dr. “Patch” Adams will talk to families about how important happiness is to health. The content themes of the five books include playing/creating games, healthy learning, teamwork, sportsmanship, entrepreneurship. The books seek to foster reading, critical thinking, future thinking, creativity and curiosity. Once you join our cause, you'll get updates about the books we will include in the Summer Reader, live events where you are invited and other exciting details!WHO IS HELPING?It's amazing who is already helping!Good guys like Dr. “Patch” Adams, Survivor: Africa winner-turned-social-entrepreneur Ethan Zohn and University of Louisville Men's Soccer Head Coach Ken Lolla; the Gannett Corp.; Aviva Publishing and Nomad Press; the Collaborative Summer Library Program and public libraries nationwide, some Boys & Girls Clubs of America, some YMCAs, retail locations, and school libraries from Alaska to Florida and everywhere in between. And now, YOU! :)For every two dollars you give, we can serve another child. Seriously. For the price of a cheap burger, a year's worth of learning can be saved for a child. Aren't our partners amazing? They are supporting this effort up to a run of TWO MILLION Summer Readers. Don't you want to join us? $2 = one summer saved. Let's get kids off that summer slide, now. TWO MILLION SUMMERS, saved. For every $2 we raise over the $10,000 goal, we can serve another child. Meet Some of Our TeamPublisher Janny WinterJanny is a born mom-preneur. She saw a problem and took her 25 years of publishing experience, crossed it with her 25 years being a mom and created a magazine for kids that lights up their imagination, their sense of a positive future and a strong drive for self-responsibility. She founded Wordsworth Publishing to address the fact that schools really don't teach health any more. And they never really have taught creativity, curiosity or critical thinking. The Fit4Fun Reader leaps over broken systems to get directly to kids and plant the seeds of a successful life. Over the past four years Janny has grown an international network of friends and colleagues who believe in Fit4Fun and in kids. Co-founder Mae MarksMae is on our Dream Team for a reason - she is a tireless, hilarious, dedicated young idealist with a strong passion for quality. Mae represents the Fit4Fun brand in every sense and at every opportunity. She is a designer, a developer, a dreamer and a do-er. She suggested and is running this Indiegogo campaign to tell the world about all the cool stuff we are doing for families. Sales Director Nick MaximWe spend every day seeking new partners, collaborators and friends, with Nick at the top of managing that list. A young dad who reads to his kids daily, Nick knows that these early experiences are the most meaningful. He is super fun to work with and enjoys knowing our work makes a difference.Artist Eddie SunEvery image in every Fit4Fun Reader comes from the mind and heart of our artist, Eddie Sun. He brings to life our characters in hilarious, compelling new ways in every edition. A father of three young children, Eddie is dedicated to giving all kids the kind of fun with the Reader his own kids enjoy. Writer Robbin GoodinRobbin is the teacher on our team, the one who helps us understand how to help teachers and parents connect with their child's learning via the Fit4Fun Reader. She's also the kind of mom every kid needs.Besides these key players, our advisory team includes brilliant educators, researchers, parents, teachers, and kids. We'd love to hear from you, too!HOW CAN I HELP? Because this is awesome.This party is officially moving and grooving people! Now that the money is rolling in, don't you want to be a part of this AWESOME project? Here are ways you can HELP:1) Donate if you can. Remember every $2 is another summer saved!2) Share us with your friends! Be our friend on Facebook.com/MyFit4Fun, Tweet us on Twitter @MyFit4Fun, Show us your pics on Instagram @MyFit4Fun, or Pin us with your summer reading ideas on Pintrest @MyFit4Fun!3) Read to the important kids in your life. At the end of the day, Two Million Summers is about getting kids and families connected to reading. Showing them how reading can be FUN!

story:
My Mission

Hi!  My name is Rosiris Baez and I am passionate about inspiring others to reach their full potential despite their circumstances.  I, along with 3 friends, are working with Infusionarts in order to fund six Maasai children, so that they may go to school and have meals for a full year.  We are challenging ourselves to climb Mount Kilimanjaro because we want to raise awareness about how important it is for these children to have the opportunity to receive an education and a meal.  During our trip to Tanzania, we will be holding educational workshops for the children in the Maasai village.  We will be spending time with the children in order to experience their day to day struggles and really see what a gift an education will be, not only to them but to their families and the village as well.  

 

Infusionarts

Infusionarts is a UK based organization run by Shirley Beth Newbery. Infusionarts works in both the UK and Africa. It runs community based arts courses, workshops and film projects in the UK.  In Africa, Shirley Beth raises money for micro projects, and individuals in need. Her small but trusted network of contacts there ensures that her not-for-profit activities make a significant difference for those she helps. 

In 2009, for example, Infusionarts raised the $800 needed to pay for an operation for a Maasai lady with a large goiter condition. The operation led to a full recovery and her reintegration into her community. 

Looking forward to 2014, Infusionarts is raising money to fund schooling and meals for a year for six children in Northern Tanzania. Three at primary level and three at secondary level. This will significantly enhance the lives of those six children and their families, and increase their chances of further education and a hopeful future. A future in which educated young people in Africa see their developing countries grow stronger, becoming self-sufficient and prosperous.

During our time there, we will be volunteering at the schools and supporting the children that we are affecting by holding workshops for them.  It is an amazing opportunity to be able to give the gift of education and we can't do it without you!


    Who You'll be helping

    Many families live at a subsistence level and cannot afford food, the fees or school uniform, even though they are very low by Western standards. The hope for the family's future seems to shine brighter when their children are attending school. The children are keen to learn and take pride in their place at a school. Your money will help these children and their families by giving them hope for a brighter future. The children chosen will be attending school for the first time, others may need help to continue with their education, with the hope of eventually going on to college or university and a career.  This leads to them supporting their families and communities, so you are actually investing in the future of this Maasai Village!

    Imagine having to tell your own children that they will have to stay at home because you cannot afford to send them to school. With small campaigns like this we can make a huge difference to the lives of these children and their families!   

     

    Challenges

    Because the schools and businesses are in areas we know, we can make sure the money gets to the exact point it is needed, with no large overheads/admin/endless middlemen and administration costs. Sure, you will have to trust us to ensure this happens as we intend, but isn't that also true of big charities? With Infusionarts the trail is very short! 

    In the event that we don't reach our goal of sending six children to school, we will fund as many children as we can.  If we achieve more than our target, we will fund more children to go to school this coming year!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Spread the word about our cause any way you can!

story:
Let's keep building the crowd in our crowdfunder!

Please support our campaign to create the Early Literacy Storytime Nook for the Hudson Area Library.  Help us set children on the road to success.

We are proud members of the Hudson Area Library in Hudson, New York.  In about 12 months, we will be moving from our current facility to the Hudson Armory, more than doubling the Library's size.

This new facility is coming just in time.  With studies indicating how important early literacy is,  we're thrilled to have more room to dedicate to the infants and young children in our membership area.  In case you hadn't heard, it’s important to expose the youngest children to reading.  Here’s what The New York Times said.
With the increased recognition that an important part of brain development occurs within the first three years of a child's life, and reading to children enhances vocabulary and other important communication skills, the group, which represents 62,000 pediatricians across the country, is asking its members to become powerful advocates for reading aloud, every time a baby visits a doctor.
"It should be there each time we touch bases with children," said Dr.  Pamela High, who wrote new policy.  It recommends that doctors tell parents they should be "reading together as a daily fun family activity" from infancy.  (Pediatrics Group to Recommend Reading Aloud to Children from Birth - June 24, 2014 - New York Times)

An important part of brain development occurs within the first three years of a child's life, and reading to children enhances vocabulary and other critical communications skills.

 What We Need

We are very close to our goal raise $5,000 to support our Early Literacy Storytime Nook, part of our Children’s Library area.  Your contribution will go towards furnishings in the nook - a place where our staff will hold story times for infants and preschoolers as well as a place where parents and children can read together.  Comfy chairs in both grown-up and pint-size will make the nook inviting - a perfect environment to absorb the basics of learning.  With your help, we hope to create an inviting space and bring more and more children and families into our new, expanded Hudson Area Library. The more readers, the better!


The nook is housed in the round turret of the Hudson Armory shown in this vintage rendering. It's a perfect place for imaginations to grow.

The Impact

Early Literacy has been proven to have an impact on children for the rest of their lives. Hearing words, grasping the concept of communication, and spending physical time with parents, sets these children on the road to success – a circumstance that will stay with them throughout school and into adulthood. At the Library we are eager to present an atmosphere that will contribute to that learning. And what could be better than a special room – dedicated exclusively to expanding the horizons of children?

What You Get

As with every fundraiser, our rewards are distributed across a wide range of values. They are designed to include every donor at every income level. And, like our library, we want to be all inclusive. But, if you’re thinking about contributing to a library fundraiser, you already know that learning is impossible to value. It will impact you and those around you forever. A strong education and the drive to achieve can do more than just make a smart individual. That drive can change the world.



Join Lisa Dolan, co-founder of the Hudson Children's Book Festival -- the largest festival of its kind in New York State, in her support of the Early Literacy Storytime Nook.

“Early Literacy is a crucial part of child development and can assist our youngest students in being school-ready.  When we read with our children it opens up worlds to them."– Joan E. Hunt, Project Director, Greater Hudson Promise Neighborhood

Please contribute to the Storytime Nook.  Help our children thrive.

We've been lucky enough to surpass our initial goal. Now we'll use any additional donations – up to $10,000.00,  to purchase Early Literacy computers.  Beyond $10,000.00 (!!) we’ll move on to the needs of our pre-teens.  Thanks for all the continued support.  Keep it up!


Thank you!

P.S.  Want to learn more about our campaign and our Library? Please visit www.hudsonarealibrary.org or www.armory.hudsonarealibrary.org/

story:
IM Kids 3rd Meal is a community driven, not-for-profit, kids feeding program. Entirely volunteer based, our goal is to provide ‘3rd Meal’ sack dinners to food insecure elementary students within Ionia and Montcalm counties in Michigan, USA. The 2014 school year began our pilot phase, as we successfully provided ‘3rd Meals’ to over 380 students at two different elementary schools from April to June. 

IN ORDER TO KEEP THESE KIDS FED, AND TO FURTHER EXPAND OUR PROGRAM, WE NEED YOUR HELP.

One of our schools, Walnut Hills Elementary in Greenville, Michigan

'3rd Meals' ready to be picked up by students at Emerson Elementary in Ionia, MI

Why do we need your help?

IM Kids makes 380 sack dinners a day. Every 3rd Meal is made the morning of its intended consumption and is dropped off at school in the afternoon for student pick up. Each sack dinner consists of:

  • Sandwich (PB&J or Meat/Cheese)

  • Fruit or Vegetable Serving

  • 100% Juice Box

  • Granola Bar

  • Healthy Snack


Because we use our facility for free, and because our staff is consists entirely of Americorps VISTAs and volunteers, IM Kids is without overhead costs. So: what is the main expense within IM Kids? 

                                                                    FOOD.

It costs us $2 for every 3rd Meal we make. Now, Feeding America does allow us to purchase at their warehouse for a discount rate, but costs add up quickly: feeding 380 kids, 5 days a week, 9 months a year at $2 each is very expensive!!!!

To add to our troubles, up until now, the purchasing of this food has been mostly grant-funded, with the addition of small donations made by area residents and in-house volunteers. While this was a great source of start-up funding (our start-up $50,000 food grant will run out this September), this model alone cannot possibly keep us afloat as we look to further our expansion. 

                                            HELP US BUY THESE KIDS DINNER.

How can you help?

With $10,000, we can sustain our current operation (just two schools) for the entire school year. Kids at Emerson Elementary in Ionia and Walnut Hills Elementary in Greenville will ALL have dinner… Every Five Days a Week.

With an additional $10,000, we can expand our operation further. Where have we set our sights on next? Carson City Elementary in Carson City!!!

We hope to expand to Carson City Elementary soon.


Add ANOTHER $10,000? We could buy a walk-in freezer, for long-term food storage. At this point, a freezer would be a grand luxury…. but why not dream big?

So…. to round this out, $10,000 is our middle-ground objective. As evidenced by our statistics above, we could use much more money than $10,000, but we also realize the potential to earn much less than $10,000. So we meet in the middle: No dollar will be turned away, just as no child is turned away from IM Kids.

The impact of your contribution:

Inside the area of our project’s reach (Ionia and Montcalm counties), a large number of kids regularly go hungry. Now how many kids exactly is this? 1 in 5 Ionia county kids are food insecure, and 1 in 4 Montcalm county kids are food insecure. Even more specifically, at the two elementary schools of our pilot program, (Walnut Hills and Emerson) 97% OF KIDS ARE FOOD INSECURE.

How do we know?

They…

  • Rush to food lines

  • Have extreme hunger on Monday mornings

  • Eat ALL food served at meal times.

  • Frequently ask for 2nds

  • Complain about hunger DAILY

They are…

  • Extremely thin, puffy, or swollen

  • Hyperactive, irritable, withdrawn, or aggressive

  • Often sick or absent

  • Don’t get along well with others



Want to help more?

Register to volunteer at imkids.org

SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE

                   SHARE US ON SOCIAL MEDIA. It only takes a second.

story:
The Lowdown

If you've known me for any amount of time, you know I have both a huge love for music and an obsession with God. 
Well, I've been offered the amazing opportunity to attend Bethel School of Worship, a place where I can cultivate my skills as a worship leader and learn to take my passions beyond 'singing in front of a bunch of people at church.' 
My vision for worship music is:
  • To change atmospheres and break barriers
  • To break the mold--spiritually and musically
  • Do it with excellence

Bethel School of Worship is the perfect place for me to grow my skills and learn from some of the most influential and impactful worship leaders alive today. I will also be meeting people from all over the world and country--how sweet is that! 

What I Need & What You Get

This is what I need in a little more detail:

  • $555 to complete my tuition costs
  • $500 for a plane ticket from North Carolina to Northern California
  • $180 to complete my housing costs
If I receive all these funds, I will have the opportunity to visit a place I've wanted to go for years and learn from my heroes. To thank you I've included a list of fun perks...it includes dancing in public so you might want to contribute ;) 

What this will do for my life

Beyond just being a cool opportunity, I feel so strongly about going because I believe this School is a catalyst to the next season of my life. Travis and I have both been doing music related things for a long time, but I feel like in some ways I've plateaued and it's time to take it to the next level. I believe that attending this summer will help me understand my spiritual responsibility as a leader, teach me the practical disciplines I need to reach my musical goals, instill in me an attitude of excellence in regards to music, take me deeper into songwriting, and unlock ideas inside of me that I didn't even know were there. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute right now, don't fret. I know it doesn't mean you don't care--if I had the money either I wouldn't be asking! Other things you can do to help are:

  • Pray for me, for the funding but also that my heart will be good and ready to step into this next season and receive all that He has for me. That all this effort and new knowledge will be profoundly impactful. For protection. 
  • Use the IndieGoGo share tools to spread word about this campaign!
  • Share the Wake Up Worship livestream
story_txt:
The LowdownIf you've known me for any amount of time, you know I have both a huge love for music and an obsession with God. Well, I've been offered the amazing opportunity to attend Bethel School of Worship, a place where I can cultivate my skills as a worship leader and learn to take my passions beyond 'singing in front of a bunch of people at church.' My vision for worship music is:
To change atmospheres and break barriers

To break the mold--spiritually and musically

Do it with excellence
Bethel School of Worship is the perfect place for me to grow my skills and learn from some of the most influential and impactful worship leaders alive today. I will also be meeting people from all over the world and country--how sweet is that! What I Need & What You GetThis is what I need in a little more detail:
$555 to complete my tuition costs
$500 for a plane ticket from North Carolina to Northern California
$180 to complete my housing costs
If I receive all these funds, I will have the opportunity to visit a place I've wanted to go for years and learn from my heroes. To thank you I've included a list of fun perks...it includes dancing in public so you might want to contribute ;) 
What this will do for my lifeBeyond just being a cool opportunity, I feel so strongly about going because I believe this School is a catalyst to the next season of my life. Travis and I have both been doing music related things for a long time, but I feel like in some ways I've plateaued and it's time to take it to the next level. I believe that attending this summer will help me understand my spiritual responsibility as a leader, teach me the practical disciplines I need to reach my musical goals, instill in me an attitude of excellence in regards to music, take me deeper into songwriting, and unlock ideas inside of me that I didn't even know were there. 
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you just can't contribute right now, don't fret. I know it doesn't mean you don't care--if I had the money either I wouldn't be asking! Other things you can do to help are:
Pray for me, for the funding but also that my heart will be good and ready to step into this next season and receive all that He has for me. That all this effort and new knowledge will be profoundly impactful. For protection. 
Use the IndieGoGo share tools to spread word about this campaign!
Share the Wake Up Worship livestream

story:
Here's the equation...

Teacher + out-of-pocket expenses for classroom = Yikes!!!! 

  • I am an elementary school teacher helping to build a public Montessori program in Florida. 
  • My classroom is short on some very important math materials!
  • I have set a $600 goal to buy Montessori math materials for my students. The materials include number beads and numeral tiles that kids can manipulate on a gorgeous multiplication checkerboard. You can see an example of them in my Indiegogo photo. These materials are beautiful... glamorous, even. They make math come alive for kids!
  • By funding my campaign, you will help my fourth- and fifth-graders become brilliant math scholars. This is VERY important because one day they might be doing YOUR taxes or crunching the numbers at your office. And you do NOT want them making silly mistakes. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The $600 will go towards purchasing sets of bead bars and numeral tiles. These represent the multiplier, multiplicand, and product on the multiplication checkerboard. 
  • You remember what I'm talking about... in the equation 40 x 5 = 200, the 40 is the multiplicand, the 5 is the multiplier, and the 200 is the product.
    Don't worry. There is NOT a quiz at the end of this.
  • In return for your generous contributions, you will receive super cute, personalized, handwritten thank you letters straight from the kids you're helping. You might even receive a very special thank you written in...drumroll please...CURSIVE!!! These letters, of course, will include photos of the materials in action!!
  • Even if I don't reach my goal, the money will still help defray costs. The materials are beautiful but pricey!

The Impact

Did you struggle with double-digit multiplication as a kid? Take a second to remember.

Ok... the equation is 24 x 15. Let's see, five times four is twenty, carry the two... wait. Where is that two supposed to go??... why am I even carrying this number? And what is this 'magic zero' supposed to mean anyways????? Ugggggggh, this is stupid! I haaaaate multiplication!!!!

If this sounds familiar to you, then you probably did. Your contribution will help kids avoid this stressful scenario. The Montessori materials that you'll fund will help my students truly understand how multiplication works so they DON'T become forever-frustrated math haters. The number beads and numeral tiles will give my students a visual, manipulative way of multiplying numbers. This is necessary because kids need a concrete way to visualize how numbers multiply before moving on to the abstract pencil-and-paper version of multiplication. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You might not be able to contribute right now, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Spread the word!!! Let someone else know about this Indiegogo campaign. Feel free to forward this to others. Remember: every dollar helps!

story:
Mr. Miyagi? Really?

Karate is an often misunderstood art and sport.  We encounter many whose perception is that we only teach how to fight or that we are cultivating bullies.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  It may sound cheesy, but if you get a chance, please watch the original Karate Kid and listen carefully to Mr. Miyagi.  It is a pop culture icon that people tend to make jokes about, but the "Miyagi-isms" are real.

Pat Morita portrayed a descendent of the real "Mr. Miyagi."  Warrior Karate is our school and our style is called Goju-ryu (The Way of Hard and Soft.) This style was founded by a man named Chojun Miyagi from Okinawa and the brief snippets of history or technique that we learn from the first three movies are pretty much exactly how they are taught even today.  Although the movie states that "karate is for defense only," its principles go a long way to living with honor and integrity. 

We have always strived to provide our students with a safe, professional, family-oriented atmosphere. We offer first-rate instruction on techniques, language, Martial Art and Okinawan history, and virtues of Goju-Ryu Karate.  Our goal is to develop each individual with a strong body, a strong mind, and an insurmountable spirit so that each student may learn and inherit the self-discipline, respect, humbleness and humility to become a success in life.

 

Becoming Warrior Karate

Our karate school once enjoyed great success, but in early 2012, our school's Sensei (head instructor) was forced to make a very abrupt departure due to circumstances beyond our control.  Under the worst of conditions, his son willingly assumed the reins and created his own school, naming it Warrior Karate.

Though many students initially remained loyal in attendance, we quickly lost students as our Sensei's sudden departure became ill-received throughout the community. We were no longer permitted to train at our old dojo and spent months training in public parks, which if you have ever lived in Florida during the summer months, you know this is not conducive to the heat and unpredictable weather patterns.  For a while, we sublet office space with a fabrication company, but after our landlord skipped out on his lease we were forced to leave and find a new home.  We now have a new and more suitable home and share space with an MMA/Kickboxing gym.  Though the rent we are being charged is very modest, we cannot sustain unless we have students who can pay the monthly membership fee.

The majority of the students who still train with us come from low-income families and have never been able to afford the pricey costs of training at the big name martial arts schools. Many of these students and their families aren't able to afford even $40 or $50 per month and when our school enjoyed success and high enrollment, these students were granted free or substantially reduced tuition by our Sensei because his passion for karate had never been about the money.  His philosophy was if a student was willing to learn, he was willing to teach.  These are the students who trust in our school, our teachings, and the art itself. These students, myself included are the most appreciative of the gift we have been given -  the gift of martial arts.  For us, karate is not just something we "do"; it is a passion and an honorable way of life for us and it is a gift we only want to share with others.

We have never charged exorbitant fees, nor do we wish to start; but we still have to pay rent and make ends meet; and "hounding" our best students for tuition that their parents just don't have is counter-productive to the principles that we teach.  To tell a student they cannot train until their academics improve is one thing; but to tell a devoted student they can no longer train with us if they can't pay will never feel right to us.

We would like to continue this tradition of offering karate to those who are willing to learn because we truly believe in the benefits of martial arts.  We have witnessed martial arts take students from being a troubled children/teenagers who were expelled from school for fighting and transform them into a focused and disciplined young adults.  One such student just graduated high school with high honors and was accepted to be a member of the United States Martial Arts Team - she is currently training to represent the United States in the World Games in September.  In fact, our school has three students who are members of this elite team, the youngest being only 11 years old.

What We Will Do with Your Contributions

The $5000 that we are requesting will go toward 5 scholarships.  Three of the scholarships will go to current students who will be selected by our senior panel of black belts.  These three students will have demonstrated great dedication and discipline, as well as show that they are living by the principles we teach.  The other two will be reserved for new students who apply.  Each scholarship will allow a student to have their tuition and any equipment costs paid for one full year.

In the event that we are not able to reach our goal, all contributed funds will go toward the tuition costs for our current students whose families are struggling to pay.

The Impact You Have on Our Students

Helping us reach our goal will allow us to continue the time-honored tradition of teaching and passing on the art of karate to the next generation.  Yes, karate teaches fighting techniques and is great for giving practitioners means of effective self-defense, but the attributes and principles of its teachings can be and are applied to every day life in a positive and healthy manner. 

While we have been very fortunate to produce top competitors and state champions, our primary goal has always been to simply offer youths an environment where they can grow and develop positive life skills.   

For some of our students, karate is the only "fun part" or the only "outlet" of their day and for others, karate gets them out from behind the video games; but for all of our students, the karate dojo is where they come to improve their whole self.  The vast majority of our students excel in academics, extra curricular sports and activities, or at work and most will tell you that it was karate that helped turn their lives around.

Transcending the Negativity

There was no pretty way to mask the situation we were faced with and we have had to look past and overcome months of negative connotations and ill-spoken rumors about our school.  When you spend the majority of your time trying to combat the negativity, it gives you little time to construct the path that will lead you ahead. 

But, we have worked hard to remain focused on the positive and by sticking to our principles and virtues and we have put the worst of our challenges behind us.  Two years later, though we have struggled greatly and are battle-weary, we are still here, ready to work and teach, and unwilling to back down from achieving success.  However, the struggles of the school and its reputation should not be the burden of students who were once promised a chance to train and so, we are humbly asking for your help that will allow us to keep our students training hard.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some will believe in our cause but are not necessarily in a position to help our students financially.  Believe me - we get it!!!  However, just helping to spread the word about our school would be of great help!

We thank you all in advance for your time and consideration!

story:
What is a Cavalcade of Authors?

Cavalcade of Authors is a conference for students made up of two components: 1) students reading novels from 17 featured authors, and 2) a writer's conference led by these authors to be held on May 2nd, 2015. We are collaborating with Pacific Lutheran University to present a literary/writing conference for 450 middle level and high school students in Pierce County, Washington. COA West is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

Cavalcade of Authors West is in its first year, modeled after the Cavalcade of Authors established in the Tri Cities of Washington in 2009.  We want to bring the rich experience of working with authors practically one-on-one to western Washington students.

Adolescent literacy is a significant need in our community and this program promotes reading and writing skills in an engaging and unique way. The response from students, teachers, and authors has been positive and encouraging. It is our hope that the program will grow and expand to become a truly regional event that draws students from all around Pierce County.

Our five founding board members have a vast amount of teaching and literacy experience as classroom teachers and librarians. We have each contributed to a number of boards, conferences and events of various sizes and scope. Above all, we all have a passion for students, authors and literacy; this conference will allow us to combine all of those pieces to deliver a unique and meaningful experience to the students of our own community.

What We Need & What You Get

To operate a program of this magnitude for our Pierce County students, we are looking to raise nearly $18,000. To reach as many students and schools as possible, donations of any value are welcome and appreciated.

The funds will go directly to pay author honorariums, travel and lodging expenses, and meals, as well as for marketing and school outreach. We have worked hard to negotiate discounts and donations when possible; for instance, conference fees have been donated by PLU and many authors are donating travel expenses and autographed books.

Perks:

  • $500 - Author Social invitation May 1, 2015
  • $100 - Autographed book by the author of your choice
  • $25 - Poster autographed by all participating authors

The Impact

We are committed to promoting literacy in our community. We want to pass on the love for books in our world that is slowly beginning to devalue the wonder of reading. As educators, we know that reading is the number one indicator of student success in school and in determining their earning power in the workplace. The Cavalcade of Authors West is the experience of a lifetime for students, bringing together world-class authors and their young adult readers.

Risks & Challenges

This is the first event of its kind in the Puget Sound. Although it is our first year, we are using the very successful Cavalcade of Authors (Tri-Cities) as our template, and with their support, we are confident in the success of this project. We are also well aware of national and regional book and author festivals, have attended a number ourselves, and we understand the amount of work, planning and support that must go into them to make these events successful, and ripe for growth year after year. We have 17 authors contracted at this time, both local and nationally known, and know we can continue to attract the high caliber authors that are at the top of students' reading lists. Our biggest challenge is having the money to support our commitments to both authors and students. We will continue to reach out to our corporate community as partners in this project, but we need to count on our friends and supporters to get off the ground.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can contribute or not, please help us spread the word about this very worthwhile cause. We can be found on Twitter and Instagram (@cavalcadewest), and please refer to our website for updates and information about this campaign and this project so important to us.
