story:
Help Me Finish the Job!

Hi! My name is Christy. You may know me better from the internet as /u/sadaye or @HockeyBabbler. I am a nontraditional student in her final year at the University of Puget Sound in Tacoma, WA. It's been a journey to get to this point, and it hasn't been easy. I am fortunate enough to qualify for a generous financial aid package that allows me to attend this school which I would otherwise have no way of affording. However, with a recent rise in tuition prices by nearly $1,000 a semester, I've gone from receiving $500 per semester to spend on books and other expenses to owing $435 each semester just for tuition. That's not counting the $200-$300 worth of books I am required to get for each semester. While I have a job on campus and my husband works full-time, we are already living paycheck to paycheck, sharing a house with a roommate and living frugally. It may not sound like a lot of money to you, but the difference of $935 a semester moves us from "ok but poor" to "one small problem from real trouble."


By donating, you will be helping me to finally receive my Bachelor's degree and bring me one step closer to my dream of working in publishing. $1,400 will pay for my books and tuition for the rest of the year.

What I Need & What You Get

Breakdown of expenses:

  • $665.72 - Fall 2014: $435 Tuition (after Financial Aid), $232.72 for Books.
  • $685 - Spring 2015: $435 Tuition (after Financial Aid), ~$250 for Books (exact cost currently unknown)
  • ~$50: Approximate fees should I reach my goal
  • Total: ~$1400.72. We'll call it $1400.

Rewards

(See individual rewards for details and restrictions)


    The Impact

    I graduated from high school in 2003, and while I went to a local community college right away with the intent of transferring to San Jose State University, life decided to intervene. Because of the stress related to my father's long term illness (which he would later pass away as a result of), I left school and started working full time. Fate has a funny way of working things out, and I met my husband at my first full time job. We have moved around quite a bit, but we have been working towards the goal of earning our Bachelor's degrees. We're taking turns so that one of us is working full time to pay the bills while the other goes to school, and I'm going first.

    This means that not only will you be helping me to finish school, you'll be enabling my husband to start going back to school as well.


    "But Christy," you probably aren't saying, "Your Senior Year should be so much more than just graduation. College should be an experience!" You're right, Imaginary You. It should be! So if I am able to reach my goal and achieve certain amounts beyond my goal, I will be able to do more than just graduate - I will be able to do two things that I would love to do in the next year!

    And if you want to see me suffer? Well, there are even benefits for you. The more people who donate, the closer I get to perils and pitfalls. There's fun available for everyone!

    Stretch Goals:

    • $3,500: I start learning to play hockey, and YOU reap the benefits.How is that? I will document by video my journey from out-of-shape, terribad skater who can't stop (me right now) to...maybe slightly less terribad? These videos will then be posted to YouTube for the entire world to admire/be inspired by/laugh at. I guarantee that even if I fail utterly, you'll still have a good time. There will be a minimum of one video per week throughout my journey. This goal amount is based on a rough estimate of what I would need to purchase the needed equipment, lessons and ice time to start playing.
    • $5,000: Outdoor Game and Bay Area Meetup! In February, the San Jose Sharks will be playing the Los Angeles Kings in the brand new Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara. Outside. In California. Because reasons. If I make this much, my husband and I will be able to afford a trip back to the Bay Area to go to this game. And, once there, I'd love to have a few beers with any of you there, with a drink (or more than just one? depends) on me.
    • $7,000: Make me learn to play goalie. I'm not tall and I'm stocky, and would probably make a terrible goalie. I guess my flexibility is not terrible considering how out of shape I am? But still, it'd be hilariously bad. Increase the hilarity of the previous reward by making me look like a fish out of water. This goal amount is based on a rough estimate of what I would need to purchase the significantly more expensive goalie equipment, as well as the cost to my dignity and ligaments.
    • $10,000: I will buy and wear a Kings jersey. Seriously. I'll do it. I'll do a video wearing it. This will probably make me cry. Extra hilarity. This goal amount is based on a rough estimate of how much money I would need to be OK with this. Emotional damages will result. It will haunt me. But hey, it will make you laugh, and it's not like we're going to hit that amount, right?

     

    Risks & Challenges

    As a Dean's List student determined to graduate, it would take an event of life-altering proportions to keep me from graduating this year. Even if something awful were to happen to me or my family, you can bet I'd do everything in my power to finish school now that I'm this close. I can't make any promises about the quality of the hockey if I get that far in my funding, though.

    Aside from the risk of being able to fulfill that which I say I will fulfill by raising this money, there is also the risk that I will not be able to deliver the rewards promised. I will combat this by starting on the custom doodles as soon as the first donations roll in - that's right, before I'm even guaranteed funding, you'll be getting rewards. If I don't reach my goal, not only will you get your money back, but you'll get to keep your doodle. How awesome is that?


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you are not able to donate, but you still want to help, consider sharing this with your friends, family, mailman, dog, mailman's friends, coworkers, coworker's dog, etc. The more eyes we can get on this, the more likely it is that I will be able to pay for school. Yay! If you use referral links, I'll be able to see how many visitors and donations your referrals bring in. Those most effective at referring will earn doodles even without donating! Woah! And maybe even other stuff, too!
story_txt:
Help Me Finish the Job!
Hi! My name is Christy. You may know me better from the internet as /u/sadaye or @HockeyBabbler. I am a nontraditional student in her final year at the University of Puget Sound in Tacoma, WA. It's been a journey to get to this point, and it hasn't been easy. I am fortunate enough to qualify for a generous financial aid package that allows me to attend this school which I would otherwise have no way of affording. However, with a recent rise in tuition prices by nearly $1,000 a semester, I've gone from receiving $500 per semester to spend on books and other expenses to owing $435 each semester just for tuition. That's not counting the $200-$300 worth of books I am required to get for each semester. While I have a job on campus and my husband works full-time, we are already living paycheck to paycheck, sharing a house with a roommate and living frugally. It may not sound like a lot of money to you, but the difference of $935 a semester moves us from "ok but poor" to "one small problem from real trouble."

By donating, you will be helping me to finally receive my Bachelor's degree and bring me one step closer to my dream of working in publishing. $1,400 will pay for my books and tuition for the rest of the year.

What I Need & What You Get
 Breakdown of expenses:


$665.72 - Fall 2014: $435 Tuition (after Financial Aid), $232.72 for Books.


$685 - Spring 2015: $435 Tuition (after Financial Aid), ~$250 for Books (exact cost currently unknown)

~$50: Approximate fees should I reach my goal
Total: ~$1400.72. We'll call it $1400.


Rewards
(See individual rewards for details and restrictions)



  
The Impact I graduated from high school in 2003, and while I went to a local community college right away with the intent of transferring to San Jose State University, life decided to intervene. Because of the stress related to my father's long term illness (which he would later pass away as a result of), I left school and started working full time. Fate has a funny way of working things out, and I met my husband at my first full time job. We have moved around quite a bit, but we have been working towards the goal of earning our Bachelor's degrees. We're taking turns so that one of us is working full time to pay the bills while the other goes to school, and I'm going first.
This means that not only will you be helping me to finish school, you'll be enabling my husband to start going back to school as well.


"But Christy," you probably aren't saying, "Your Senior Year should be so much more than just graduation. College should be an experience!" You're right, Imaginary You. It should be! So if I am able to reach my goal and achieve certain amounts beyond my goal, I will be able to do more than just graduate - I will be able to do two things that I would love to do in the next year!
And if you want to see me suffer? Well, there are even benefits for you. The more people who donate, the closer I get to perils and pitfalls. There's fun available for everyone!
Stretch Goals:


$3,500: I start learning to play hockey, and YOU reap the benefits.How is that? I will document by video my journey from out-of-shape, terribad skater who can't stop (me right now) to...maybe slightly less terribad? These videos will then be posted to YouTube for the entire world to admire/be inspired by/laugh at. I guarantee that even if I fail utterly, you'll still have a good time. There will be a minimum of one video per week throughout my journey. This goal amount is based on a rough estimate of what I would need to purchase the needed equipment, lessons and ice time to start playing.

$5,000: Outdoor Game and Bay Area Meetup! In February, the San Jose Sharks will be playing the Los Angeles Kings in the brand new Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara. Outside. In California. Because reasons. If I make this much, my husband and I will be able to afford a trip back to the Bay Area to go to this game. And, once there, I'd love to have a few beers with any of you there, with a drink (or more than just one? depends) on me.

$7,000: Make me learn to play goalie. I'm not tall and I'm stocky, and would probably make a terrible goalie. I guess my flexibility is not terrible considering how out of shape I am? But still, it'd be hilariously bad. Increase the hilarity of the previous reward by making me look like a fish out of water. This goal amount is based on a rough estimate of what I would need to purchase the significantly more expensive goalie equipment, as well as the cost to my dignity and ligaments.

$10,000: I will buy and wear a Kings jersey. Seriously. I'll do it. I'll do a video wearing it. This will probably make me cry. Extra hilarity. This goal amount is based on a rough estimate of how much money I would need to be OK with this. Emotional damages will result. It will haunt me. But hey, it will make you laugh, and it's not like we're going to hit that amount, right?

 
  Risks & Challenges As a Dean's List student determined to graduate, it would take an event of life-altering proportions to keep me from graduating this year. Even if something awful were to happen to me or my family, you can bet I'd do everything in my power to finish school now that I'm this close. I can't make any promises about the quality of the hockey if I get that far in my funding, though.
Aside from the risk of being able to fulfill that which I say I will fulfill by raising this money, there is also the risk that I will not be able to deliver the rewards promised. I will combat this by starting on the custom doodles as soon as the first donations roll in - that's right, before I'm even guaranteed funding, you'll be getting rewards. If I don't reach my goal, not only will you get your money back, but you'll get to keep your doodle. How awesome is that?

  
Other Ways You Can Help If you are not able to donate, but you still want to help, consider sharing this with your friends, family, mailman, dog, mailman's friends, coworkers, coworker's dog, etc. The more eyes we can get on this, the more likely it is that I will be able to pay for school. Yay! If you use referral links, I'll be able to see how many visitors and donations your referrals bring in. Those most effective at referring will earn doodles even without donating! Woah! And maybe even other stuff, too!

story:
Short Summary

I am enrolled at Georgia perimeter college, and I am still in high school through an early college program. This program was very challenging and as a result my GPA is not where i wish it to be. Log story short, I just got accepted into that ideal school that I have often dreamed of. However, I have a huge problem, I do not have any financial aid!! I have always been a hard worker and have always done my best with what ever I do,but its just not enough. I tried to build money through the two small businesses that I own but not enough people want to support my businesses. This is my only chance to get to where I desperately want to be in life. By going to college, I believe that I can achieve my life long goal to produce greener more efficient forms of technology, and to make life more bearable and enjoyable for all.

  • My first business is my computer company called Tech-Masters, but barely anyone supports me I only made $30 for the whole year.
  • My second business is gift wrapping company, again not that many people support me and I was only able to save $60 for college.
  • I have no where else to tern,because I do not wish to have loan debt.


The why & What I Get from contributions

Why do I need $10,000: 

  • Southern Poly cost me a total of $17,278 a year.
  • I have not received any scholarships/grants, and might just be lucky enough to receive the Hope scholarship from Georgia and or FAFSA which wont be enough with out help from you all.
  • Even if I don’t reach my entire goal I will still use what I can for college because as anyone should know every little bit helps.
What you get from me:
  • I know its not much but this is what i will give in return.
  • Firstly, every contribute will receive a personal thank you card for their contributions after the campaign.
  • 1 small Handmade piece of origami (paper folded figures) per person who contributes at least $20. By mail
  • 1  large Handmade piece of origami (paper folded figures) per person who contributes at least $100. By mail

The Impact

The impact of your contributions on my life will be extremely substantial. This money will not just go to help me for school but will also aid in completing my life long goal to make a better more efficient society.

  • Getting my education will help me to research new forms of tech. that will not only be greener tech. but also make the different types of societies more efficient.
  • Currently, I am exploring the possibilities of car that use electrical pulse motors and magnetic polarity to make cars move.
  • Through this I plan to not only make cars less expensive but also less damaging to the environment.

Other Ways You Can Help

For people who can not give money:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools so I can recieve support!!

Thanks again for all your help! =)

email: ship13@rocketmail.com 

email me to ask about how to get perk

story:
The Organization: Precious Minds Foundation is a non-profit organization  centered in remote village Jamnindo Marri in province Sindh, Pakistan. The village is in a poorly serviced, remote and rural area with unpaved roads. Most of the children in Jamnindo come from poor farming families . Most of the farming families earn less than $3 a day. Because of this prevalent financial struggle, the cycle of poverty continues and the children of Jamnindo Marri have only gloomy futures ahead. PMF provides these children with the opportunity to attend a free school where they receive an education and become literate in Sindhi, Urdu and English, thus expanding their horizons and improving their chances of a brighter future. The students are taught the Government Curriculum of Pakistan by skilled teachers.

The organization recently organized "Summer Camp for Underprivileged Village Children" for different schools in the nearby villages. School supplies and hygiene packs were distributed among the children.

     

(Kids with their hygiene and stationary packs at a local school.)

The Problem: Village Jamnindo Marri is home to over two thousand people, including 700 children and about 400 families, but this community of farmers is so underdeveloped that only a few families can afford sending their kids to private schools in nearby towns. Floods and government ignorance have badly affected the area and the poor education system keeps the villagers trapped in this cycle of poverty. The school provided by the government is non-functional due to neglect. Poor but determined young kids walk long distances everyday to reach our school which still lacks a proper building, school equipments, adequate chairs and desks, requiring students to stand. Despite of all these constraints, we strive to continue this good work for these underprivileged village children.

The Project: To break the cycle of poverty, the children of Village Jamnindo Marri must receive enough education to shape their future and become a vital workforce in the development of the area. PMF is working to provide furniture and school supplies for its school and the kids. In order to achieve this goal, the organization must raise approximately $1,600.

(Over 100 kids attend our school to learn English and Sindhi.)

The Budget:  

$875: First our plan is to buy furniture for the school. A 3-seat school desk costs about $35 here. That will get us 25 benches for 75 students, thus, making the students comfortable with seating.

$150: Secondly, we will need funds for equipment like blackboard/chalkboard and locker. 3 blackboards will cost $100 total and a locker for $50. 

$400: Thirdly, we need school supplies for the kids. Each kid will receive 1 backpack, 3 notebooks, 1 drawing book, pencils, color pencils. Each kit will cost about $4.

$175: Lastly, the transportation charges. The village is in a remote area, so we would have to hire vehicles to carry the equipment.

Other ways you can help: Though we are in a remote area with little access to donation funds we rely on spreading the word about our cause through viral means. If you cannot donate through indiegogo due to any reason, you can contact us at info@preciousfoundation.org for information about others ways to donate.


Thank you, donate generously.

story:
My name is Erika Fennelly and I’m enrolled in my senior year at the University of Colorado at Boulder for Germanic and Chinese Studies. Since high school, my goal has been to master the German language and to be able to use that skill for my career in the future and in life in general while living in German speaking countries. To make it official, I’m striving to earn the internationally accredited and extremely rigorous Goethe-Zertifikat C2, which is an official certificate from the Goethe Institut proving my mastery of the German language. With funding from this campaign, I am hoping to finance the exam and preparation courses.



More About the Test:

The Goethe-Zertifikat C2: Großes Deutsches Sprachdiplom requires extremely advanced language skills and documents the highest level – C2 – on the six-level competency scale described in the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

The level C2 means I must be able to:

  • understand everything in German that I read and hear effortlessly
  • summarize information presented to me from a variety of sources, written and spoken, and, in doing so, synthesize correlating arguments as well as explanations
  • organically express myself in a fluent and precise manner and articulate the finer nuances of complex arguments.

The Goethe-Institut’s certificates are recognized worldwide and are highly regarded by employers and further-education institutions as proof of language competency.

As the final push during my time in Germany, I will be taking the exam at the end of April before going back to my university in Colorado in May 2015 to finish my bachelor degrees.


Why help me reach my goal?

Scholarships are there for those who work hard and seek support in reaching further achievements, but sometimes there isn’t a cookie cutter scholarship for everyone. I have a very specific goal in mind and have been striving to reach it for 7 years. In this final push, I need financial support to get the preparation and support necessary to make this a reality.

As you see in the last section, I will be able to use the certificate I get by passing the exam for the rest of my life to prove my German skills in my career future, whether living in Germany or teaching the German language in America.

Click here to read more about my exceptional efforts in high school, at the university and beyond.


Budget

Test: € 295 ($370)

[More about the test]


 Preparation Course: € 240 ($300)

[More about the preparation course]


Neue Schule Language School 5 weeks Intensive 1 Course:  € 450 ($560)

[More about the language school]


Total: €985 ($1230)

 MY GOAL: $1200


What if my goal is surpassed?

Of course, I would be extremely thankful for any further donations after my goal and will dedicate them to working even harder to passing the C2 exam. There are many ways for me to do that in accredited language schools, depending on available funds. I will gladly provide proof of how I allocate all funds.

With funds reaching $1,900

If I am fortunate enough to reach $1,900, I will spend two out of my five weeks at the Neue Schule language school in the “Intensive Special Course” and the other three weeks in the normal intensive course. Together, the 5 weeks would cost $840 extra than attending just the normal course for the 5 weeks.

Benefit: In the two weeks in the “Intensive Special Course” I get 20 hours of private tutoring from teachers from the school for extra support in class materials.

With funds reaching $2,200

Thank you so much! Now I’ll be able to spend 6 weeks in the Neue Schule language school: 3 weeks in the “Intensive Special Course” with 30 weeks of private tutoring and 3 weeks in the normal intensive course.

What if my financial goal isn’t met?

Even if my goal of $1,200 isn’t reached, I still can use the donations made to take the exam ($370). Any further funding will be used to spend as much time in preparatory courses as possible.


Questions/Concerns?

Do you want to know more? Contact me at erika.fennelly[at]colorado.edu and I will gladly get in touch with you.

story:
I have been blessed with the opportunity to study abroad in Germany next semester. During my seven (7) months long trip I will be in Stuttgart, studying German and Film & Literature; Heidelberg, taking liberal arts courses and performing in a play; and using my two weeks of free time in between those two cities to explore other cities and attempt to celebrate my 21st birthday.

Right now, you might be telepathically asking me, "Why Germany?" I've received this inquiry on many an occasion. My freshmen year at Saint Andrew's School I met German Exchange student, Jonas Dunkel. Jonas and I are obviously different at face value but the concept of being new at a school and feeling like an outsider was a commonality that kindled our friendship. During that year, Jonas told me wonderful stories of him growing up in Berlin, taught me a few basic German phrases, and allowed me to meet his wonderful parents who visited the States at the end of the academic year.

Since then, I've known that my amazement with Jonas and his culture is something that I must see for myself. I've been teaching myself German for the last four years (buying books, taking online lessons) and preparing myself for the day when the opportunity to travel to Deutschland would present itself.

Ladies and Gentlemen, that day has come but I know that I cannot accomplish my goal without your help. I need your financial support to make my way to and through my upcoming adventure. I have added perks to each donation level to let you know that your generosity will not go unnoticed. I am determined to reciprocate the wondrous love you have shown me.

Thank you, Happy Holidays, and God bless you!

Danke schön, frohe Feiertage, und Gott segne Sie!

I am determined to reciprocate the wondrous love you have shown me.Thank you, Happy Holidays, and God bless you!Danke schön, frohe Feiertage, und Gott segne Sie!

story:
120 Years of Changing Lives

We are proud of our history of providing individuals and families with the tools they need to thrive; such as educational, recreational and social service programs.  We are proud of our successes and our growth, but with current economic challenges and wavering government support, we know that we need to do more.

We have two great needs and opportunities to respond to the communities we serve:

The first is the need to support our Early Childhood Education Program. Educators agree that the first few years of a child’s life are a particularly sensitive period in their development. Our programs are critical to helping children develop cognitive, social and behavioral functions, as well as language development. We even address nutrition and the physical health of the child at this critical point of development. Our program does so much more than prepare children for success in school; it provides support for the parents, the children, and in many ways, the family as a whole and lays the foundation for a lifetime of learning and success. All the children we serve are at-risk for academic failure, and 100% of our students enter Kindergarten ready and able to learn.

The second is our Adult Education Program through which we offer English As a Second Language (ESL) and basic computer classes. Our ESL classes transform immigrants into confident and able citizens through reading, writing, listening, speaking and grammar instruction.  Beyond teaching non-native speakers verbal and comprehensive skills, we are empowering entire families by helping them acclimate to their new communities and culture.

Better Education = Better Opportunities

Studies by the Department of Education suggest that non-English speaking adults were at a distinct disadvantage regardless of education level and were routinely placed in entry-level positions or non-critical jobs. However, after ESL classes, participants were eligible for jobs that included rigorous training and accordingly higher pay with better opportunities for advancement. Through our programs we not only hope to increase the ability to expand employment opportunities, but also to help individuals and families thrive by integrating into their surrounding communities. By expanding our ESL offering, we are hoping to elevate the opportunity and potential of all participants.

Our Community Computer Resource Center (CCRC) provides classes in essential computer skills.  As the only free, open access computer lab in the Belmont Cragin neighborhood, individuals have the opportunity to learn computers to compete in today’s job market. Our courses include beginner-level to advanced technology with a focus on topics like Microsoft Office software, job search tools, web site design, and introduction to hardware. Computer literacy is an important part of ESL and integrated into learning, assessments, and testing.



There Are Many More Waiting for Help

While our programs are successful for individuals, families and the community at large, the bad news is that our resources are limited and we can’t serve all who want and need to be part of our programs. We want to change that, and we can with your help.   

We also can’t stress enough how vital these programs are. Both, in their own way, help alleviate poverty, reduce unemployment, increase literacy rates and language skills and improve high school graduation rates.

You Can Make a Difference

 Onward Neighborhood House hopes to raise $50,000 during this campaign. With $50,000, we will be able to significantly enhance our Early Childhood Education and Adult Education programs.

  As a result of our reputation for positive outcomes working with children with disabilities, enrollment of children with disabilities has tripled in the last three years. With your help, we can hire teaching staff to work with our children with disabilities. This will allow us to provide these children with more individual attention and help maintain high quality education.   

With $50,000 we will also be able to expand our Adult Education Program. We will add at least 20 more computer stations, part-time instructional staff and open our classrooms to at least 220 more people who want to change their lives by mastering English or computer literacy.

Our Students Need You

We need your help to raise $50,000, which will allow us to begin three very important initiatives that will give students and families in the West Town and Belmont Cragin communities the tools that they need to be successful and empower their community:

  1. We will hire much-needed staff that will maintain the quality of service that we provide to the future leaders in our Early Childhood Education program.
  2. We will enhance our technology resource center and make it available to an expanded amount of motivated students.
  3. We will expand our Adult Education Program to include advanced English as a Second Language (ESL) courses and GED courses for individuals looking to make a significant contribution to their community and the world.
Even if we do not reach our funding goal, your contribution can make a big impact in the lives of the children and adults of the communities we serve. The funds raised will be used to expand our Early Childhood Education and Adult Services programs to include GED and advanced ESL (English as a Second Language) courses. And you will still be a community hero to so many!

Why it Makes Sense for Everyone

Our students and families care about your help. Most of the perks in this campaign contain a special message or gift that is hand-crafted by one of our participating students as a heartfelt ‘Thank You’ for giving them the tools that they need to be successful.

The programs at Onward Neighborhood House not only impact the lives of our participants; they help empower a community that has been built by a blend of hardworking, inventive people and cultures for generations. Your contribution means the future to the pioneers that come from this historic neighborhood.

We Can Do Even More!

 By surpassing our goal of $50,000 we can do so much more!  

With your help, we can reach $75,000 and feed hundreds more individuals and families in the Belmont-Cragin neighborhood by opening a second food pantry in partnership with St. Peter’s Church.

  We can even develop a summer sports and arts program for school-aged children (6-12) to keep them in a safe, learning environment while they are not in school.  

And by helping us reach $100,000 we can make huge improvements to our facility that will save a significant amount in energy costs and would allow us to use these savings to help countless more individuals and families in need.


Other Ways You Can Help


Think you can’t contribute? Think again!

Onward Neighborhood House was built for community. You can make a serious impact in helping our effort by reaching out to your own community. Volunteers are appreciated to read to our young students in the classrooms or help in our food pantry.

Please share our story with your family, friends and co-workers using the Facebook button on this page or by email.  Every time our story is told, an opportunity is created to help change the lives of capable and deserving students and families. 


We are also in need of licensed plumbers and carpenters to help us make the ongoing updates and renovations to our facilities. Please consider donating your time for a great cause.

Please visit us at onwardhouse.org or facebook.com/onwardhouse for more information on how you can help.

We Need You

 There are many more children who need a safe, secure, happy, educational place to go for preschool that are waiting for an opportunity to join our program. There are parents who need a place for their children to grow so that parents can work to provide for their families and better integrate into a new culture.  

Our English as a Second Language classes and computer classes have a profound impact on individuals, families and community members. These critically important programs are the key to fulfilling careers. The participants will be better prepared to effectively raise and support their children. They will have the tools to support their children with their homework and partners with the teachers.

Make a contribution and enjoy a perk from Onward Neighborhood House. Help us spread the word about Onward Neighborhood House and the need to expand our life-changing Early Childhood Education and ESL programs. Please Share, Like and Tweet!   

Thank you for your help.

story:
Short Summary


Hey lovely's

For those who don't know me, I am Eliza. I am 27 and I have a real heart for the homeless, lost and broken. Some great people have helped me change the way I was heading and I want to help others find their purpose. 

So, I am heading to YWAM for a DTS (discipleship training school) to learn more about myself and how I can make a difference. I went to Cambodia last year to volunteer and I came back to Perth wanting to experience so much more. After looking at different organizations to volunteer with I felt it was right to go with Ywam because I will be committed to 6 months of learning and working in indigenous communities. The first 3 months is more about learning and the next 2-3 months is putting everything I learn into practice.


I need $4830 for the lecture phase, accommodation and food included for 3 months and;

$4000 approx. For the outreach phase which includes food, travel and accommodation for the last few months.

If I don't reach this financial goal I will be putting it towards another DTS or looking into supporting other volunteers and donating it.

story: In 2010 a major earthquake hit the country of Haiti. Enormous numbers of people are still homeless and thousands of children have no where to attend school.  This July  I will be joining a group of Catholics to help build a school in rural Haiti. We will be there for a week and hope to make serious progress in opening this facility to deserving children. I am trying to raise funds - specifically $2,500 to cover my travel costs. Your help is much appreciated.

story:
Short Summary

As sophomores in an English II Honors class, we have been working on Passion Projects since the beginning of the school year. My project was inspired by my experiences at an equine therapy camp. These experiences inspired me to raise funds for students with special needs. The students who are granted scholarships will attend this camp over a five week period beginning on consecutive Tuesdays from May 6 through June 3; creating opportunities for socioemotional growth as the students not only care for the horses but also ride the horses.

The students will be assessed before and after the program to determine the benefits of the program for each of the students; which will hopefully prove the success of the program allowing it to continue. 

What We Need & What You Get

My goal was to send at least two students. However, I would like to send five students; which will cost $520.00 per student with a total cost of $2,600.00 

All donations will be greatly appreciated with each donor receiving a thank you note.

One individual who donates $275.00 or more can claim the perk of receiving a complimentary riding party for four individuals at BEAMING Inc. located in Neenah, WI. This complimentary riding party will occur on a date between June 2014 and October 2014 for a total duration of two hours including a 45 minute riding session; which will be mutually agreed upon between BEAMING Inc. and the recipient. Additionally, the recipient will be responsible for all transportation to/from the party.

The Impact

This program is extremely beneficial to the students involved as well as everyone contributing to it's success. These students will not only receive an experience of their lifetime but also receive benefits for both the mind and the body. Additionally, the success of the 2014 program may impact future students with special needs to benefit from the wonders of Equine Therapy. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread "my passion" to help other students with my fundraiser through any form of communication including the Indiegogo share tools even if you are unable to donate! 

Attn: Exceptional Perk!

One individual who donates $275.00 or more can claim the perk of receiving a complimentary riding party for four individuals at BEAMING Inc. located in Neenah, WI. This complimentary riding party will occur on a date between June 2014 and October 2014 for a total duration of two hours including a 45 minute riding session; which will be mutually agreed upon between BEAMING Inc. and the recipient. Additionally, the recipient will be responsible for all transportation to/from the party.

story:
The students of Colegio Cristiano Presbiteriano (CCP) in Managua, Nicaragua need computer skills to have any hope of lifting themselves out of poverty.  We need your help to fund a computer teacher and provide internet service for the school over the next three years.  

The families of the Hialeah neighborhood are some of the poorest in Managua, and Nicaragua vies with Haiti as the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.  Many of the children who live there and attend CCP live in homes with dirt floors and walls made of scrap materials.

About the School

CCP is a private school that offers classes from pre-school through ninth grade.  It was founded in 1997 by the Mission of the Presbyterian Church of South Korea in Nicaragua in order to provide a better education, opportunity, and moral guidance for the children of Barrio Hialeah.  The Korean mission continues to operate the school.  CCP provides a much higher quality of education than is provided in the public schools, which is evidenced by the fact that over 250 families in this extremely poor neighborhood make the sacrifice to pay the tuition fee. 

CCP has struggled to survive over the years due to lack of sufficient funding, and funding remains an ongoing challenge.  However, despite nearly closing in 2008, CCP has persevered with the help of generous donors who believe in its mission.  Austin Samaritans, a non-profit, and Westlake Hills Presbyterian Church, both based in Austin, Texas, provided emergency funds to keep the school open in 2008  and have provided ongoing support since that time.


Some generous donors built a secure computer lab for the school in the fall of 2014, which was then furnished with 28 computers  by a Korean Presbyterian Church.  Initiatives like these provide students with the resources and encouragement they need to become better educated and to create more hopeful futures for themselves, their families, and their community.

We cannot stop there, however.  In order for the students to receive the full benefit of the computer lab, we are hoping to raise $7,642 for a computer instructor for three years, and $2,592 for reliable internet service for three years, equaling our total campaign goal of $10,234. Remember that the organization for which you work may match your donation—you will receive an email with the EIN number of Austin Samaritans after you make a donation.

School Leadership

Sarah Kim, a Korean missionary, became administrator of CCP in 2013 and many improvements have been made under her leadership. 

She cares deeply for her students and is committed to their spiritual, moral and intellectual growth.  She is supported by her husband, Pablo Kim, who leads a Christian outreach program for university students.

Mrs. Kim has hired highly qualified teachers who genuinely care for and love their students.  They are young and have a passion for developing their students’ capabilities.  In addition, CCP has a pastor and psychologist on staff to provide support to the students and their families.  Parents are encouraged to participate in school activities and to take an active part in their child’s education.


Kumon curriculum has been introduced to give students a strong foundation in math, which is essential for admission to a college.  The AWANA discipleship program is offered to grades 2 through 6, to develop Christian beliefs and values through engaging and fun group activities.  Bible study is provided for the upper grades.

And now – the most recent and exciting step forward – a secure computer lab complete with 28 donated computers!

Computer skills, a strong overall educational foundation and moral guidance, give the children of CCP a genuine chance to compete in the 21st century for a much brighter future.  Let's help insure this new computer education gets established and continues for years to come! 

Who We are and Why We Care

The members of our team currently serve on the Board of Directors of Austin Samaritans.   We have seen the poverty and the living conditions in this barrio.  Yet we have also seen the pride of the families in sending their children to CCP and their eagerness to help the school as they are able.  Dirt floors or no – these children show up every day with clean and pressed uniforms, bodies washed, hair in place, and smiles on their faces. 

These families want the best for their children, as we all do, and are sacrificing to give it to them.  Now it's our turn to come alongside them with hands and hearts to lift them up.

story:
Wir möchten, dass Robert seiner Begeisterung für die Luftfahrt folgen kann und unterstützen die Finanzierung seiner Ausbildung zum Flugdienstberater.

 

Was macht das Leben aus?

Wer sollte darüber bestimmen, was man tut? Was, wenn doch zu viele Steine im Weg sind und Hürden unüberwindbar scheinen? Die Begeisterung ist ein Antrieb, wenn nicht sogar der Antrieb, der den Erfolg schon beim Tun mit sich bringt.


Die Begeisterung liegt in der Luftfahrt.

Schon jeher... Der Flugsimulator am PC gehört zu seiner Standardinstallation. Über das Netz gründete und unterhielt er mit anderen Luftfahrtbegeisterten erfolgreich eine „Erfundene-Airline. Ein Highlight seiner Begeisterung war ein Flug im beweglichen Aviare Flugsimulator, mit dem auch Piloten trainiert werden. Er flog Singapur, Zürich und St. Marteen.


Robert gibt sehr viel.

Wir, seine Freunde wissen, dass Robert sehr viel gibt. Unter anderem als Jugendfeuerwehrwart der Freiwilligen Feuerwehr in Mohlsdorf. Er organisiert u.a. den Berufsfeuerwehrtag und sorgt somit für Weiterbildungen der Jugend. Im Rahmen der Feuerwehr und des Katastrophenschutzes sensibilisiert und unterrichtet er Kinder und Jugendliche in Kindergärten und Grundschulen für die Gefahren. Im Greizer Theaterherbst e.V. engagiert er sich. Er steht auf der Bühne und begeistert das Publikum zum Beispiel mit Improtheater. Aber auch hinter der Bühne unterstützt er den Verein bzw. das Theaterfestival mit viel Tatkraft. Bei dem Greizer Stadtmagazin 12°Ost bringt er viele Ideen, aber auch mitreißende lesenswerte Artikel.


Seine Freunde unterstützen ihn.

Dennoch... wir wissen, dass ihm etwas fehlt und es in unerreichbarer Ferne scheint. Robert möchte seiner Luftfahrt Begeisterung mehr Platz im Leben einräumen und in Paderborn eine Ausbildung zum Flugdienstberater machen. Jeder von uns möchte etwas von seiner Begeisterung abgeben, dass Robert seiner Begeisterung folgen kann!

Wir geben unserer Begeisterung an Sie weiter!
Wer Robert dabei unterstützt seine Ausbildung zum Flugdienstberater in Paderborn zu finanzieren, erhält von uns (seinen Freunden) als Benefiz etwas, das wir mit Begeisterung tun.
Wir wissen, dass Robert nicht mehr so viel für uns da sein wird, aber wir freuen uns für Ihn, wenn er diese Chance nutzen kann!
story_txt:
Wir möchten, dass Robert seiner Begeisterung für die Luftfahrt folgen kann und unterstützen die Finanzierung seiner Ausbildung zum Flugdienstberater.
 
Was macht das Leben aus?
Wer sollte darüber bestimmen, was man tut? Was, wenn doch zu viele Steine im Weg sind und Hürden unüberwindbar scheinen? Die Begeisterung ist ein Antrieb, wenn nicht sogar der Antrieb, der den Erfolg schon beim Tun mit sich bringt.
Die Begeisterung liegt in der Luftfahrt.
Schon jeher... Der Flugsimulator am PC gehört zu seiner Standardinstallation. Über das Netz gründete und unterhielt er mit anderen Luftfahrtbegeisterten erfolgreich eine „Erfundene-Airline. Ein Highlight seiner Begeisterung war ein Flug im beweglichen Aviare Flugsimulator, mit dem auch Piloten trainiert werden. Er flog Singapur, Zürich und St. Marteen.
Robert gibt sehr viel.
Wir, seine Freunde wissen, dass Robert sehr viel gibt. Unter anderem als Jugendfeuerwehrwart der Freiwilligen Feuerwehr in Mohlsdorf. Er organisiert u.a. den Berufsfeuerwehrtag und sorgt somit für Weiterbildungen der Jugend. Im Rahmen der Feuerwehr und des Katastrophenschutzes sensibilisiert und unterrichtet er Kinder und Jugendliche in Kindergärten und Grundschulen für die Gefahren. Im Greizer Theaterherbst e.V. engagiert er sich. Er steht auf der Bühne und begeistert das Publikum zum Beispiel mit Improtheater. Aber auch hinter der Bühne unterstützt er den Verein bzw. das Theaterfestival mit viel Tatkraft. Bei dem Greizer Stadtmagazin 12°Ost bringt er viele Ideen, aber auch mitreißende lesenswerte Artikel.

Robert möchte seiner Luftfahrt Begeisterung mehr Platz im Leben einräumen und in Paderborn eine Ausbildung zum Flugdienstberater machen. story:
UGANDA: Only 32% of children in Uganda have the opportunity to complete primary education. Until 2006, devastating political conflict and rebellion beleaguered northern Ugandan children for over two decades, leaving this region of the world underdeveloped and virtually forgotten. Health-related issues such as female menstruation and sexual/reproductive health still remain taboo to discuss in the Ugandan culture, and consequently are not taught in schools, leaving youth with very little knowledge about their bodies and rights.

THE GIRLS: The girls’ ability to achieve their full potential is limited by this lack of knowledge coupled with major health and inequality concerns, including domestic abuse, gender-based violence, dropping out of school due to lack of funding or household responsibilities, HIV/AIDS, sexually transmitted diseases (STD's), early marriage, and unwanted pregnancy.

Schools often do not have the proper accommodations, including: appropriate bathrooms, feminine products, adequate sanitation, or even a place to dispose of used feminine products. Millions of girls in developing countries like Uganda miss up to 20% of the school year because they cannot afford mainstream sanitary products when they menstruate or because their schools lack proper facilities. Therefore, a girl’s right to an education can be dramatically curtailed when schools lack these necessary tools.

US: Educate for Change (E4C) is a 501c3 non-profit organization founded by two change-seeking American women and one Ugandan woman, determined to change educational opportunities in Uganda after teaching in the Ugandan school system and observing the steep educational inequalities.

E4C was founded to empower the most vulnerable children in northern Uganda by providing high-performing primary male and female students with scholarships to secondary school. Since it’s inception in 2012, we have managed to make a secondary education possible for over 40 students. Our scholarship program aims at keeping these high-achieving students in the school system even if their families cannot afford further schooling.  Check out our website today at www.educateforchange.us.

OUR PROJECT: This summer E4C will host recurring multi-day Health and Leadership Camps to provide imperative education to female youth on topics including feminine health, sexual health, self-defense, and self-esteem. But we need your help!  In order to best prepare, we have a pilot project scheduled for April 24-26th with our Educate for Change female scholarship beneficiaries.  In order to make this three day, boarding camp work, we need $1,500 (tax deductible).  

In July and August 2015, Health and Leadership camps will be held in several sessions for students from various villages. Taking place throughout rural northern Uganda, each camp will provide approximately 100 at-risk girls with critical information on topics including feminine health (menstruation, HIV/AIDS and STD's, pregnancy), gender issues (domestic abuse, gender-based violence), self-defense, and self-esteem.

By providing a comfortable and culturally sensitive atmosphere, girls will become educated, empowered, and able to make smart decisions that benefit their general and sexual health for the rest of their lives. Attendees will receive reusable feminine products, providing approximately 400 girls with a better means of dealing with their monthly cycle.

The learning and passing on of knowledge will be a boundless cycle of change after the program ends. These girls will be equipped to serve as information ambassadors to their peers in the village; spreading accurate, life-changing information about sexual health/care, self-defense, and self-esteem and creating a long-lasting, effective and sustainable project.

YOU: We are hoping to take a step further than school scholarships and provide our girls with an opportunity to gain lifelong skills to care for themselves and their sisters, but we need your help! All pledges on this page will be allocated to the expenses for the three-day pilot camp session which includes: venue, menstrual kits, visual aids/education materials, guest speakers and educators, food, housing and transportation.

By funding this project, you will have a direct hand in a life changing experience for over 400 young girls. Consider a financial contribution to aid in the expansion of knowledge, resources, and an equal right to education!

story:
Merhaba

Ben Batman’ın merkez köyüne bağlı Aydınkonak Ortaokulu’nda görev yapan Bilişim Teknolojileri ve Yazılım öğretmeniyim. Okulum, daha doğrusu öğrencilerim için bu kampanyayı başlatmak istedim.

 

Okulumuz tek blok, 32 derslikten oluşan, 2015 Mart ayında teslim aldığımız bir yeni bir okul. Okulumuzun öğrenci sayısı 1000’i geçmektedir.  Dersliklerin ise -öğretmen ihtiyacından dolayı- sadece 14 tanesi kullanımdadır.  Ortalama sınıf mevcudu 40-45 öğrenciden oluşmaktadır. Okulumuzdaki öğretmen arkadaşlarımızla birlikte bu yeni eğitim kurumunun ihtiyaçlarını karşılamak adına oldukça emek veriyoruz.

 

 

2013 yılında Bilişim Teknolojileri ve Yazılım dersi yaratıcı- eleştirel -analitik-üç boyutlu düşünebilme, neden sonuç ilişkilerini kurabilme, özgüven geliştirme, girişimcilik gibi kazanımlarla 5. ve 6. Sınıflara haftada 2 saat olmak üzere zorunlu ders,  7. ve 8. Sınıflarda ise hafta iki saat seçmeli ders haline getirilmiştir. Fakat uygulamaya konulan bu ders gerek laboratuvar gerekse donanım altyapısı sağlanmadan uygulamaya konulduğu amacına hizmet edemiyor.

 

 

Yapılandırmacı eğitim anlayışına göre yaparak/yaşayarak öğrenmenin gerçekleşmesi gereken bu uygulama dersi, okulumuzda teoriden pratiğe geçememektedir.  Milli Eğitim Bakanlığına gerekli donanımların sağlanması için yapılan başvurularımız olumsuz sonuçlanmış, Fatih Projesi’nin beklenilmesi yönünde dönüşler alınmıştır. 

İnsanlar okuduklarının % 10’unu, işittiklerinin % 20’sini, hem görüp hem de işittiklerinin% 50’sini, söylediklerinin % 70’ini ve yapıp söyledikleri bir şeyin ise % 90’ını hatırlar. Öğretimde görsel ve işitsel araçlar kullanıldığında öğrenme hem daha çabuk ve hem de daha kalıcı olduğundan biz de öğrencilerimize daha sağlıklı bir eğitim verebilmek için bu ortamı sağlamalıyız. Bu bağlamda okulumuzun bilgisayar ihtiyacının karşılanması için yardım talep etmekteyiz.

Şimdiden her şey için teşekkür ederim.

Çağlar GÜLCEK
Aydınkonak Ortaokulu – Bilişim Teknolojileri Öğrt.

caglargulcek@gmail.com

 
 

********************************************************

 

Hello,

I am a teacher of information technology and computer in a country school in Batman. I pioneer to this campaign for my students who have not touched to real computers more than seeing on TV. In March, 2015, we moved to our new school consisting of 32 classrooms. we have more than 1000 students. As long as visual and auditory teaching materials are used, learning occurs faster and more permanently. Therefore we are trying to provide our students with more productive learning environment. In order to reach our purpose we request your donations for our school. Thank you for everything in advance.

 

Çağlar GÜLCEK

caglargulcek@gmail.com

 

 

 

********************************************************

story:
Hi Everyone!

   My name is Andreja Morrison and I am a 14 year old  from Ontario, Canada. For as long as I can remember I’ve wanted to make a difference. How? By helping those less fortunate than myself. Craig Kielburger has been a big influence on me and many other youth, helping to change the mind set of our generation from ‘Me’ to ‘We’.

   In 2018, I plan to embark on a volunteer trip to a developing country to learn about leadership and social change through the ‘Me to We’ organization.  To kickstart my journey, I am hosting a fundraiser where all profits from the evening will go towards my opportunity  to participate in a "Me To We" trip, learning first-hand about issues in developing countries, and learning how to reach beyond our borders to make positive change in the world.

   The total cost of the trip is $5000 but I am starting with a goal of $1000. In the future, I plan to continue fundraising for a 2 year period of time until I reach my goal, starting my travel at 16 years old. With my part time job working at a local art studio and maintaining an 80% average in my last year of elementary school, it is often hard to find time to help create change, but it has never stopped me before. Being an advocate for social change, I have participated in food and clothing drives, vows of silence, equality discussions and much more. Having gone to school my whole life and being privileged enough to even have the option of travel, I am extremely excited to help people in developing countries reach goals of equality similar to mine. Everybody deserves the potential to make their dreams come true. Helping others is my dream, and hopefully once I raise this money, I can help them to achieve their dreams also.

   I appreciate you taking your time to listen to my story and my goal. Even if you cannot donate, it would mean so much to me if you spread the word about my goal to others.

   By helping fund my volunteer travel, you will not only be helping me to become a leader who can inspire and motivate others, but you will also be making the world a better place for everyone.

Thank You!

story:
Belgrade VIP in a nutshell

What shall we do this weekend? It's a question all of us ask. Maybe we'll take in a basketball game or attend a tennis match. Maybe we'll go hiking or visit a museum. Are there any good movies at the cinema? Who's playing at local nightclubs? Is there a ballet performance this week?

For 20,000 English  expatriates, executives, and embassy employees here in Belgrade, making plans is no simple matter. This European capital is quickly becoming a tourism hotspot but there is no English-language resource that lists options.

What exhibits are opening at the capital's museums? Where can I find a gym with a swimming pool? What exhibitions are coming to the Belgrade Sajam, the expo center? What family and children's events are coming to town? How long will the carnival be here before it moves on? What international entertainers are coming to play at the Kalemegdan and the Sava Centar? Where can I sign up for a tour of Belgrade's wine country or its historic pre-Roman settlements? What are some good destinations for weekend getaways? Where do I find local mineral hot springs and spas?

I'm J.D. Hildebrand. I've been producing information products - magazines, blogs, brochures, whitepapers, websites - since 1983. I've lived in Serbia for the past five years and I have heard dozens of expats lament the difficulty of exploring this part of the world and taking advantage of all it has to offer.

That's why I am looking to launch the Belgrade VIP program:

  • It gives English-speaking residents and visitors convenient access to information they need.
  • It gives Serbian businesses cost-effective access to an audience elite, affluent customers.
  • It allows me to support my family doing the work I love doing.

How to get involved

The Belgrade VIP program isn't going to make anyone rich, but it should provide a good living for three staff members and generate enough profits for us to make contributions to charity a couple times a year. We'll be directing at least part of our charitable giving to the Susan G. Komen breast cancer foundation. You can help us choose where to send the rest.

I forecast break-even well before the end of year one. We're looking for operating expenses as we ramp up to 100 percent revenue. We expect 10,000 euros will cover cash-flow needs during that period, though we would be glad to raise a bit more.

That amount will cover start-up costs, including legal and accounting consultations. We won't be renting an office or purchasing computers. Workers will be self-employed under Serbia's "agency" tax designation. The main cost is salaries during the first three or four months of operation as revenues ramp up.

Impact

I have surveyed the English-speaking community here to assess their interest in an information product like this. There is high demand for information about local events, about Serbian culture and history, and about nearby travel destinations. This is also a unique, cost-effective opportunity for local businesses to reach out to the small but affluent English-speaking expat community.

With Belgrade VIP we'll send a weekly newsletter of current events to everyone who visits our website and subscribes. The newsletter will also include an updated list of discounts and special programs currently offered to our elite members - so every issue we send out will also be a marketing piece.

In addition to listings, we can expand the website to include reviews and blog posts from expats who are exploring the Balkans.

I have worked closely with the English-speaking expat community. A couple years ago I teamed up with the Belgrade Foreign Visitors Club to launch Stranac Academy, a night school for English-speaking adults. BFVC has promised to cooperate with the Belgrade VIP program, including marketing the program on its Facebook page and website, access to its email list, and more. 

Risks

The idea of a paid-membership discount program is proven in America but not among expats. It may be that we need to adjust our program to emphasize unique members-only events, not discounts. It may be that our 79-euro annual price is too high or that we are unable to convince Serbian businesses to offer discounts to our members.

An enterprise of this size is highly dependent on the personnel. I'm confident that I can use WordPress, themes, plug-ins, and Mailchimp to set up the program and that I can write all the copy. But if the project were to lose my involvement, I would be tough to replace.

We will be similarly dependent on our sales manager, who will reach out to Serbian language schools, restaurants, splavs, kafanas, and other businesses to offer discounts to members. Hiring the wrong sales manager, or losing a competent one unexpectedly, could damage our prospects.

Growth opportunities

Once the website and membership program are off the ground, we can expand the business with events. Once or twice a month we can have breakfast programs featuring presentations from experts in Serbian culture and history, Serbian tax law and real estate regulations, business law, Serbian holiday traditions, and more. 

The website and membership program serve as a platform for the breakfast programs and other ancillary businesses. They establish a relationship of authority and trust between us and the expat community. That relationship allows us to pursue further business opportunities that are much more profitable than the "main" project.

Thank you very much!

Impact

I have surveyed the English-speaking community here to assess their interest in an information product like this. There is high demand for information about local events, about Serbian culture and history, and about nearby travel destinations. This is also a unique, cost-effective opportunity for local businesses to reach out to the small but affluent English-speaking expat community.
With Belgrade VIP we'll send a weekly newsletter of current events to everyone who visits our website and subscribes. The newsletter will also include an updated list of discounts and special programs currently offered to our elite members - so every issue we send out will also be a marketing piece.
In addition to listings, we can expand the website to include reviews and blog posts from expats who are exploring the Balkans.
I have worked closely with the English-speaking expat community. A couple years ago I teamed up with the Belgrade Foreign Visitors Club to launch Stranac Academy, a night school for English-speaking adults. BFVC has promised to cooperate with the Belgrade VIP program, including marketing the program on its Facebook page and website, access to its email list, and more. 
Risks
The idea of a paid-membership discount program is proven in America but not among expats. It may be that we need to adjust our program to emphasize unique members-only events, not discounts. It may be that our 79-euro annual price is too high or that we are unable to convince Serbian businesses to offer discounts to our members.
An enterprise of this size is highly dependent on the personnel. I'm confident that I can use WordPress, themes, plug-ins, and Mailchimp to set up the program and that I can write all the copy. But if the project were to lose my involvement, I would be tough to replace.
We will be similarly dependent on our sales manager, who will reach out to Serbian language schools, restaurants, splavs, kafanas, and other businesses to offer discounts to members. Hiring the wrong sales manager, or losing a competent one unexpectedly, could damage our prospects.
Growth opportunities
Once the website and membership program are off the ground, we can expand the business with events. Once or twice a month we can have breakfast programs featuring presentations from experts in Serbian culture and history, Serbian tax law and real estate regulations, business law, Serbian holiday traditions, and more. 
The website and membership program serve as a platform for the breakfast programs and other ancillary businesses. They establish a relationship of authority and trust between us and the expat community. That relationship allows us to pursue further business opportunities that are much more profitable than the "main" project.
Thank you very much!

story:
Operation Refugee Child has moved to a new campaign page! Thank you all for your support please click on the link below for our new campaign! 

            OUR NEW CAMPAIGN LINK FOR ORC 

          

OPERATION REFUGEE CHILD 

Our Mission

Operation Refugee Child (ORC), will distribute backpacks with basic necessities to bring comfort, health, safety and warmth to refugee children and families who have left everything behind.  ORC will distribute at least 10,000 backpacks to refugee children in 2016. 

We collect and personally distribute relief packs to refugee families fleeing violence, oppression and persecution to aid refugees in their journeys to safety.

HOW YOU CAN HELP! 
1.) Sponsor a relief pack: http://igg.me/at/OperationRefugeeChild
2) Volunteer with us to help assemble and distribute backpacks.
https://www.facebook.com/Operationrefugeechild
3) Set up a corporate partnership for in-kind or financial support to Operation Refugee Child
4) Buy supplies for a refugee child backpack from our official Amazon Wish List (https://amzn.com/w/1SU5N1J43VKCB)
5) Like and share this campaign! 
Twitter: @oprefugeechild
Instagram: @operationrefugeechild
Facebook:http://www.facebook.com/Operationrefugeechild/
5) Pack a shoebox to fill a refugee child backpack (coming soon).

A Message From Our Team

Operation Refugee Child will help aid those who have left everything behind and have little or nothing to eat or keep themselves warm. As parents, we work hard to keep our children warm, healthy and safe, and it is our intention to keep helping these families and children who need us the most. The Syrian Refugee crisis really hit home, as many of us have children the same age as sweet little Aylan Kurdi, whose body washed ashore after attempting to reach Europe with his family.

We are a volunteer group of over 5,000 people who have united together from across the globe with one common goal of aiding refugees families. Over 9,000 refugees are arriving daily in Greece and 30% of them are children (UNHCR). Facing torrential rains and the onset of winter, refugee families urgently need food to eat and clothing and supplies to stay warm, clean, and healthy as they continue on their journey across Europe.

However, there is little to no support on the ground for refugees; local governments are underfunded and overwhelmed, and large aid organizations have a surprisingly minimal presence.

As parents, we want the best for our children, and we make these decisions based first on safety. You wouldn’t put your family in a tiny boat to cross the sea unless you knew it was safer than land. If and when these families survive the boat ride across the Aegean Sea, they face hardships on land with no food, shelter or warm clothes. We want to aid these families with items that can help ease their transition on their journey to asylum. Refugees are sleeping in the parks without shelter, water, food, bathrooms, medicine, or dry clothes.

Operation Refugee Child will provide refugee families with supplies for a healthier and safer journey to their asylum destination through direct volunteer distribution of donations. All it takes is one person to start changing the world, and it can start with you! We look forward to delivering your Operation Refugee Child Relief Pack to a refugee family soon!

Our volunteers work as a team to provide refugee families with essential items* that they will need on their long journey.  ORC backpacks will include items such as: Mylar blankets, Thermal sleeping bag (heavy duty), Battery-less flashlights, Adult poncho, Inflatable pillow, Kid poncho, Emergency whistle, 1st aid kits 54 piece, Hand warmers, Rehydration salts, Balloons, Fleece hat, Mittens, Toothbrush/toothpaste, Baby socks, Chapstick, Plush toys, Sharpie marker, Purell, ID Lanyards, Collapsible water bottles, Caribiner 25 lb, 4 pack crayons, Drawing pad, Baby food, Protein bars, Halal beef jerky, Diaper rash cream, Candy, Pacifiers, Warm baby blankets, Wool headscarf, Vaseline, Chamois towels, Tea Tree Oil, Baby bottles & Nipples, Ready to use formula.

*Companies who manufacture these products are invited to join our growing list of corporate partners. Please contact operationrefugeechild@gmail.com

 All it takes is one person to start changing the world and it can start with you!  

Thank you! 

The ORC team

story:
A propos de moi

Je m'appelle Jeanne et je viens de terminer ma dernière année de Licence Etudes Cinématographiques et Audiovisuelles à L'Université Paris-Est Marne-la-Vallée. Pour cette dernière année, je suis partie en tant qu'étudiante d'échange aux Etats-Unis, en Californie. Durant deux semestres, j'ai pu apprendre aux côtés de professeurs renommés comme John Wineglass (Compositeur et Lauréat de trois Emmy Awards entre 2001 et 2005) et nouer des relations extraordinaires avec des étudiants de nombreux pays. Aussi ai-je décidé de repartir pour un an, cette fois sans support financier de la part de mon Université.

Effectuer une année supplémentaire à l'Université de Monterey Bay me permettrait de réaliser un court métrage de niveau professionnel avec toute une équipe d'étudiants passionnés. Je pourrais mettre en commun toutes les connaissances acquises pendant ma Licence pour créer un projet qui me tient à coeur et que je pourrais présenter à des festivals.


A quoi sert cette somme ?

10600$ est la somme requise pour l'inscription à la California State University Monterey Bay. En effet, en raison de 5300$ par semestre pour les étudiants étrangers, une année en Californie coûte cher.

C'est donc pour cela que j'ai besoin de votre aide ! Bien sûr, toute participation compte. Ainsi, même une petite somme peut m'aider à réaliser mon rêve. Mes parents prennent en charge mon loyer, l'argent recueilli me servira à payer mon inscription uniquement. Si le projet recueille plus d'argent que prévu, celui ci me servirait à:

  • Financer mon projet de fin d'année: un court-métrage professionnel.
  • Me donner un coup de pouce pour les dépenses du quotidien.

 

Pourquoi ?

La réalisation de films m'a toujours passionnée. Au cours de mes deux années d'études en France, je me suis rendue compte que la pratique n'était pas au coeur de mes études cinématographiques. Je me suis donc dirigée vers les Etats-Unis et j'ai eu la chance d'être sélectionnée sur dossier et de passer un an en Californie. Là-bas, j'ai travaillé sur plusieurs films, disponibles sur mon site internet.

http://jeannenicolassutter.weebly.com

J'ai aussi pu aider d'autres étudiants à réaliser leurs projets de fin d'études, des courts métrages professionnels qui servent de tremplins dans une profession aux débouchés assez fermés. Les voir ainsi s'épanouir m'a confirmée dans mon choix de réaliser à mon tour mon propre projet, avec votre aide.


Me soutenir autrement...

Me soutenir dans ce projet ne signifie pas forcément me soutenir financièrement. Ainsi, vous pouvez m'aider de bien des façons: 

  •  En partageant cette page avec vos amis afin de leur faire découvrir mon projet,
  •  En en parlant autour de vous, tout simplement !
